Global warming was a biggie for Senate farm bill writers, with three USDA studies outlined on: -Agriculture and forestry implications of global change. -Effects of global warming on rice production. -Experimental studies on the effects of global warming on the production of major U.S. crops. The House version of the farm bill included a heavy concentration on food aid to foreign countries, including one on World Food Day. Others included a report on ``wood and fish export promotion,'' which was listed next to Chairman de la Garza's favored study on cut flowers, followed by a ``commodity transportation and technology assessment'' report and a ``red tart cherry'' study.

DOC.HEAD: All Factions Touched by Lebanon Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD 1976 assassination of U.S. ambassador and economic counselor, SUB 3 grafs for grafs 24-25 pvs, `Malcolm Kerr ... his home.' Picks up 26th pvs, `On Oct. ...' ^By NICK LUDINGTON
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's political mob war has spared no one. Leaders from all major Moslem and Chrisiian groups in the bloody 15-year power struggle have been assassinated by bullets or bombs. The latest victim, Christian leader Dany Chamoun, was killed Sunday when five gunmen burst into his Beirut apartment. The five uniformed gunmen, who used silencer-equipped pistols, also murdered his wife and two small sons. The slayings were branded by Christian and Moslem leaders alike as an attempt to block a plan to end the civil war, which has primarily pitted Moslems against Christians. Chamoun, a Maronite Catholic and the son of late President Camille Chamoun, was one of the most outspoken critics of President Elias Hrawi and Syria's military presence in Lebanon. He also was at odds with Christian warlord Samir Geagea, whose Lebanese Forces militia fought a four-month war with Gen. Michel Aoun's troops early this year for mastery of the Christian hinterland. Chamoun was a top supporter of Aoun, who took refuge in the French Embassy a week ago after being routed by government and Syrian troups. France has granted him asylum, but the government insists he stay and stand trial for alleged crimes. Chamoun's father, Camille, died a natural death in August 1987. But in 1980 and 1987, he narrowly escaped assassination when remote-controlled bombs exploded near his car, wounding him both times. On June 13, 1978, Christian militiamen loyal to Bashir Gemayel murdered Tony Franjieh, son and political heir of Suleiman Franjieh, president of Lebanon from 1970 to 1976. Franjieh's wife and three-year-old daughter were also killed. Gemayel later admitted that his men were involved - but said they had no authorization to kill Franjieh, who led a rival militia. Four years later, Gemayel was slain at age 34. Three weeks after being elected president on Aug. 23, 1982, he was killed in an explosion at the headquarters of his Phalange Party, the leading Maronite Christian political grouping. Rene Mouawad, head of an important Christian clan in northeast Lebanon, did not even last as long as Gemayel as president. On Nov. 22, 1989, just 17 days after his election, a remote-control bomb killed Mouawad. He was succeeded by Hrawi, who is seeking to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan. The most important surviving Christian militia leader, Geagea, has survived several assassination attempts. Moslem factions have also seen their top chiefs murdered. Prime Minister Rashid Karami, the most prominent Sunni Moslem leader in Lebanon, was killed June 1, 1987, when a bomb exploded aboard an army helicopter in which he was a passenger. The current prime minister, Salim Hoss, has tasted the threat of assassination. Hoss, a prominent Sunni Moslem leader, was education minister in 1984 when a bomb exploded as he drove to a mosque, wounding him with glass and shrapnel. Lebanon's largest religious group, the Shiite Moslems, lost their leader Musa Sadr. He disappeared in 1978 while on a trip to Libya, whose leader Moammar Gadhafi has backed the Sunnis. Sadr is presumed to have been murdered. Kamal Jumblatt, a prominent left-wing political leader and chief of Lebanon's Druse sect, which fields one of the toughest militias, was machine-gunned to death at a road ambush in March 1977. His son and successor, Walid Jumblatt, survives uneasily. In June 1987, he asked an aide to open a gift that appeared to be a case containing a pen. It exploded, blowing the aide's hands off. Prominent foreigners have also fallen in the spate of assassinations. In June 1976, kidnappers took U.S. Ambassador Francis E. Meloy and his economic counselor, Robert O. Waring, from their limousine. Their bullet-riddled bodies were recovered later at a beach in Moslem west Beirut. Four French Embassy staffers have been killed since 1981, including Ambassador Louis Delamar when three gunmen fired on him on Sept. 4, 1981, just outside his home. Malcolm Kerr, president of American University of Beirut, was shot to death in a hallway outside his office in January 1984. On Oct. 23, 1983, a suicide truck-bomber blew up the headquarters of the French contingent of the multinational peacekeeping force in Beirut, killing 58 French soldiers. A similar bombing was carried out at the same time against the force's U.S. Marine contingent, killing 241 Americans. The bombings were claimed by the pro-Iranian Shiite extremist group called Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. An estimated 150,000 people have died in Lebanon's civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops May Be Regrouping North
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops are continually repositioning themselves inside Kuwait, making it ``entirely possible'' that a large number of forces have regrouped in the north, according to Pentagon and private analysts. Lt. Col. Steve Roy, a Pentagon spokesman, said Sunday he could not confirm a report from the Persian Gulf that Iraqi forces have begun pulling back to the northern part of the country. But he said the report was ``entirely possible'' because of constant Iraqi troop movements in Kuwait, the oil-rich country Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. U.S. officials estimate Iraq has up to 400,000 troops in or around Kuwait. Al-Khaleej, a newspaper in Sharjah, one of the United Arab Emirates, reported Sunday that hundreds of tanks and armored vehicles and armored personnel carriers have been sighted heading toward north Kuwait, specifically to the region of Matla. The paper gave no source for its report, and independent verification could not be obtained because journalists have been unable to enter Kuwait recently. The Iraqi forces were grouping around a fence in the occupied country, the paper said. Last week, Kuwaiti refugees said Iraqis were building a fence in the region of Matla, surrounding the islands of Warba and Bubiyan and the Rumailah oil field. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein claimed these regions before Aug. 2. Marshall Wiley, a former ambassador to Iraq now in private business, said Saddam might be inclined to increase protection of the oil field and the islands if he believed the United States was prepared to launch offensive action. James Akins, a former ambassador to Saudi Arabia an now a private consultant, said the Bush administration's ``worst nightmare'' would be for Saddam to withdraw from most of Kuwait, clinging only to the huge oil field and the islands. Saddam has long sought the islands because they give Iraq access to the sea. Such a scenario would force the administration to justify keeping 200,000 troops in Saudi Arabia even though Saddam had left most of Kuwait, Akins said. The Bush administration and the United Nations have insisted that Iraq withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait and returning control of its government to the al-Sabah family now in exile. There have been conflicting interpretations of what Saddam intends to do in Kuwait, a country his troops have systematically looted over the past 2{ months. CIA Director William Webster said in an interview with The Associated Press last week that ``everything suggests he is there for the long haul.'' Webster said Saddam's troops are ``dug in.'' Another intelligence analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam's fall-back position might be to relinquish all of Kuwait except the islands and the oil field. Last week, a London-based Iraqi opposition group said Iraq was considering withdrawing from Kuwait. The Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq said Iraq's ruling political party had circulated a questionnaire asking key members for their opinion on the issue. In other developments Sunday: - Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, insisted that only Congress has the right to declare war. Mitchell reiterated a position that has put Congress at odds with top Bush administration officials. ``Only Congress can make that grave decision,'' Mitchell said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. Last week, Secretary of State James A. Baker III refused to commit the administration to getting any advance congressional approval for any military action. - The Middle East Policy Survey, a newsletter published in Washington, reported that a few days before Saddam invaded Kuwait, Bush sent a message to the Iraqi president. The message, relayed to the Iraqi foreign minister, expressed the administration's concern about Iraqi troop movements, but said the United States wanted improved U.S.-Iraqi relations. The Washington Post in Sunday's editions quoted sources as confirming that Bush wrote a presidential message which was supposed to be relayed to Saddam through April Glaspie, the U.S. ambassador to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Hits $1.47 a Gallon at the Pump
DOC.TEXT: The price of a gallon of gasoline rose an additional 2{ cents in the past two weeks, reaching a national average of $1.4709, an industry analyst says. That's an increase of more than 40 cents since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gas stations. The dealers' margin stands at about 11 cents a gallon, down 2 cents a gallon from before the Middle East crisis, analyst Trilby Lundberg said Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Right Message Eluding Woman Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Josie Heath was showered with national attention when she became the only woman in the country to launch a serious Democratic bid for the U.S. Senate this year. The former Boulder County commissioner attracted support from women's groups with her pro-choice abortion stance and she captured the Democratic nomination in August after a tough primary election campaign against attorney Carlos Lucero. Then she ran up against Republican Rep. Hank Brown. Brown, who has been in Congress 10 years, holds a comfortable lead in the pols and is gaining ground. His well-financed campaign emphasizes the congressman's independent streak. For example, Brown has been a diehard opponent of new taxes. And he has a more moderate record than the current holder of the seat, GOP Sen. Bill Armstrong, on issues such as abortion and the environment. Brown never has been a Republican Party ``goose-stepper,'' says press aide Katy Atkinson. ``He's voted against Ronald Reagan, and he's voted against Bush - even though Bush has been out here twice to raise money for him.'' The fact that Brown is an incumbent is not a drawback in Colorado. ``Simply to be a part of the news flow that comes out of the nation's capitol, at this point, is not a disadvantage,'' said Rick Ridder, a political consultant to Democratic candidates. ``We've not seen any anti-incumbency movement in Colorado, unlike Massachusetts.'' Brown ``is so popular right now I think people just aren't going to change - no matter what the television ads say,'' says longtime lobbyist Stan Sours of Denver. During the primary campaign, Heath, 53, proposed converting the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant to a toxic waste research facility. She also favored some form of national health care. But in the race against Brown, she has spent much of her time attacking her opponent, characterizing him as an advocate for polluters and a friend of savings and loan wheeler-dealers. Lately she has toned down that approach. But she has failed to establish who she is and what she stands for. ``You cannot launch an attack on someone without establishing your own base - it's fundamental,'' said longtime Democratic consultant Jim Monaghan. Aside from her reputation as a hard-working Boulder County commissioner, she has no established political credentials. ``It's clear that voters do not yet know who Josie is,'' acknowledges Heath coordinator Bobby McCallum. Brown was leading Heath 57 percent to 29 percent in the latest poll. His lead went up 8 percentage points in two weeks. He also is way ahead in campaign finances, collecting more than $2.5 million in donations to Heath's $1.25 million. McCallum predicts a major shift in support when Heath's campaign airs new television ads, claiming that only 36 percent of Brown's support is solid. And Heath's camp has enough money to make ``a decent buy'' on the airwaves, he says. Some feel Heath may have turned some Democrats off during her vitriolic clashes with Lucero before the August primary. ``In Colorado, if they (the voters) don't know you, they don't really like to see you come out blasting someone they do know,'' said one political advisor, who asked not to be identified because she is working for a Republican candidate. Heath's views on defense also don't play well with many of Colorado's conservative Democrats. Early in the primary campaign, she proposed cutting the defense budget by half over 10 years. That backfired after the primary when political cartoonists juxtaposed her stand on defense with depictions of Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. In addition, Heath is emphasizing her opposition to the line item veto and a proposed balanced budget amendment when more and more of the state's Democrats are embracing those ideas.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Students Risked Another Tiananmen, And Won
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 went on hunger strike. Six were hospitalized. But in the end, the students who created a bloodless version of Tiananmen Square in the Ukraine were sad to go home. For 16 days this month, the pro-independence hunger strikers lived in a tent city on the main square of Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, deliberately duplicating the tactics of pro-democracy Chinese students in Beijing in 1989. The Ukrainian students gambled that Soviet authorities would not dare to follow China's example and send the army to crush them. They turned out to be right. ``We went in with cold minds, prepared for any kind of conflict, but with the conviction that the only real path open to the government was peaceful,'' said Vladimir Boyarsky, a 22-year-old medical student. On Wednesday, the Ukrainian government capitulated to most of the students' demands for faster steps toward independence, including the resignation of the republic's prime minister. On Thursday, they took down the tents they had staked between cracks in the marble slabs of Revolution Square. And over the weekend, they headed back to their homes across this fertile republic of 51 million people, the breadbasket of the Soviet Union. ``After the government announced it was giving in, we went wild with joy,'' Boyarsky said Friday. ``Then we all realized that this piece of our lives was ending, we would be heading off in different directions, and hardly anyone slept that night with all the sentimental goodbyes.'' That sentiment was far removed from the tension the students felt on the first day of the hunger strike, Oct. 2, when seven busloads of riot police pulled up to the square. The strike had been planned for weeks, in extreme detail, by the Ukrainian Student Union in Kiev and the Student Brotherhood in Lvov, a city of 770,000 in the Western Ukraine. Both groups were angry over the lack of progress toward independence by the republic's parliament since it declared sovereignty July 16. They demanded bolder moves, such as those taken by the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. ``Every nation has a right to self-determination on its own territory,'' law student Igor Osobik, 22, said Friday. ``You know, more than 40 million Ukrainians have been killed in the period of Soviet power, from famine and from bullets. Why can't we be masters of our own fate, our own future, our own land?'' On Oct. 2, a day after the Ukrainian parliament opened its session, 120 hunger strikers and 50 supporters set up the first 22 tents on Revolution Square, under a towering bronze statue of Lenin. Supporters wore armbands to mark their pre-assigned roles: red for medics; black for guards keeping order in the camp; blue for people serving tea and cleaning up. They had a permit for a demonstration, but not for the tents. While fearing a police raid at any minute, they concentrated on explaining their position to passers-by. The students accused the parliamentary majority, a bloc of 239 Communist Party members, of ``toadying to Moscow.'' They argued that the Communists and the republic's prime minister, Vitaly Masol, were trying to thwart real independence by moving toward a new union treaty with other Soviet republics at the urging of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They vowed to remain on the square until the parliament agreed to six demands: Masol's resignation; rejection of any new union treaty; permission for all Ukrainians in the Soviet army to serve on Ukrainian soil; nationalization of Communist Party property in the Ukraine; dissolution of parliament; and new elections. ``The first day there was a very heavy feeling, because we didn't know what the police were going to do,'' said Boyarsky. ``But all they did was surround us, and the next day, we began what you might call normal life.'' History student Lyudmila Demirskaya, 25, said most of the students spent their days singing folk songs and meeting new arrivals, who came at the rate of more than 50 a day from schools across the republic, swelling the camp to more than 800 people. A total of 217 students registered as hunger strikers for varying lengths of time. About 20 reportedly went without food for a full two weeks. Christopher Kedzie, a Harvard University researcher working on economic reform in the Ukraine, said he walked by the tent city every day and was ``amazed at two things: the discipline of the students and the outpouring of support'' from Kiev residents, who brought mattresses, blankets, money and flowers. Thousands of people marched through the city last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesdaty to support the students' demands. Students claim the largest march, on the 17th, involved more than 100,000 people; authorities say it was only 20,000. Whatever the figure, public support for the students was strong enough that parliament realized ``we had to take them seriously, and the only rational course was compromise,'' said Alexander Kotzuba, a centrist lawmaker. On Wednesday evening, Masol agreed to resign, and parliament passed a resolution promising to put off signing a new union treaty and saying all Ukrainian soldiers should be allowed to serve inside the republic. It also set up a commission to work on nationalizing Communist Party property and called for a referendum to decide whether to dissolve parliament and hold new elections. ``Last week, we felt the strength of our youth,'' Sergei Sukhov, a 62-year-old printer, said on a Kiev streetcorner. ``Not all of us were at the demonstrations, but we supported, they won, and they are now the pride of our nation.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Parting Not So Sweet, or Sad, for Retiring Lawmakers
DOC.TEXT: Retiring from Congress this year must feel like stepping off a runaway train: Relief mixed with concern - and no regrets. ``One of my burdens is being teased by my colleagues for having such incredible timing,'' laughs Rep. Bob Whittaker, R-Kan. ``I'm glad I'm going to do it now.'' The budget mess, government shutdown, ethics scandals and the pay raise have made this latest Congress even more hateable than usual. But if the historical pattern holds, and it may not, there will be few House incumbents sent packing by the voters on Nov. 6. There are a handful packing their own bags for home. Eleven out of 434 House members are retiring - not defeated, just leaving. Conversations with most of them reveal some bitterness, a longing for happier times and a wish they were retiring from a Congress with higher public esteem. ``It takes you out with a bad taste in your mouth,'' the way the 101st Congress has performed, said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., who labored mightily to find a bipartisan budget only to have the House shoot it down. ``It's no fun to be part of a group that can't get its work done.'' Rep. Jim Courter, R-N.J., ran for governor last year. He could have kept his House seat, but decided against seeking another term. He feels he's been proven right. People who questioned ``the rightness and correctness of my decision'' are now coming up and saying, ``I don't blame you,'' he said. Courter, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said things had changed for the worse over the 12 years he's spent in the House. He related how he was barred from recent House-Senate talks on the defense budget, and then was threatened if he didn't sign the agreement. ``They told me, `You've put some language in there (the bill). It's going to come out unless you sign it,''' he said. He didn't sign. ``It's a heck of a way to go out,'' he sighed, looking forward to what he said would be ``a more simple life.'' Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., saw her husband Hale give his life to the House. She now is retiring from the seat he once held. The current gloom ``gives me particular pain because I spent so many years in the institution.'' But she takes solace in the work she did on marking Congress' bicentennial. ``When this temporary difficulty is passed, (that) will be there to sustain the institution ... the People's Body,'' she said. Whittaker, who'll be teaching political science at the University of Kansas, said he wasn't worried about Congress. He said there have been other periods when the legislative branch was held in low regard. ``From a historical perspective, it's something that goes around,'' he said. Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, says he hopes people will see something positive in his retirement from an influential congressional career at age 59. ``People say nobody walks away from that job. Well, somebody did. And maybe that gives a little bit of faith to people who think the system is so totally corrupt and bad. It really isn't,'' Leath said. Rep. Virginia Smith, R-Neb., though saddened by the current uproar, remains sentimental about the place. ``It's been 16 great years,'' she said, recalling how she ``had to win over nine handsome young men just to come to Congress'' at a time when women were still considered unusual in politics. ``I'm going to miss these folks,'' she said, but ``we want to leave while we're still young enough to look forward to going home.'' Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., is a powerful committee chairman who looks forward to returning to private life after 28 years - and complaining about Congress. ``It's good. I'm glad to see it,'' he said of the national discontent. ``And I'll be one of those outsiders attacking.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Policemen Killed by Sikh Land Mine
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists lured a government patrol down a lonely road early today and exploded a land mine that killed four policemen and wounded 10, a police official said. Three police jeeps were dispatched to Vadalakan after Sikh gunmen fired on a police post at the village, according to Parmjit Singh, senior superintendent of police of the surrounding Majitha district. When the patrol approached the village 25 miles east of Amritsar, a land mine exploded between the first two jeeps, he said. No one was injured by the gunfire directed at the police post, Singh said. Similar attacks have been staged often in Punjab in order to ambush policemen rushing to the assistance of colleagues. Sikh militants fighting to create an independent nation in Punjab state have killed at least 2,430 people so far this year, making 1990 certain to be the extremists' deadliest year since their separatist revolt started in 1983. The worst previous year was 1988 when about 2,440 people were killed by the militants in Punjab, a prosperous farming state northwest of New Delhi. The Sikh militants accuse India's Hindu-dominated government of economic and political discrimination. Sikhs hold a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab, but nationwide they make up only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus have a national majority of 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Finds Former Hostage Label a Political Liability
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Hermening is still searching for the right start to his political career a decade after his release as an Iranian hostage. He is fighting his past as much as his political rival. The former hostage label is a political noose to him. ``It is the single major liability to my running for office,'' said Hermening. The 31-year-old Republican is running for the Wisconsin Assembly after two failed bids for Congress. ``The people of the community are sick and tired of it,'' Hermening said of his hostage past. ``The biggest difficulty is most people think the only thing I have done has been in Iran.'' Hermening, a former Marine guard, was the youngest of the 52 people held hostage for 444 days at the U.S. Embassy in Iran in 1979. Since returning to Wisconsin, he has worked for a political consulting firm and run twice unsuccessfully for Congress, losing in 1986 and 1988 to Democratic Rep. David Obey. Hermening scaled back his political ambitions in June, announcing he would challenge state Rep. Brad Zweck, a two-term Democrat. He is running in a north-central Wisconsin district that has elected five different legislators in the past 12 years. Running for the legislature is a ``relief actually,'' not a letdown, Hermening said. ``Running for Congress in the `80s and `90s is like trying to scale a mountain with none of the gear,'' Hermening said. ``Unless you are a self-made millionaire, you simply don't have a chance.'' A year ago, on the 10-year anniversary of the seizure of the embassy in Iran, Hermening said the experience drove everything he did. Today, he tries to distance himself. Politics dictates such a strategy, he says. Hermening has received letters from people praising him for his courage. But letters accusing him of cowardice come too: ``Kevin Hermening and other Marines surrendered the fort. They gave up the ship,'' one letter said. Hermening has sent out about 75 campaign news releases over the past five years, none of which mentioned Iran or the hostages. He's asked newspapers editors not to refer to him as a former Iranian hostage - at least not in the first three words of their stories. ``My campaign brochure doesn't have a picture of me with a Marine uniform,'' Hermening said. Zweck says Hermening's celebrity status is a ``two-edged sword.'' People have a very strong first impression of him, ``one way or the other,'' the incumbent said. But Zweck isn't so sure voters question Hermening only about his role in the Iranian hostage crisis. Some wonder if he is a carpetbagger who moved from his native Milwaukee to northern Wisconsin only to run for Congress, Zweck said. ``They resent he abused that status and moved into a strange area and immediately ran for office,'' Zweck said. Hermening's well-publicized involvement in protests against Indian hunting and fishing rights in northern Wisconsin also irritates some voters, Zweck added. ``Those are types of activities that make you a great person in the eyes of some but a very negative figure in the eyes of others,'' the lawmaker said. Hermening, a self-described conservative, said he's always been interested in public service. He's owned a home in the district for 3{ years. ``Tell me what Brad Zweck ever did to better qualify him for running for office compared to what I did,'' he asks. While Hermening shuns the ``former hostage'' label in public, he maintains personal pride in the ordeal he survived. And he feels a special concern for those now held hostage in Iraq. ``I have got my medals displayed prominently. I have a flag outside my house. You're damn right I am proud of it,'' Hermening said. ``I have a big yellow ribbon outside my house. Millions of people put them up for me. The least I can do is put one up for them.''

DOC.HEAD: House Votes Limits on Mailing Privileges
DOC.TEXT: Stung by public criticism, the House is moving to force its members to tell the public how much postage-free mail they send and rein in those lawmakers who abuse the privilege. New limits on how much mail House members can send out free were made part of a $2.2 billion bill that provides money to operate Congress in the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The bill was approved 292-117 Sunday and sent to the Senate. The bipartisan compromise limit on Congress' franking privilege, adopted on a voice vote, was a sign that lawmakers are nervous about their low standing in the public eye. With that in mind, and with elections just 16 days away, the House also voted $76 million in spending cuts before giving final approval to the appropriations bill. Included in the cuts was a proposed $50,000-per-member increase in staff salary accounts. Members were so sensitive about spending money on themselves that they hours Sunday sparring over whether to spend $500,000 on modular furniture and $350,000 to renovate the House beauty shop. The furniture was nixed, but the beauty shop renovation was preserved after female House members argued that its old wiring represents a safety hazard. Despite appearances, the ceilings on free mail were set high enough to avoid affecting most lawmakers. And some of the other cuts are expected to be restored in negotiations with the Senate this week or in a supplemental money bill next year, staff sources said. Left unscathed was a whopping increase in House members' salaries - from their current $96,600 to $125,100 effective Jan. 1. Under the new mail limits, each House member would be given an allowance sufficient to send three first-class mailings to each residential address in the district, an average of $178,000. Members could boost that another $25,000 by transferring money from their office accounts, and each would have to report quarterly on how much had been spent. Total mailing costs would be limited to $59 million in the year that began Oct. 1. The move was designed to prevent abuses by a few members who spend upwards of $400,000 a year on mail, including the ubiquitous newsletters designed primarily to get a lawmaker's name and picture into thousands of homes. It is those mailings that reformers point to as a primary benefit that enabled 98 percent of the incumbent House members to hold on to their job last election. Mass mailings were used as ``a public relations menu for some members of the House,'' said Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., who argued in favor of the change along with Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif. The Senate already restricts and reveals the mail costs of its members, but House leaders until recently resisted the idea. Two congressional watchdog groups, Common Cause and the National Taxpayers Union, had endorsed the restrictions on the franking privilege.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Hanged at Hayride Hanging Scene
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager posing as a hanging victim along the route of a Halloween hayride was found hanged for real, authorities said. Brian Jewell, 17, of Toms River was found dead Saturday night by the driver of the hayride. Police spokesman Lt. Howard Patterson said the death appeared to be accidental. The rope was a prop only and never should have gone around the boy's neck, said Lt. Michael Murray, spokesman for the Ocean County prosecutor's office. A group of hayriders had approached the hanging scene, but Jewell never gave them his haunting pitch, Murray said. It was then that the driver checked on the boy. The ride, featuring costumed performers, was run by Ocean Haunted Hayrides Inc., for whom, Jewell, a high school student, was working. A employee who refused to give his name said the ride's operators had no comment.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Still Edging Up, Stocks Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued edging up today from its 13-day slide against the Japanese yen, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rose above 25,000 points for the first time since Sept. 13. The dollar closed at 126.25, up 1.00 yen from Friday's close of 125.25 yen. It opened at 125.68 yen and ranged as high as 126.40 yen. The dollar had fallen 13.55 yen in 13 trading days before gaining 0.85 yen on Friday. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose for the sixth consecutive trading day, closing at 25,070.86, up 589.37 points, or 2.1 percent, from Friday's close. The index gained a total of 2,091.33 points last week. In dollar trading, traders said some market players have been expecting a correction after the U.S. currency's rapid decline. But most, they add, look for the dollar to fall later this year near its postwar low of 120.45 yen, reach on Jan. 4, 1988. ``There is a tug-of-war between the two sides,'' said Jumpei Ishii of Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Katsumi Asako, chief corporate dealer with Standard Chartered Bank in Tokyo, said, ``I don't think the dollar can climb as high as 130 yen.'' ``Over the medium term, most people are still bearish toward the dollar. But for the next one or two weeks, the market should be nervous and won't have enough momentum to push the dollar down further,'' said Masafumi Iwamoto, assistant general foreign exchange manager with Mitsui Trust and Banking. Meanwhile, ``the stock market continues to be vigorous, following last week's five-day rallying stretch,'' said a dealer at Wako Securities Co., who spoke on condition of anonymity. Reports about a possible peaceful resolution of the Middle East crisis added to the market's optimistic mood, he said. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein expressed interest in a negotiated settlement in a Japanese television interview. Peace in the Persian Gulf is expected to mean cheaper oil prices for Japan, which depends on the Middle East for about 70 percent of its oil. Japan has been plagued by inflation fears and plummeting stock prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The market now is recovering from a two-year Nikkei index low of 20,221.86 points on Oct. 1. Trading volume also has recovered. Estimated volume for the first section Monday was 600 million shares. Volume last Friday was 1.1 billion shares, the highest this year. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 84.75 points today from their close of 84.66 on Friday. Their yield dropped to 7.750 percent from 7.770 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Forest Service Workers Join Group Critical of Agency
DOC.TEXT: On the Olympic Peninsula, where logging is revered and spotted owls are hung in effigy, Jeff DeBonis preaches a message that many folks don't want to hear: the Forest Service has been raping the land for decades to feed a ``profit-hungry'' timber industry. It's a message that the founder of the Association of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics repeats often - to generally polite audiences. However, he acknowledges he has his work cut out for him in a region where the conservation vs. jobs debate tends to be stated in stark terms. ``There is a real cultural bias that has been perpetuated - the tree-hugging, environmental hippy on food stamps versus the good-ol'-boy, red neck, pickup-truck-driving logger,'' DeBonis said recently before making an appearance at the Highway 101 diner. ``If they consider me to be the enemy, then that's fine. The Forest Service has been considering the public the enemy for years,'' he said in an interview. DeBonis, of Eugene, Ore., resigned his job in February after 12 years as a timber sales manager with the Forest Service. He said most of the 1,500 Forest Service workers who have joined his group are foresters who went to college in the 1960s and 1970s ``and got a dose of ecology and social conscience.'' ``They have seen the destruction but they are not in a position of power yet to do anything about it,'' he said. AFSEEE advocates dramatic reductions in timber harvests to help protect the Northwest's dwindling supply of old-growth forests. The group contends that the Forest Service has been overcutting trees in violation of the 1976 National Forest Management Act. DeBonis said those practices have resulted in the northern spotted owl becoming a threatened species and the red cockaded woodpecker becoming endangered. DeBonis' fear of a hostile audience in Sequim proved to be largely unfounded. But one critic in the crowd of 75 did shout, ``You're wrong,'' and a local Forest Service employee charged that DeBonis' organization was ``a front for preservationists ... a special interest the same as the timber industry.'' ``It seems to me that you're saying if I am not a member, then I am not for the environment,'' said Harvey Olson, a Forest Service timber sale administrator. ``There are a lot of people in the Forest Service with guts and real concerns. You don't have a license on that,'' Olson said. Since he launched AFSEEE nearly two years ago, DeBonis said its membership has grown to include about 5 percent of the agency's workforce nationwide. More importantly, he said, an increasing number of those disgruntled workers are going public with their complaints. ``There are lots of people who are still afraid to join AFSEEE. It's a very valid fear because the Forest Service is decentralized and there are lots of old-school managers out there. It is very easy for them to make people's lives miserable,'' DeBonis said. ``But the lower echelon people are starting to say enough is enough. I know of a lot of people in the past who would just quit in disgust,'' he said. DeBonis' appearance was sponsored by the Quilcene Ancient Forest Coalition. Bob Crowley, head of the coalition and the Olympic Environmental Council, said interest in AFSEEE became visible on the peninsula among 30 to 35 Forest Service workers about a year ago ``but it was pretty clandestine.'' John Calhoun, Olympic regional manager for the state Department of Natural Resources in Forks, said the debate over timber management practices has sharply divided the Forest Service. ``The Forest Service internally is just in a shambles right now. There is a lot of difficultly with morale,'' Calhoun said. DeBonis said he is sympathetic to concerns of lost jobs as a result of reductions in logging. But he said at the current rate of cutting, the jobs will be lost in 10 years anyway, regardless of the spotted owl or other environmental issues.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Coalition Retains Power
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's governing coalition retained power in weekend elections, winning more than the two-thirds parliamentary majority it had sought, election officials said today. The National Front coalition won 127 seats in the lower house to 49 for the combined opposition. Four seats went to independents. Elections Commission officials said the final results were delayed until this afternoon because heavy rains prevented some ballot boxes from remote aborigine settlements from being airlifted when the polls closed Sunday. After singing a victory song and cutting a cake, a jubilant Mahathir said, ``We are happy that the people have returned us to power with a more than two-thirds majority. This will enable us to give a strong, peaceful and stable government.'' It was his third election victory since becoming prime minister in 1981. He claims credit for one of the fastest growing economies in Southeast Asia. But the governing coalition suffered to upsets: Defense Minister Ahmed Rithaudden was defeated in the Kelantan state district of Kota Baharu, and Stephen Young, minister for science, technology and environment, lost in Sarawak. Anything less than a two-thirds majority in Parliament would have been regarded as a setback for Mahathir. Such a margin is needed to amend the constitution and it also is a gauge of the prime minister's power. In the old Parliament, the coalition held 133 of the 177 seats. The new one was enlarged by three seats. Opposition leader Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah won re-election to his Parliament seat. He issued a statement congratulating the governing coalition on its victory. But, he added: ``I wish to remind that this victory has been achieved through abuse of power, money, the mass media, government machinery and every deceit possible.'' He did not elaborate. The campaign was largely bereft of issues, focusing instead on personalities. The opposition charged the National Front with economic mismanagement and cronyism and said it was indifferent to ethnic tensions and eroding judicial powers. Mahathir dismissed the accusations as groundless and derided the opposition's promise of tax cuts as ``the height of irresponsibility.'' Voter turnout ranged from 60 percent to 70 percent across the nation. The nation's 7.9 million voters are not required by law to cast ballots. Polling began Saturday in remote areas of Sabah and Sarawak states and in the rest of the country Sunday. Mahathir narrowly defeated Razaleigh in a 1987 contest for the leadership of the United Malays National Organization, the key party in the governing coalition. Malaysia has been ruled by a multiracial coalition led by the United Malays ever since independence in 1957. Political parties are essentially based on race. The National Front coalition also includes the Malaysian Chinese Association, Malaysian Indian Congress and seven smaller parties. Malays comprise about 53 percent of the population of 17.8 million. Chinese make up about 32 percent, with Indians and other races making up the balance. In seven earlier national elections, a fragmented opposition made little headway against the National Front, establishing only regional power bases. But this time, the electorate had an organized alternative representing the same ethnic mosaic as the National Front.

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Accord Reached
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with negotiators completing agreement on bill and action on a job-loss program, TOPS with new grafs 1-8; picks up 3rd graf pvs: Negotiators reached ....; to conforms, SUBS grafs 6-8 pvs: Congress has ....; to provide details adds new last 2 grafs: Early today ....
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators reached a tentative agreement today on a wide-ranging clean air bill that will require factories, automakers and utilities to cut pollution dramatically over the next decade. The legislation, which toughens federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years, was expected to be formally approved by a House-Senate conference, possibly later today, and then go back to the two chambers for endorsement. Congress began considering the clean air measure more than a year ago. The compromise bill retains a five-year, $250 million aid program for workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The White House had objected to financial assistance and had threatened to veto the bill if it were included. But the administration appeared to soften its opposition to the provision after language was included to keep the program from becoming too costly. White House aides when departing from the talks did not repeat their veto threat and congressional sources said they doubt President Bush would scuttle the long-sought clean air legislation on that job-loss assistance issue. Agreement on the last sections of the massive bill, which covers nearly 700 pages, came as House and Senate negotiators worked through most of night Sunday and much of the early morning today. Congressional leaders had wanted a bill by the end of the weekend to give it enough time to clear Congress before adjournment Friday. The bill's controls, aimed at cutting urban smog and ridding the air of millions of pounds of toxic chemicals, are expected to touch on almost every sector of industry and cost the economy between $22 billion and $25 billion when all its provisions go into effect. Negotiators reached agreement early Sunday on steep pollution cuts from electric power plants to reduce acid rain. Coal-burning power plants in 21 states will be directed to cut their sulfur dioxide releases almost in half, reducing annual emissions by about 10 million tons by the year 2001. The acid rain provision, which will hit utilities and consumers of electricity in the industrial Midwest the hardest, was the last major section of the bill to be resolved. Agreements had been reached previously that cut smog-causing emissions from automobiles and toxic chemical releases from factories and businesses. ``We're getting real protection. It meets the acid test on acid rain,'' said Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn., a leading proponent of acid rain curbs. The House-Senate conferees struggled since mid-July to resolve differences in separate bills approved earlier by the House and Senate. For weeks there was only modest progress, but the pace quickened in recent weeks with tentative agreements on key sections of the massive and technically complex legislation. Among the major provisions: - Utilities must reduce their annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons, or nearly in half, by installing ``scrubbers'' or switching to low-sulfur coal. They also must cut nitrogen oxides, which also contribute to acid rain. - About 100 cities now considered to have unhealthy air must meet federal air quality standards within five to 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem, by reduce smog-causing emissions. Los Angeles is given 20 years. - Industry must install new pollution control equipment to cut the release of toxic chemicals into the air by 90 percent over the next decade. Only the steel industry's coke ovens would be given more time, until 2020. Even stronger pollution control measures could be required if the Environmental Protection Agency concludes that residents near a plant are not ensured ``an amble margin of safety'' from the risk of cancer. - Pollution from automobiles must be cut 30 to 60 percent through additional controls on tailpipe emissions and the phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles in fleets. A California pilot program also would require 300,000 personal cars powered by alternative fuels by 1999. It could be copied by other states. - Oil companies must provide cleaner gasoline blends in cities with the worst smog problems. The requirement is aimed at pushing the sale of ``reformulated'' gasoline or blends that include additives such as ethanol. The measures affecting factories, thousands of small businesses, automobiles and electric rates are acknowledged to be expensive. But environmentalists argue much of the cost will be offset by savings in health care because of the cleaner air. The controls on acid rain are expected to hit hardest in the industrial Midwest where electric utilities have the dirtiest plants because of their heavy reliance on high-sulfur coal. In final bargaining, Midwest lawmakers gained some additional credits that will ease the cost of installing new pollution devices, especially over the first five years. Negotiators, however, rejected efforts by the utility industry to roll back the sulfur dioxide reductions substantially, according to congressional sources. Early today, the House and Senate negotiators also agreed to impose for the first time air pollution restrictions on offshore oil rigs, an issue pressed by California lawmakers. Rigs off the Gulf of Mexico, however, are exempt. Meanwhile, a requirement to regulate visibility in federal parks was taken out of the bill. Several western senators had threatened to block the legislation on the Senate floor if it contained the visibility provision. The compromise calls for park visibility to be studied.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan Protests Japan's Move Against Taiwan Ships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment by Taiwanese, Japanese officials, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hau Pei-tsun today protested Japan's move to block two Taiwanese ships from reaching a disputed island chain and warned of ``effective measures'' if Japan harasses Taiwanese ships in the area. ``We launch the severest protest against Japan's unfriendly harassment of our fishing boats,'' Hau said after an emergency Cabinet meeting. He also urged Japan to tear down a lighthouse built on one of the eight unpopulated islands that make up the chain in the East China Sea. They are known as the Senkaku Islands to the Japanese and the Diaoyutai Islands to Taiwan and China. Japanese coast guard patrol boats turned back two Taiwanese fishing vessels approaching the islets on Sunday. The Taiwanese boats sought to land a delegation of politicians and athletes to plant national flags on one of the islets, Uotsuri, to reinforce a claim to the territory by Taiwan's Nationalist Chinese government. In Tokyo, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said the islands are ``our country's native territory and it is regrettable that such an action was conducted'' by the Taiwan boats. ``Our government handled the matter according to related laws,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Taipei, about 30 Taiwanese pelted Japan's unofficial embassy with eggs, and demonstrators said they opposed what they called the ``revival of Japan's militarism.'' In the southern city of Kaohsiung, protesters burned a Japanese flag. Like most countries, Japan does not recognize Taiwan. It maintains close trade ties with the island nation, but has diplomatic relations with Taiwan's longtime enemy, Communist China. Uotsuri, about 2{ miles long and one mile wide, is the largest of the disputed islands. Five of the eight islets are no more than rocks. The area, however, is regarded as a rich fishing ground, and also is believed to contain oil deposits. Taiwanese fishermen have been known to shelter in the islets during storms. The islets are 270 miles southwest of Naha, capital of the Japanese island prefecture of Okinawa, and 95 miles northwest of the nearest neighboring Japanese island, Iriomotejima. They are 118 miles northesat of Taiwan. Premier Hau said the government supported Sunday's ``patriotic'' efforts. ``Japanese authorities must not deter our boats from fishing near Diaoyutai waters, or we will take effective measures to protect such fishing activities when necessary,'' Hau said. He did not elaborate. The islands were claimed by Japan in 1895. But the Nationalists, who claim to be the legitimate rulers of all of China, say the islets came under Chinese sovereignty in 1945 when Japan was defeated in World War II. In 1949, the Nationalists lost a civil war to the Chinese Communists and fled mainland China to Taiwan. The United States took over administration of the islets after the war and returned them to Japan, along with Okinawa, in 1972. The Communist government in China laid claim to the islands in 1971 and reiterated the claim last week. The latest dispute followed reports that a Japanese right-wing political group had received permission from the Japanese government to renovate a lighthouse on one of the islands. The issue has touched a raw nerve among Taiwanese who suffered much during Japan's occupation of the island from 1895 to 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in South, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the South and Midwest early today, and showers were scattered in the East. Temperatures dipped below freezing in Minnesota and Iowa. A low pressure system was expected over the Appalachians, bringing showers and thunderstorms from Louisiana to Maine. Today's forecast called for clear skies across much of the remainder of the nation, as a high pressure system extended from the just Mississippi River to the West Coast. Scattered rain was expected in Minnesota. Temperatures were expected to reach the 50s in Minnesota and the Great Lakes region; 60s in New England and the Pacific Northwest; 70s in the mid-Atlantic states and central Plains; 80s in the Deep South and Northern California and the 90s in the desert Southwest. The high for the nation Sunday was 92 degrees at Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, Four Injured in Train Wrecks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Demeagt is cq in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train struck a group of people drinking beer on the tracks, killing two people, and another person was struck dead in an unrelated train accident, authorities said. An Amtrak train enroute from Los Angeles to San Diego Sunday scattered the bodies of a man and woman about 60 yards apart. Another man was in serious condition at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, nursing supervisor Carla Dadd said. Three others were treated for minor injuries and released. ``Trespassers were playing cards and drinking on the track,'' said Arthur Lloyd, an Amtrak spokesman in San Francisco. ``The engineer probably saw them, but they can't stop in time. It's very upsetting.'' Another man was killed Sunday in Los Angeles when he was hit by a train in the San Fernando Valley area, said sheriff's Sgt. Ted Demeagt. No other details were available, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ice Cream Magnate Tom Carvel Dies at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Born Thomas...', to correct grammar.
DOC.TEXT: Tom Carvel, a drummer-turned-ice cream maker who parlayed a $15 loan during the Depression from his future wife into a fortune, has died at age 84. Carvel, who died at home Sunday of undetermined causes, was the gravel-voiced spokesman on television and radio for his Carvel Corp., the nation's third-largest ice cream store chain after Dairy Queen and Haagen-Dazs. Carvel Corp., based in Yonkers, has more than 700 stores, most of them in New York, Florida, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and other East Coast states. In 1989, Carvel sold his 99 percent share in the Carvel Corp. for more than $80 million to an investment bank, Investcorp, and stayed on as a consultant. Carvel founded the ice cream company in 1938. He began narrating his own commercials in 1955, and his pitches to ``please visit your local Carvel store'' became known to millions. His commercials promoted Fudgie the Whale and Cookie Puss ice cream cakes, Flying Saucers ice cream sandwiches and Thinny Thin dietary frozen dessert. Despite criticism of his diction and syntax, Carvel never edited for flubs and said his commercials ``are for the people who look like us, talk like us and sound like us.'' Carvel was credited with paving the way for corporate chairmen like Lee Iacocca and Victor Kiam to make their own commercials. Born Thomas Andreas Carvelas in Greece, Carvel emigrated to the United States when he was 4. His family settled in Connecticut. In the 1920s, Carvel played drums in a Dixieland band and worked as an auto mechanic before borrowing $15 from his future wife in 1934 to sell ice cream. He later opened his first ice cream store in Hartsdale, a New York City suburb. In the mid-1920s, Carvel invented the first machine to make soft ice cream. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Agnes, and a brother.

DOC.HEAD: `Bikerbank' Says He's No Hero
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts top two grafs to clarify. Picks up 3rd graf pvs ``Dozens of Israeli...
DOC.TEXT: The robber captivated the Israeli public by holding up 22 banks and making off on a motorcycle. But the suspect in custody apparently is anything but a latter-day Robin Hood. Police on Sunday identified the suspect as an heir to millions who allegedly turned to crime to pay his debts. Dozens of Israeli press and broadcast reports had chronicled his exploits, and his helmeted image adorned T-shirts and decal stickers. In news reports, he was nicknamed ``Bikerbank.'' But the man, identified by police as Roni Leibovitz, tried to fight that image in an interview with army radio today. He said he was not a hero, and had made ``a terrible mistake,'' the radio said in the interview. ``All of this attention I am getting - I am not a hero, not a folk hero or a hero of any other type,'' Leibovitz was quoted as saying. ``They are creating me as they want. I made a terrible mistake.'' He was quoted as saying the robberies were a ``result of pressure on me ... of certain family circumstances, certain environmental circumstances.'' Many Israelis were shocked to learn that Leibovitz, arrested Thursday, was the suspect. The 37-year-old man's family runs a large Israeli food products company and several businesses in New York. Leibovitz, in custody in Tel Aviv, has acknowledged taking $175,000 from banks but had no charitable goal for the loot, police said. ``When asked what his motive was, he said `money.' He said he did not want to take revenge against police or the banks; he did not want to be a national hero, but needed the money because of his debts,'' Tel Aviv police spokeswoman Dalia Gilad said Sunday. The deputy police superintendent who headed the investigation, Chaim Pinchas, said Leibovitz was as meticulous in his planning ``as an army operations officer,'' but not so in his financial affairs. He owed more than $1 million, Pinchas said. The bandit would walk into a bank wearing a crash helmet and fire one shot in the air from a .38-caliber pistol. He always robbed the teller nearest the door, then disappeared on a high-powered motorcycle. No one was ever hurt. Leibovitz had unsuccessfully tried to run family ventures in Israel, according to the Israeli media. Newspapers described his privileged life and a large villa he started to build in Herzliya Pituach, a wealthy seaside area near Tel Aviv. Leibovitz was arrested at his parents' Israeli home after he attempted to rob a bank in suburban Tel Aviv. Police said they found the motorcycle and pistol allegedly used in the robberies in the garden. Police say he had had an initial hearing and will be charged soon. He has so far accompanied police to about half of his robbery sites to show them how it was done. But even with the arrest, the myth did not die completely. As Leibovitz was taken to a Haifa bank on Friday to recreate one robbery, hundreds of Israelis gathered outside and applauded.

DOC.HEAD: Another Protest in Korean Spying Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurled firebombs today at a main office of the South Korean intelligence agency and demanded that the government stop spying on dissidents. Police said eight protesters were arrested. A number of students hurled about 20 firebombs in the predawn attack on an office in central Seoul of the Agency for National Security Planning, formerly called the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. Police said the students burned a car, scattered leaflets demanding the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo, and shouted slogans insisting that intelligence units be disbanded. About 20 intelligence and police officers, firing blanks and tear gas, immediately surrounded and arrested eight protesters trapped on an elevated road, police and news reports said. In declaring war on crime and violence last week, Roh gave police permission to open fire when necessary. It was not immediately clear whether the firebombs damaged the office. Intelligence officers declined to comment and blocked access to the building housing one of the security agency's two main offices in Seoul. Police said a firebomb exploded at an adjacent police substation, scorching a motorcycle, but no injuries were reported. Intelligence officers took the eight protesters away for questioning, they said. The students' leaflets, titled ``The Reason for Our Attack on the Agency,'' accused Roh of stepping up ``suppression of the democratic movement'' and declard war on his government. Government intelligence offices have been the target of sporadic protests by dissidents and radical students since a scandal involving a military intelligence unit spying on civilians surfaced early this month. The attack today came as Roh was urging police to end social unrest and crime. In a televised speech commemorating police day, Roh asked police officers to concentrate all their power on ending crime and civil disorders.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Higher in Light Trading, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly today against other major currencies in light trading in Europe. Gold prices fell in part because of weakening world oil prices, bullion dealers said. Foreign exchange dealers said trading was generally quiet. The first major economic indicator for the week is not due for release until Wednesday when U.S. durable goods orders for September are to be announced. A trader in Milan said ``it's becoming pretty clear'' that the seven major industrialized nations, known as the Group of Seven, have lowered their ``acceptable dollar range.'' In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1 yen to a closing 126.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a fractionally lower rate of 126.20 yen. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9490 compared with $1.9590 late Friday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe compared with late rates Friday included: -1.5080 German marks, up from 1.5040. -1.2735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2700. -5.0505 French francs, up from 5.0380. -1.6995 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6940. -1,128.00 Italian lire, up from 1,127.00. -1.1710 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1675. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $368.50 per ounce at midmorning, down from $372.75 per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, gold was bid at $369.10 an ounce, down from $372.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.22 an ounce to $371.36. Silver traded in London at a bid of $4.22 a troy ounce, down from $4.28 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Wedding On New River Bridge Far From Perfect
DOC.TEXT: Tom King and Vivian Taylor's plans for a quiet wedding atop North America's second tallest bridge were gone with the wind when a couple of thousand spectators crowded in. The Memphis, Tenn., couple were wed on Saturday during the 11th annual Bridge Day, when hundreds of parachutists bounded off the 876-foot New River Gorge Bridge to land on the banks of the New River. The wedding was not without its glitches. Some wedding guests were crowded out of the ceremony, a couple of guests were barred from jumping because organizers felt they weren't qualified for a windy-day jump, and one groomsman was cited on a trespassing charge after he landed in the wrong place. Bridge Day is the only day of the year that jumping is allowed on the New River Gorge Bridge. It's the premier event for members of the U.S. BASE Association, whose members like to jump off stationary objects like buildings, bridges and cliffs, sometimes without legal sanction. BASE stands for building, antenna, span and earth. King, a veteran BASE jumper, wanted to marry in a special roped area on the bridge before taking the plunge with two groomsmen and three wedding guests. But the crowd wouldn't let him. King, Taylor and their guests couldn't move past the center of the bridge reserved for jumping. They married instead on a wooden portable staircase, while screaming people pushed each other for a closer view. Some guests missed the wedding entirely because they were waiting elsewhere on the bridge. ``They ended up getting married in the wrong spot,'' said groomsman Mark Worthen. Worthen had problems of his own. After jumping, he landed on railroad tracks instead of the riverbank and was promptly cited for trespassing by railroad police. ``I told him `I didn't land here on purpose,' and (the officer) said, `Did someone push you off that bridge?''' Worthen said. Worthen now must return to court in Fayette County to face a trespassing charge. On Saturday, King took the plunge with another groomsman, Andy Calistrat, trailing a blue banner reading ``Just Married'' behind him. The new bride is jumping enthusiast, too - but only as a spectator. Bridge jumping was described by participants as ``high anxiety followed by total euphoria'' and ``a rush.'' Jumpers pull their parachute cords three seconds after leaping and slow to a landing in about eight seconds, after reaching speeds of 60 mph. Three parachutists suffered leg injuries and a fourth hit his head on a rock on the riverbank when his parachute snagged a tree branch, officials said. All the injuries were minor. More than 20 jumpers landed in the water and were pulled from strong currents by people in rescue boats, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 700 Attend Tearful Vigil for Jacob Wetterling
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: More than 700 people marked the first anniversary of the abduction of an 11-year-old boy with tears, music and testimonials, saying his absence ``crushes you inside.'' ``We are not giving up, no matter what,'' Sister Pauline Fernandes said Sunday before the vigil at a church less than two miles from where Jacob Wetterling was snatched by a masked gunman on Oct. 22, 1989. Fernandes, a Roman Catholic nun who has regularly volunteered time to the foundation working for Jacob's return, said the anniversary has reinforced the hopes of many who believe Jacob will be found alive. The boy's parents, Jerry and Patty Wetterling, attended Sunday's vigil but did not speak to the crowd about 700. They also were to attend a tree planting ceremony this afternoon at Centennial Park in St. Joseph to mark the anniversary. Carol Keller of St. Augusta, a frequent volunteer at the Jacob Wetterling Foundation, said supporters of the family are still working hard t keep the public aware of Jacob's abduction. The foundation continues to average about 2,000 mailings a day, she said. ``He's coming back, that's a promise,'' Mrs. Keller said. ``Jacob we miss you, we want you home,'' Ron Marotte, a director of the foundation, said Sunday night at the vigil at St. Joseph's Catholic Church. ``Can I say something to him?'' Dottie Bradford, 33, of Key Biscayne, Fla., asked minutes before the vigil. ``Everybody loves you and we hope you're home soon.'' Bradford said she hasn't been able to keep Jacob out of her thoughts since she heard of his plight on a television show. ``Just looking at (pictures of) his face it kind of takes your heart,'' she said. ``The best way to sum it up is that it crushes you inside.'' Stearns County Sheriff Charlie Grafft said a nationwide search for the boy has failed to find a trace of him. He said a new suspect was being checked out, but said people should not get their hopes up unduly. At the vigil, the congregation prayed for the boy's protection and return. ``Bless the abductor with your love and forgiveness so that Jacob may be released to his family,'' the group said in a prayer that many in the town of 1,300 have memorized. The Minnesota Gospel Twins called for people in the church to start a three-day fast and sang ``He Has Never Failed Yet.''

DOC.HEAD: CIA Defector in Moscow Says He Has Traveled in West
DOC.TEXT: The first CIA agent to defect to the Soviet Union says he has traveled widely in the West since he fled the United States five years ago, according to an interview with The Washington Post. ``I don't think any secret service can deal with multiple names, multiple passports,'' Edward Lee Howard said in an interview from Moscow published today in the Post. Howard said he has dodged Western intelligence services and customs officials while traveling in France, Canada and Mexico. He also said he has traveled widely in Nicaragua, Cuba and Eastern Europe since asking for asylum in June 1986. Howard said he did the traveling ``for fun'' and over the objection of the KGB. The Post said the interview, resulting in Howard's first published remarks since a series of meetings with author David Wise more than three years ago, was conducted over a four-hour period at Howard's dacha outside Moscow and at a restaurant in Moscow. Asked why he decided to talk, Howard said he was replying to an item in a recent news magazine report that said he had committed suicide. Howard maintained the CIA had planted the item as a ``deliberate plot to get me to surface.'' ``They hit me, I hit them,'' he said. ``Very simple. I know why they want to hit me. there have been traces of me in the West. They know I've been there.'' Howard insisted that ``I love my country - America,'' but said he is ``waging war with the CIA,'' which forced him to resign. He fled the United States after U.S. authorities accused him of spying for the Soviet Union. Howard has maintained consistently that he was not a Soviet spy. ``I'm a political refugee and defector,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Largest Cities Hit by 20 Percent Increase in Murders
DOC.TEXT: Murders in the nation's largest cities jumped 20 percent in the first half of the year, the FBI reports. The big-city murder rate contributed to an overall 10 percent in violent crime reported by the nation's police departments, the FBI said in a report released Sunday. Overall, the number of crimes reported to state and local police departments increased less than 1 percent during the first six months of the year over the same period last year, the FBI said. But the bureau's Uniform Crime Index reported that violent crimes - murder, aggravated assault, rape and robbery - went up 10 percent during the period that ended June 30. Murders increased 8 percent nationwide but in cities with populations greater than 1 million they were up 20 percent during the period, the FBI said. Murders increased 10 percent in cities with populations between 500,000 and 1 million. The jump in violent crimes was the largest since 1986, when it increased 12.1 percent over 1985. It was also twice the 5 percent increases posted during the first six months of both 1988 and 1989. By region, the Northeast led the way with an 18 percent jump in murders, followed by an 8 percent increase in the West. Murders went up 4 percent in the South and 5 percent in the Midwest. In response to the report, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, complained that ``drug dealers are battling over turf, and we are waging an anemic war to stop it.'' ``Deadly weapons are being used to slaughter innocent bystanders, and the gun lobby is blocking action to stop it,'' Biden, D-Del., said in a statement. ``We have a national bloodbath on our hands and we must get serious about stopping the killing,'' Biden said. Dan Eramian, a spokesman for Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, called the figures ``further evidence of the need to pass a crime bill that is tough on criminals.'' Rapes were up 10 percent, with the biggest increases occurring in medium-sized cities. The number of rapes reported to police in cities with populations between 100,000 and 250,000 went up 16 percent. Cities with populations between 250,000 and 500,000 reported rapes increasing by 15 percent. Robberies increased 9 percent and car thefts were up 6 percent. Burglaries declined 5 percent and thefts were down 1 percent. Suburban areas posted an 8 percent jump in violent crimes, including a 1 percent jump in murders. The increase in violent crime also reached rural areas, where it went up 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Hrawi Working to Control Beirut, Free Hostages, Disband Militias
With PM-Lebanon-Assassination, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's government is moving to accelerate the process of unifying Beirut, disbanding rival militias and freeing Western hostages, aides said today. They said plans were made during two days of talks in Damascus between Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad, who renewed a pledge to support efforts to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Hrawi returned to Beirut on Sunday night, hours after gunmen killed Christian leader Dany Chamoun, 56, his wife and two young sons at their home in suburban Baabda. Today, the Christian area staged a day-long shutdown to protest the slayings, which came a week after Hrawi's army and Syrian troops crushed the mutiny of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. The general took refuge in the French Embassy. Chamoun, the younger son of the late President Camille Chamoun, supported Aoun. Aoun's headquarters had been in Baabda. Pro-Syrian groups blamed the killings on Christian warlord Samir Geagea, whose Lebanese Forces militia fought an unsuccessful four-month war with Aoun's troops for mastery of the Christian heartland northeast of Beirut early this year. Geagea denied involvement in Chamoun's killing. He joined other Christian and Moslem leaders in urging Hrawi's government to bring peace to the area that had been controlled by Aoun's forces. Hrawi told Syrian state television his government was resolved to end the militia control of Beirut. ``All militias will be disbanded by peaceful means, but we will use other means if we face objections,'' Hrawi said. ``I warn everybody that no opposition by the gun or the cannon will be tolerated.'' Prime Minister Salim Hoss headed for Damascus today for talks with Syrian leaders on ways to end the 15-year division of Christian east Beirut and Moslem west Beirut. A Hrawi aide said that within two weeks, the government wants Geagea's men to give the Lebanese army control of the three east Beirut districts they hold. ``If the Lebanese Forces agree to a peaceful handover, then there will be no need for Syrian troops to enter east Beirut like they did with Aoun's zone. The ball is in Geagea's court,'' the aide said. He said the army also hopes to peacefully assume control of Beirut's Shiite Moslem southern slums from Hezbollah, the umbrella for pro-Iranian factions holding most of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. Hrawi's aide said the Syrian government plans to discuss the slums' fate with Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran this week. ``This (the talks) will definitely include the fate of the Western hostages, whether they still are held in the slums or smuggled out to the Bekaa Valley,'' the aide said. ``There is a Syrian-Lebanese understanding that the hostage issue should be resolved correspondingly with the creation of Greater Beirut irrespective of where the hostages are being held. Wherever they are, the Syrians control the access,'' he said. Two Lebanese army intelligence officers told The Associated Press last week that six American and two British hostages were spirited from south Beirut to east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley before the attack on Aoun's enclave Oct. 13. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate. They control more than 70 percent of Lebanon's territory, including the Bekaa Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Former Romanian Leader Criticizes End of Security Chief's Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former member of Romania's revolutionary government has bitterly criticized the suspension of the trial of the late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police chief. In a weekend telephone interview with The Associated Press, Silviu Brucan said the decision by a military court in Bucharest to suspend the trial of Gen. Iulian Vlad was an ``international scandal.'' The military court trying Vlad on charges of complicity to genocide acted Friday, citing insufficient evidence against the former head of Securitate, the Ceausescu regime's secret police. Brucan, a writer and former ambassador to the United States, had been under house arrest when Ceausescu fell last December, and became the second ranking official in the National Council of Salvation which took over the government. He later quit the council to protest its inclusion of high officials from the Ceausescu regime. ``Vlad controlled the most monstrous repression machine in Eastern Europe,'' Brucan said, adding it was ``wrong only to have tried him only on the limited charges of complicity in genocide from December 17 to December 23 of last year.'' The charge stemmed from the alleged killing of more than 1,000 Romanians by Securitate troops during the revolution that toppled Ceausescu. Vlad faced a maximum sentance of life in prison if convicted. Brucan said the story had been framed ``to avoid an examination of Securitate itself, and its criminal activity'' during the Ceausescu regime. Brucan is in the United States on a lecture tour that includes visits to Dartmouth College in New Hampshire and Tulane University in Lousianna. One of the earliest members of the Romanian Communist Party, Brucan was frequently harassed and imprisoned by the Securitate after he broke with the Ceausescu government.

DOC.HEAD: Embassy Receives `Guest' Letter
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A letter from Americans and other foreigners complaining about their detention at strategic sites in Iraq reached a Western embassy today, diplomats said. A photocopy of the handwritten letter, minus the signatures, was distributed to reporters. It referred to foreigners detained inside a gas storage terminal by Iraqi officials. They are among those being held by Iraq to try to deter attack following its invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait. The letter said: ``The camp inside the LPG (liquefied petroleum gas) storage terminal compound is in an extremely dangerous location and in the event of fire or explosion resulting from any reason whatsoever, it would be impossible for camp occupants to survive. ``Disregarding our strong protests, the persons named herein have been forced to move into this camp. ``This is contrary to international law, the Helsinki Accord on Human Rights and the promises of his excellency the president, Mr. Saddam Hussein, who has stated that the guests would be housed alongside of Iraqi residents and share the same risks as Iraqi citizens. ``We, the undersigned, continue to protest this immoral and illegal act and herewith demand that we be permitted to contact our respective embassies and inform embassy personnel of this inhuman action being taken by representatives of the Ministry of Petroleum.'' Western diplomats, speaking on condition they were not identified further, said they believed the signatories were Americans and other foreigners. The diplomats declined to say how many signatures were on the letter. There was no immediate clue to the location of the plant mentioned in the letter. When asked how the letter was received, one diplomat said it ``came along with the mail.'' But he did not say if it had actually been stamped and postmarked, or just slipped into a regular mail delivery. About 600 Americans, Britons, Germans, Japanese and other foreigners are being held at strategic sites in Iraq, according to sources. The number is believed to include about 100 Americans, they added. Diplomats said they have not been allowed to visit their citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Mayor and Top City Officials To Get 5 Percent Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins is set to announce that he's cutting his own pay and that of hundreds of top officials by 5 percent, according to a report published today. The wage cuts - 5 percent for officials earning at least $70,000 annually - would affect 44 mayoral aides, 60 commissioners, and nearly 350 deputy or assistant commissioners, the Daily News said in today's editions. The story quoted unidentified senior Dinkins administration officials. Dinkins himself would lose $6,500 from his $130,000-a-year salary. The city has been plagued by a budget shortfall caused in part by a slowdown in the city's economy. In addition to the pay cuts for top officials, Dinkins planned to freeze the pay of 3,800 municipal managers with salaries of more than $40,000, the News said. The cuts and freezes would be effective immediately and stay in effect until fiscal year 1992. The city would save $25 million from the wage freezes and $1.2 million from the pay cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Youth Stabs Israeli In Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with soldiers attacked, 18 Arabs wounded, other details and editing. No pickup.
