He officially returned to the campaign trail Oct. 16, despite metal pins keeping the bones of his left forearm in place. His other limbs were either bandaged or in a removable cast. Seale's cast and metal pins were expected to be removed soon, and he's beginning to get around on crutches, an aide said. ``The loss of my wife of course is a tragedy and something that has hit me very hard,'' Seale said. But, he said, she would have wanted him to continue the race. Shaffer, a state senator who works as the North Las Vegas building director when the Legislature isn't in session, also has questioned Seale's qualifications for the post. Seale, a managing partner of Pangborn & Co., has 20 years accounting experience and has given investment advice to clients. ``I'm sure he's made out a lot of income tax returns for people, but that doesn't make him an investment expert,'' Shaffer said. Shaffer said he would solicit advice from outside companies to recommend a investment strategy. ``Once an investment policy is in place, it is very easy to follow,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Students Support Donated Legal Services
DOC.TEXT: Law schools should require students to donate their services to people who can't afford legal representation, a group of law students said Monday. ``We find that it is really outrageous that people can go through three years of law school and never be exposed to the legal problems of someone who can't afford a lawyer,'' said Harvard law student Steve Donzinger, a member of Law Students for Pro Bono. ``We are asking our educators to say ... these problems are important enough to incorporate into our education,'' he said at a news conference here. The group wants each of the nation's 175 accredited law schools to incorporate a pro bono requirement into their traditional courses of legal study by 2000. Lawyers and other professional don't charge for pro bono services. Donzinger said fewer than one in six lawyers or law students performs any pro bono work, even though American Bar Association guidelines say its members should perform 50 hours of such work annually. As many as 1 million people could receive needed legal services if each of the nation's 129,000 law students performed 100 hours of pro bono work a year, Donzinger said. Consumer advocate Ralph Nader, who spoke on behalf of the students' efforts, said the legal profession was becoming too profit-oriented. ``It's not just the poor who are being deprived,'' he said. ``The law is a very noble institution that has been ennobled by its practitioners. The practice of law is not just for commercial gain, it's for the advancement of justice.'' Pro bono requirements have been adopted by Tulane University and Florida State University, Nader said, adding that several other law schools - including Hawaii, Harvard and UCLA - are considering such programs.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Big Spenders in Kuwait, Saddam Photos Everywhere
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Associated Press reporter Salah Nasrawi was among a group of reporters flown to Kuwait on a tour arranged by the Iraqi Information Ministry. ---=

With their pockets full of Iraqi dinars, hundreds of Iraqi visitors have descended on Kuwait, buying everything they can. A group of Baghdad-based journalists went to Kuwait over the weekend on a trip arranged by the government to discredit Western media reports that Iraqi soldiers were plundering the occupied emirate. During the visit, it appeared that Kuwait, a thriving business center before the Aug. 2 invasion, is slowly but steadily becoming more and more Iraqi. Saddam's photographs are everywhere, just as in Iraq. More and more vehicles are displaying Iraqi license plates, and there are no signs of Kuwaiti armed resistance. ``I feel here like at home,'' said Kamal Abbas, a visiting Iraqi businessman. ``There are no visas, no border checkpoints and no need for re-export license. ``I buy anything and everything,'' he said, referring to the supply of consumer goods that surpasses what he can find at home. Bashar Mubarak, a Kuwaiti businessman selling household goods in the city's Nigras district, was asked what he thought about the presence of his Iraqi counterpart. ``Who cares,'' he replied. ``Money is not an important thing right now.'' Iraqi officials strongly deny reports that there may be a chance for a compromise solution of the Persian Gulf crisis. They say they will never give back any of Kuwait. ``After decades, Kuwait has become what it should be - part of Iraq,'' said Shihab Ahmed al-Jassim, the new head of Kuwait's education department. Out of 500 schools, at least 108 are open, said al-Jassim, who formerly was head of education in Basra, Iraq's second-largest city. All the schools have photos of Saddam. The names of schools that bore the names of family members of Kuwait's exiled rulers - the al-Sabah family - are being changed, said al-Jassim. ``However, some Kuwaiti students are not attending school,'' he said, explaining many Kuwaitis were out of the country when Iraq ``freed'' Kuwait. The schools are guarded by volunteers of Iraq's Popular Army, which also guards all government buildings and nine checkpoints in downtown Kuwait. During their 36-hour stay, the reporters did not hear any gunshots. The Iraqi government imposes a curfew daily from 11 p.m. to 7 a.m., turning the once busy city into a ghost town. And even 12 weeks after the invasion, people are still fleeing Kuwait - some because they lost their jobs or business, others because they are unsure about the future. Immigrant workers are waiting to leave, but uncertain what will happen to them. ``I have never been out of Kuwait since I came here. I do not know where to go,'' said Mariana Niaeshai, a housekeeper at a hospital who came here six years ago from the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Second Jogger Trial Opens; Defendant's Outburst Disrupts Proceedings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with mistrial denied; proceedings resume. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In her...'.
DOC.TEXT: The trial of two teen-agers charged with the brutal rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park was disrupted just after it opened today when a defendant broke down and screamed. ``No! No! No! I can't deal with this!'' cried defendant Kharey Wise as four court officers ushered him out of the courtroom. ``I can't take this! It isn't true!'' His outburst, which led to an unsuccessful defense request for a mistrial, came just after Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer completed her opening statement. The trial is the second stemming from last year's highly publicized atttack. Lederer said Wise, 18, and his co-defendant, Kevin Richardson, 16, would convict themselves through the statements they gave police, statments the defense argues were obtained improperly. As Lederer was winding up her remarks, Wise talked to himself, rocked in his seat and held his hands to his face as if he was praying. He bit his lip and pounded his forehead with his fist. After she finished, the judge announced a brief break for the jury before the defense's opening remarks. As the jury was filing out, he began crying and yelling. He also vomited. Howard Diller, attorney for Richardson, asked the judge for a mistrial because of the other defendant's outburst. But as the trial resumed after a break, the judge denied the mistrial motion and warned Wise to behave. Opening arguments for the defense then proceeded. In her statement, Lederer told jurors that Wise and Richardson were among 30 youths who went into Central Park the night of April 19, 1989, ``to beat, to rob, to assault, to attack anyone they found in the park.'' Defense lawyers claim incriminating statements made by Wise and Richardson were coerced from mentally deficient boys. But Lederer said statements from the two youths were ``freely and voluntarily made,'' and are corroborated by other evidence in the case. The two are among six teens charged with the attack on the jogger. The first trial ended in five-to-10-year sentences - the maximum for juvenile offenders - for Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana and Antron McCray, all 16. They were convicted of rape, assault, robbery and riot, but acquitted of attempted murder and sodomy. Wise, 16 at the time of the attacks, faces adult penalties that could total up to 57 years in prison if he is convicted on all counts. Richardson, 14 when he was arrested, faces the same five to 10 years as the three youths convicted in the first trial. Lederer told the jury that the defendants' guilt will be proved by the testimony of bicyclists, joggers, police officers, medical and scientific experts and by the defendants' own written and videotaped statements. She said Richardson, in his videotaped statement, described how he and the other teen-agers hid in the dark, behind trees, and attacked the jogger when she ran past. She said Richardson describes how they ripped her shirt off, how she screamed for help and how she scratched Richardson's face. Lederer said Wise made two videotaped statements because he admittedly lied to police in the first one. She said he acknowledged he had gone into the park with a group ``to do violence.'' In the second tape, he describes how he held her leg and fondled it while others raped her. Defense attorney Colin Moore was rebuffed Friday when he asked Justice Thomas Galligan to allow expert testimony that Wise is not smart enough to have knowingly and meaningfully waived his Miranda rights against self-incrimination. Moore said Wise has an intelligence quotient of 73. Diller has said Richardson likewise is not intelligent enough to have said the things police attributed to him in his statement.

DOC.HEAD: Jail Time Makes A Hero Of Bhutto's Husband
DOC.TEXT: Before the doors of the jail slammed shut behind him, Asif Ali Zardari was best known as the playboy husband of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. But when Zardari was arrested and jailed Oct. 10 on charges of kidnapping and extortion, he became a celebrity in his own right. In arresting the 38-year-old businessman, authorities accused Zardari of kidnapping a Pakistani-born British citizen in April and extorting $800,000 from him. Zardari vehemently denied the charges, saying they were fabricated by an army-backed caretaker government bent on destroying his wife's political career and her populist Pakistan People's Party. This week, Zardari could well be elected to Parliament. Even Ms. Bhutto's critics say her husband's popularity has grown since the arrest. ``From the darkness of my cell, the light of democracy burns bright,'' Zardari wrote in a plea for justice published in Urdu-language newspapers. ``When I was arrested I felt proud. I joined the people who broke the chains of oppression and fought for stability, human rights and democracy,'' he wrote. Zardari is expected to remain in custody at least until Tuesday, the eve of Pakistan's parliamentary elections. He still is a candidate for two seats in Wednesday's elections, in the districts of Lyari and Nawabshah, his home town. The elections were called after Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government was sacked Aug. 6 on charges of rampant corruption, nepotism and abuse of power. While her husband sat in jail, Ms. Bhutto led a mile-long procession of brightly-colored trucks festooned with banners through her husband's home constituency in southern Sindh Province. Ms. Bhutto pleaded her husband's case in an emotional speech to tens of thousands of party loyalists who waited nearly 12 hours in scorching desert heat for her. An employee of acting Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, a Bhutto rival, said Zardari's popularity has grown since the arrest. ``That (the arrest) was the government's decision and it was a mistake,'' said the employee on condition of anonymity. ``The arrest has become his badge of honor,'' said a foreign diplomat, also insisting on anonymity. Lyari, a sprawling slum district in the provincial capital of Karachi, was considered a good bet for Zardari before he was jailed. Now it's believed to be a sure thing, even by political opponents. Zardari was a favorite target of Ms. Bhutto's opponents during her 20 months in power. They called him ``Mr. 10 Percent,'' a reference to commissions he allegedly charged for lucrative government contracts. ``Everybody believes he was the root cause of her downfall. But if her hands were clean how could he get away with so much?'' asked Jatoi during a campaign stop in his home constituency of New Jatoi, a village neighboring Zardari's hometown of Nawabshah. But most Pakistanis now dismiss the the corruption issue as irrelevant - a failed attempt by the caretaker Cabinet to portray Ms. Bhutto's government as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history. In the sun-baked streets of Nawabshah, a squalid village of dried-mud huts surrounded by imposing 10-foot walls, people talk about the election. Most people shrug off the charges. ``We've read about it, but we don't know. His family lives in the same house in Nawabshah. We haven't seen any change. We don't know,'' said a local resident, who refused to give his name. The fight in Nawabshah is expected to be tough and violent. ``People are keeping their vote in their heart,'' said a street vendor who declined to give his name for fear of reprisal. Zardari is pitted against Jatoi's son, Murtaza, and most people say the acting prime minister has pulled out all the stops for his son. Mohammad Hashim, a local laborer, said several people had been arrested in Nawabshah since Jatoi was appointed Ms. Bhutto's successor, all of them workers for her Pakistan People's Party. While Zardari's family is native to Nawabshah, most residents say their loyalty lies with his wife and her deposed father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown in a 1977 coup and hanged two years later. Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is considered Pakistan's first populist leader. Even his detractors say he dismantled the centuries-old barriers between Pakistan's wealthy and and poor. ``In the past the poor person couldn't talk to a rich person, but now he can grab anyone by the throat and make them listen. The PPP has given us this courage,'' said another Nawabshah voter, who refused to be identified. ``Bhutto did a lot for us and we'll vote for him, not Asif (Zardari).''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Agrees to Free Some Americans; Sailors Board Iraqi Ship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Pentagon saying the Iraqi freighter was found to be empty, oil prices falling $5.65 a barrel in London. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has agreed to release some sick and elderly American captives, the leader of the Iraqi-American Foundation said today. The Iraqi leader also asked his parliament to consider letting all French hostages leave. American and Australian sailors, meanwhile, halted and boarded an Iraqi freighter in the Gulf of Oman that over the weekend had ignored warning shots and defied orders to return to Iraq, a U.S. military spokesman said. The 5,200-ton Iraqi vessel was stopped as it sailed toward the Arabian Sea. It had been shadowed during the night by U.S. and Italian warships, sai Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle, a Navy spokesman. The operation went smoothly with ``no shots fired, no resistance met,'' Van Sickle said. He said ``the crew of the Iraqi ship is cooperating.'' The Pentagon later said the Iraqi vessel was allowed to proceed on its way after it was found to be empty. The Pentagon said in a statement that the ship had probably dumped overboard the cargo of steel pipes and plywood that it was carrying to Yemen in violation of the U.N. embargo. The head of the Iraqi-American Foundation, Salim Mansour, leads a delegation that met with Saddam on Sunday night. He said today that he received a commitment from the Iraqi leader to release Americans. ``We don't want to talk about figures or names at the moment, but I'm happy to announce that some good news will come up,'' Mansour said. It was presumed Mansour spoke about Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait, which Saddam annexed after his Aug. 2 invasion of the emirate. Saddam considers Kuwait Iraq's 19th province. About 700 Americans are being held in Kuwait, and more than 300 in Iraq, many at strategic sites to deter a possible attack by the multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. Western diplomatic sources said on condition of anonymity they had no independent confirmation of Mansour's claims, but added: ``We understand that what Masnour is saying could turn out to be true.'' They said they understood that the Americans released would by ``sick or elderly.'' Also today, oil prices in New York were down $4.19 to $29.60 a barrel as of 1:05 p.m. (EDT). In London, North Sea Brent Blend oil fell $5.65 to $26.75. Since the Persian Gulf crisis began, oil prices have fluctuated wildly on world markets, reaching above $40 a barrel at times, compared with pre-crisis levels of $22. Oil prices fell today on reports that Saudi Arabia's defense minister, Prince Sultan, suggested Arab countries were willing to grant Iraq ``all its rights.'' The market interpreted this as a sign Saudi Arabia was prepared to agree to Kuwait ceding some land to Iraq. Saddam, in a letter to the Iraqi parliament, said that legislators should discuss freeing French nationals held in Iraq and Kuwait. He said such a move would be a sign of Iraq's friendship with France. There are more than 300 French citizens in Iraq and Kuwait. French leaders have favored linking a solution to the gulf crisis with negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians over the Israeli-occupied territories. Saddam has tried to make the same linkage, and in a Japanese television interview broadcast today, said the proposal deserved consideration. Saddam's request, reported by the official Iraqi News Agency, did not say when the parliamentary discussion should take place. To enforce the U.N. trade embargo on Iraq, a multinational naval force has been patrolling the gulf. It has searched numerous commercial ships, and in a dozen cases warships have fired warning shots to halt suspected transgressors. The latest incident began Saturday, when U.S. Navy and Coast Guard inspectors boarded the Iraqi freighter Al-Bahar al-Arabi in the Persian Gulf. The ship agreed to turn back to Iraq because its cargo of plywood and steel pipes was prohibited under the sanctions, Navy sources said. But the freighter continued to sail southward, despite the fact that the O'Brien early Sunday fired three separate volleys of warning shots from its deck and machine guns in an attempt to again halt the vessel, the sources said. The O'Brien and the Italian frigate Libeccio shadowed the vessel overnight. The boarding team today included 15 men from the Australian missile frigate HMAS Aeelaide and 11 from the American frigate USS Reasoner, Van Sickle said. The ship had been sailing southward toward the port of Aden in Yemen, where there are strong sympathies for Saddam and his struggle with the West. The Pentagon statement was issued on behalf of U.S. Central Command, which is in charge of Operation Desert Shield. It said the Iraqi vessel was found to be no longer carrying prohibited material and was allowed to proceed to her original destination. Asked what had happened to the ship's cargo, the U.S. Central Command said: ``We...can only assume it was dumped over the side by the crew of the al-Bahar al-Arabi sometime between her first boarding and today.'' The Iraqi News Agency said the ship was leased by a private fishing company and carrying fish from ``the Indian Ocean and African ports.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall Below $30 A Barrel in London, NY
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with prices still lower. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The market...'. Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices plummeted more than $4 a barrel in heavy trading today on optimism about a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Prices tumbled below $30 a barrel in New York - and even more, to below $27, in London. The markets appeared to be reacting to comments by Saudi Arabia's defense minister, Prince Sultan, who suggested that Arab countries were willing to grant Iraq ``all its rights.'' ``The statement has really gotten the markets unsettled,'' said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.F. & Man International Inc. ``There is some expectation that maybe an Arab-proposed solution ... is in the cards.'' By early afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for November delivery of light, sweet crude was off $4.19 at $29.60 a barrel. The decline comes on the heels of losses Friday, when the November contract settled down $3.01 a barrel on the Mercantile Exchange. In London, North Sea Brent Blend crude oil for December delivery closed at $26.75 a barrel, down $5.65 from $32.40 late Friday. Prices of refined products also fell sharply in New York. The contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline for November delivery, which lost more than 5 cents on Friday, was trading at 77 cents a gallon on the Mercantile Exchange by early afternoon, down a steep 10.91 cents. Home heating oil was down about 13 cents a gallon at 75.40 cents after the near-term contract lost 8.11 cents on Friday. The market interpreted the Saudi official's comments as a sign Saudi Arabia was prepared to agree to Kuwait ceding some land to Iraq. Traders pushed prices lower on the belief that this development might lead to a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Activity in London was fairly light as many traders stayed on the sidelines waiting out the decline. ``We're just watching the prices go down,'' said a trader at a major international trading house in London. But dealings in New York were hectic. ``It's extremely busy,'' one trader said. ``Prices opened lower, and then there was more liquidation.'' Since the Persian Gulf crisis began, oil prices have fluctuated wildly on world markets, reaching above $40 a barrel at times, compared with pre-crisis levels of $22 a barrel. North Sea Brent is a key European barometer of oil prices. In the United States, the price of a gallon of gasoline rose 2{ cents in the past two weeks, reaching a national average of $1.47, according to a survey released Sunday. The biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gas stations indicated prices have risen more than 40 cents a gallon since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Backs Genetic Parents In Surrogate Mother Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to move up that child was `test-tube baby;' add detail from ruling, reaction, restore dropped courtesy title in 5th graf, `The Calverts. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Genetic parents who paid a surrogate mother to bear their test-tube baby should raise the boy despite the surrogate's claim that she wants the child after all, a judge ruled today. Mark Calvert gently kissed his wife, Crispina, as Orange County Superior Court Judge Richard Parslow rejected 29-year-old surrogate mother Anna Johnson's claim seeking partial custody of the baby boy. ``I believe he should be raised exclusively by the Calverts,'' Parslow said. The baby, whom the Calverts call Christopher, is now 4 weeks old. The judge said that a ``three-parent, two-natural-mom situation'' would be confusing to the child and ``invites emotional and financial extortion.'' The Calverts, of Tustin, had agreed to pay Ms. Johnson $10,000 to bear their child, which was conceived through in vitro fertilization using sperm and egg donated by the Calverts. Mrs. Calvert can't carry a baby because she had a hysterectomy. Ms. Johnson wasn't in court for the ruling, but she had said earlier that she would appeal an unfavorable decision. In the six-day hearing, her attorneys tried to show she and the baby had developed an unexpected but deep emotional attachment during the pregnancy that must not be severed. The Calverts had insisted that they should be recognized as the sole parents. Parslow earlier granted the Calverts temporary custody of the baby. Attorneys have said the Calvert-Johnson dispute could break new legal ground because a genetically unrelated surrogate never has sought custody. The famous Baby M case in New Jersey involved a surrogate mother who was also the baby's genetic mother. Referring to the Calverts and the baby, the judge said, ``In this case we have a family unit, all genetically related.'' He said the argument by Ms. Johnson's lawyer that the baby has three natural parents ``is really not in the best interest of the child. ... I think the decision I'm making in this case is definitely pro child.'' Of Ms. Johnson, the judge said the Calverts ``entrusted her with carrying their child.'' The judge said Ms. Johnson appears to be articulate and intelligent, so ``I don't think the Calverts conned Anna into this agreement.'' Ms. Johnson claimed that the Calverts neglected her during the pregnancy and were late making payments. The Calverts offered evidence about the importance of the genetic link. They also attempted to cast doubt on Ms. Johnson's motives, claiming she was motivated by a thirst for publicity and money, not love of the child. ``The only bonding Anna Johnson has is with your television camera,'' Calvert told reporters after the ruling. Ms. Johnson, a single mother of a 3-year-old girl, and Mrs. Calvert, 36, met while working as nurses at a Santa Ana hospital.

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Rogers, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0591,0703
DOC.HEAD: Actress Sees Women Gaining Ground in Hollywood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Upcoming movies...', to CORRECT spelling of Pfeiffer. ^LaserPhoto LA1 sent Oct. 18.
DOC.TEXT: Mimi Rogers sees a gleam of hope that women may one day achieve equal status in today's macho movie world. ``It's an unfortunate fact that there are many more roles for men than there are for women. A favorable sign is the success of films like `Pretty Woman' and `Ghosts' - much more successful than big, male-dominated action films,'' she said. ``With these two films, in which women are on more of an equal level, being so successful, maybe the trend will start to shift in the direction of having men and women really co-starring.'' Upcoming movies seem promising: Cher and Winona Ryder co-star in Orion's ``Mermaids,'' a sweet relationship movie; Michelle Pfeiffer co-stars with Sean Connery in ``The Russia House,'' based on the John le Carre thriller; Julia Roberts stars in next spring's ``Sleeping With the Enemy''; and Academy Award-winner Jody Foster is eagerly awaited as the star of ``Silence of the Lambs,'' a taut thriller based on the best seller by Thomas Harris. If not equal, Rogers has a vital role in ``Desperate Hours,'' with Mickey Rourke and Anthony Hopkins. It's Dino De Laurentiis' update of the 1955 movie, with Rogers in the part originated by Martha Scott. Rourke plays the Humphrey Bogart role of a criminal psycho who takes a suburban family hostage. Hopkins has the part of the husband, originally played by Fredric March. The director of the MGM release is Michael Cimino. Yes, the same Michael Cimino who won an Academy Award for ``The Deer Hunter'' in 1978, and made the financial bomb ``Heaven's Gate'' in 1980. Rogers remarked that during the ``Desperate Hours'' filming Cimino ``was very relaxed, very much at ease and enjoying the whole process. There was an awareness on his part that he wanted to bring it in on time and on budget. I think we actually finished a week early and under budget. ``He knows that he knows how to make movies. There's no question the guy has made some brilliant movies. It's more a matter of reaffirming that he can do it, that he can follow a schedule and a budget, that it's no problem and boom - there's the movie. That's what he did.'' Rogers has three new films: ``Desperate Hours''; ``The Doors,'' Oliver Stone's biography of rocker Jim Morrison; and ``The Rapture,'' an apocalyptic drama. Last January, she and Tom Cruise ended their three-year marriage, during which she seemed to be subordinating her own career as his zoomed skyward. She corrected that impression: ``I actually worked quite a bit. Unfortunately, two of the films that I did haven't been released in this country. ``I did a picture for Vestron called `Hider in the House' (with Gary Busey) that got caught up in the company's bankruptcy. Then I did a film with James Belushi called `To Forget Palermo.' We spent 14 weeks shooting that. It was an Italian-financed film - an English (language) film with an Italian director. That's always a bit of an experiment,'' she said. ``I don't know what happened to it. Maybe American distributors looked at it and thought it wasn't going to make money. Both of those films, I think, have been released internationally but not here. So there's an apparent void that didn't really exist.'' Like her former husband, Mimi (short for Miriam) Rogers had a traveling childhood. Both their fathers were engineers who took jobs all over. Rogers was born in Coral Gables, Fla., but she moved to Virginia, Arizona, Michigan, England and finally Los Angeles. A good student, she graduated from high school at 14, and started acting in her 20s. Her first film was ``Blue Skies Again'' with Harry Hamlin. Her other co-stars include Michael Keaton (``Gung Ho''), Christopher Reeve (``Street Smart''), Tom Berenger (``Someone to Watch Over Me'') and Denzel Washington (``The Mighty Quinn''). She usually plays ``the love interest.'' But she hopes that will change as movies take a feminine tilt.

DOC.HEAD: West Bank Mourns Demise of `Living Martyr'
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: He was known to Palestinians as the ``living martyr,'' a youth who clung to life for more than two years with a bullet wound suffered in a clash with Israeli troops. Mohammed Naim Abu Akar lost his long battle Monday, succumbing to liver and respiratory failure, doctors at Jerusalem's Mukassed Hospital said. Abu Akar, 18, had survived on intravenous feedings because his intestines were all but destroyed by the bullet that hit him in a clash in the Dheishe refugee camp near Bethlehem on Aug. 6, 1988. An attempt at reconstructive surgery in Boston failed. Palestinians have been rebelling against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip since December 1987, and more than 3,000 of them gathered for Abu Akar's funeral Monday in the village of Irtas, south of Bethlehem. Mourners marched with scores of outlawed Palestinian flags and heaped dozens of floral wreaths upon his coffin. In Bethlehem, shops, offices and schools closed in mourning. Activists used loudspeakers to exhort the crowd: ``Anyone who wants to mourn Mohammed should go out and attack the Zionists!'' The army did not intervene. Earlier, when Abu Akar's death became known, the news sparked stone-throwing. The army imposed a curfew on the Dheishe camp's 7,000 residents to restore order. Dr. Khaled Abu Iqraiah, who treated Abu Akar over the past two years at Mukassed, said the youth would long be remembered. ``In the occupied territories, he stood as a symbol for the victims of the uprising,'' Abu Iqraiah said. ``He was a dear example for many Palestinians because he fought to survive for a long time.'' Abu Akar was wounded in August 1988 in a stone-throwing clash with soldiers. It was one of dozens of confrontations he joined as an activist with the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, friends said. The bullet tore into his abdomen, damaging both the large and small intestines, Iqraiah said. He said friends and Palestinian human rights groups raised funds to help pay for sending Abu Akar to Boston's New England Deaconess Hospital in November and December 1988 for experimental surgery. When it failed, Abu Akar was brought back to Dheishe and kept alive on intravenous feeding. He began to fail two days ago and was moved to Mukassed, where he died in the intensive care unit, the doctor said. Palestinians call those killed by the Israelis ``shuhadaa,'' or martyrs, and they now count Abu Akar as the 762nd such victim since the Palestinian uprising began. ``With our souls, with our blood we will avenge your death,'' they chanted at his funeral.

DOC.HEAD: Chefs and Nutritionists Unite To Concoct Healthy, Delicious Foods
DOC.TEXT: A group of nutritionists and chefs have joined together to forge a ``new era'' of eating, to show people there are ways to eat healthily and still enjoy good food. ``Welcome to the meeting of two formerly warring groups, the taste community and the science community,'' chef Julia Child said when the group met this weekend. Cholesterol warnings, mixed messages on caffeine, scares over chemicals and the all-encompassing bad word ``fat'' have left many fretting over what they eat. The conference, sponsored by the National Dairy Board and the American Institute of Wine and Food, attempted to allay people's fears and guilt about eating patterns. ``Fat is not a four-letter word,'' said Jan Weimer, a food consultant and conference organizer. ``It has its place.'' Dr. Carl Orringer, director of preventive cardiology at the University of Michigan Medical Center, applauded the group's efforts, but said that ultimately people need to recognize some food is not good for them. The conference sponsors ``would obviously like to avoid eliminating foods that they sponsor,'' he said. ``In reality, what they're admitting is if it's better to eat less than more, then maybe it's better to eat even less, to the point where maybe it's better not to eat those foods at all.'' Child noted that chefs traditionally have viewed dieticians and nutritionists as ``the wicked stepmother,'' and the medical community has been dubious about chefs. After months of negotiations and cooking, the group agreed on some general statements embracing the importance of tasty, healthy meals. Dr. C. Wayne Callaway said people should focus on what they eat over longer periods, and regular, moderate exercise. ``We're teaching people how to eat, rather than what not to eat,'' he said. The group plans to lobby fellow nutritionists and chefs and then take their ideas to the public. Callaway believes peer pressure and changing market demands will make restaurateurs, store owners and even fast food chains change their ways.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Study Finds Cocaine Prompts Growth of AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine speeded the growth of the AIDS virus in laboratory tests, prompting concern that it could increase infected people's chances of developing the deadly disease, researchers reported Monday. Microbiologists at the University of Minnesota Medical School exposed cells that are the primary target for the AIDS virus to doses of cocaine. The virus, HIV, was found to grow as much as three times faster in the cocaine-laced tests than in control studies. If what happened in the test tube happens in HIV-infected cocaine users, it could increase their risk of developing AIDS, said Dr. Ronald Schut, the lead researcher. ``In persons who are infected, if they continue to abuse this drug it may have a significant impact on the development of clinical AIDS,'' Schut said. While about 150,000 AIDS cases have been reported in the United States, researchers say a million or more other Americans are infected and at risk of developing AIDS. Test-tube tests, however, don't always mimic what happens in the human body. The question now for researchers is whether drug use somehow modifies the immune system to enhance HIV growth in humans. ``The initial in-vitro (test-tube) studies suggest that it's possible,'' Schut said. Schut presented the findings at the Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, sponsored by the American Society for Microbiology. Further studies are under way using immune cells from drug users in a methadone program, where cocaine use is high, ``to see if the virus grows easier,'' Schut said. Dr. James Curran, director of the Division of HIV-AIDS at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, said little if any solid information is available concerning the AIDS risk of cocaine users. He added that drug users are notoriously difficult to study and many cocaine users are involved in injectable drug abuse, which can spread HIV by dirty needles. Nearly one-fourth of the AIDS cases reported in this country stem from intravenous drug use, according to the CDC. Curran said that while the Minnesota test results may be correct, of greater concern is the practice of trading cocaine for sex, leading to the spread of the AIDS virus by sexual contact. Still, as far as cocaine is concerned, Curran said, ``I think it's safe to recommend don't do it.'' Also at the microbiology conference Monday: - Curran predicted that homosexual men will still make up ``a large proportion'' of AIDS cases five years from now, despite the increase in AIDS among intravenous drug users and their sex partners. Half of last year's AIDS cases in the United States involved gay men, he said. - Dr. Douglas Richman, an AIDS specialist at the University of California, San Diego, predicted that even without an AIDS vaccine, combination drug treatments will enable infected people to live ``normal'' lives and approach normal lifespans. ``A patient with HIV will be treated similarly to a patient with diabetes or hypertension - prevent the progression of disease and maintain the quality of life,'' Richman said. Complications from high blood pressure and diabetes can be controlled and reduced with drug treatment, and so will various complications of HIV infection, he said. - Development of an AIDS vaccine is ``a concept that is achievable,'' said Dr. Lawrence Corey, an AIDS specialist at the University of Washington in Seattle. But ``cocktail'' vaccines, combating various HIV strains, aren't at the human trial stage yet, and the protection offered by some vaccines tested in animals has tended so far to be quite short in duration, he said. Because of the risk involved in testing a whole-virus AIDS vaccine, it's more likely that researchers will aim for development of a ``sub-unit'' vaccine, utilizing only pieces of the AIDS virus, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Students Say They Were Racially Harassed at University
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Language in 3rd graf may be offensive.
DOC.TEXT: Japanese students at Teikyo Loretto Heights University say they have been racially harassed. Twelve students reported some types of harassment, from racial taunting to egg-throwing and people urinating in front of them. Two incidents involved beatings and robberies of students. Earlier this year, a fake bomb was sent to the school with a note reading, ``Japs go home,'' authorities said. The university was formed as a cooperative effort between Regis College and Teikyo University in Tokyo. About 350 students, all Japanese, began classes last April. The school is limited to Japanese students, but hopes to expand to include U.S. students next year. Despite recent incidents near the campus, many students say they are not afraid because no one has been seriously injured. ``These incidents made students wake up to the fact that they are living in the United States,'' said Takanori Matsui, 22. ``Students sometimes think they are living in Japan, which is a very, very secure place.''

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Criticize Delay in Senate Ethics Committee Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 3, Heflin defended, and 10-12, Heflin said, with Heflin reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Republicans sharply criticized the Senate Ethics Committee today for delaying a crucial ruling in the cases of five senators who assisted former savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. The Republicans demanded that the committee, headed by Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., act before adjournment this week on a special counsel's recommendation that two senators be dropped from the probe and three others remain subjets of an intensified inquiry. Heflin defended the timetable, citing work conflicts by senators. The criticism was led by Sen. John McCain of Arizona, the only Republican among the five senators under investigation. McCain said the committee's ranking Republican, Warren Rudman, R-N.H., had tried unsuccessfully to move the investigation along. ``There's far more at stake than my reputation. There's the reputation of the United States Senate,'' McCain said. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. joined the criticism as did Sens. Slade Gorton, R-Wash. and John Danforth, R-Mo. The senators noted that Congress is less than a week from adjournment, and six weeks have passed since committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett recommended that McCain and Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, be dropped from the probe. Bennett proposed continuing the investigation against Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. Heflin said in a floor speech that there had been ``an organized campaign of leaks'' that harmed three of the Democrats under investigation. Documents before the committee, obtained by The Associated Press and others, have shown that Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle had closer relationships with Keating than they have publicly acknowledged. ``It is interesting to note that the leak of documents has been confined to three senators and that there has been no leak of documents about the other two senators,'' Heflin said in a floor speech. Heflin added that in addition to Bennett's recommendations, the committee should study an Oct. 1 statement by Common Cause, urging that no senator be dropped from the probe at this time. He added that the committee would meet Tuesday. Dole said there are rumors the committee doesn't want to make a decision because of politics. ``It seems the failure to act would lead to the same conclusion. It's not a partisan committee. Judgments never have been considered in a partisan way on the Senate floor. We want to keep it that way. Two of our colleagues have sort of been hung up to dry,'' he said. The five senators intervened for Keating with banking regulators and also received $1.3 million in political contributions from the businessman and his associates. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan was seized by the government in April 1989. It may cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses. Common Cause, the congressional watchdog group, requested the investigation a year ago, and the preliminary probe began last December.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto: A Last Day Of Campaigning For Vindication At The Polls
With AM-Pakistan-Bhutto's Husband, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Monday ended her campaign for vindication in the polling booths with a procession through Lahore, traditionally her opponents' territory. Hundreds of riot police carrying semi-automatic weapons and steel-cased batons lined the streets. Officials divided the city into separate areas for cavalcades by Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party and those of her opponent, Nawaz Sharif's Islamic Democratic Alliance. Nearly 50,000 soldiers were deployed nationwide because of fears of violence between Bhutto's and Sharif's supporters. In Lahore, the parade by the Islamic Democratric Alliance strayed only briefly into territory earmarked for the Pakistan People's Party, and no violence was reported. By law, campaigning stopped at midnight Monday for the parliamentary elections Wednesday. The elections were called after Ms. Bhutto's government was dismissed three years early Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and nepotism. The elections pit the center-left Pakistan People's Party against the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a coalition united by supporters' contempt for Ms. Bhutto. The two groups, along with 30 other smaller parties and independents, are vying for 217 seats in the National Asembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minister. Ms. Bhutto, whose father Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was deposed as prime minister in 1977 and hanged two years later, has regularly warned of likely vote-rigging by the caretaker government and the president. The former prime minister's opponents have tried to portray her as one of Pakistan's most corrupt and inept leaders. The 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto is being tried on six charges of corruption and abuse of power before the special courts in Lahore and her hometown, Karachi. She could be banned from politics for seven years if convicted on any of the charges. Ms. Bhutto spent almost a decade in prison, under house arrest or in exile after the overthrow and execution of her father. She became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation in November 1988 in Pakistan's first free elections that ended 11 years of military rule for the nation of 110 million people. Her 20 months in office were marked by confrontation that paralayzed Parliament and alienated the army. Allegations of corruption, which she denies, ultimately brought about her downfall.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal, Mayor Join 2,000 at Funeral for Slain Girl
DOC.TEXT: Two thousand people packed a small Bronx church and lined the streets around it Monday to mourn the death of a 10-year-old girl whose slaying has compounded the grief of a crime-weary city. ``Those of us gathered here are the city weeping, the city in tears,'' said Cardinal John J. O'Connor, who officiated at the funeral Mass for Jessica Guzman. ``We are related by pain, by suffering, by this common language of sorrow, the anguish we all feel, every one of us.'' Mayor David Dinkins and other city officials attended. Jessica, who would have turned 11 on Saturday, disappeared from her home on Oct. 10. Her body was found Wednesday about five miles away. The city medical examiner said she was killed by ``homicidal asphyxiation,'' but the exact method could not be determined because her body had begun decomposing. Police said there were no wounds on her body. Police have reported no developments toward solving the killing, one of many high-profile crimes that have plagued New York City this year. Detectives have reopened the 5-month-old case of a 21-year-old woman because of similarities to Jessica's death. Detectives also are considering a possible link between Jessica's death and that of two other Bronx children killed last year. Hundreds of people squeezed onto the sidewalk across from St. John Vianney Church while the Mass was held inside. Some held signs in English and Spanish calling upon Gov. Mario Cuomo to reinstate the death penalty. Other signs, some held by small children, said, ``Adios, Jessica'' or ``Jessica, We Are With You.'' ``I'm a mother and a grandmother and I am scared,'' said Maria Ramirez, who held a sign in Spanish calling for death to the killer. ``Our children are our future. We need the death penalty or we will destroy our future.'' Jessica's mother, Milagros Guzman, barely able to walk and supported by her husband, Wilfredo, and a family friend, clutched her daughter's doll throughout the service, which was piped to loudspeakers outside. Wilfredo Guzman clutched a wooden cross. O'Connor urged the family and those assembled to ``use this suffering. It can make all of us compassionate. It can change this city. It can completely revitalize this city. It can replace violence with love and gentleness. It can replace crime with tenderness. It can replace anger with peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Supreme Court Strikes Ethics Amendment From Ballot
DOC.TEXT: The Missouri Supreme Court on Monday threw an ethics amendment off the Nov. 6 ballot. Opponents argued it was unconstitutional because it covered too many subjects. In a one-paragraph ruling, the court upheld a judge's decision to take Amendment 5 off the ballot. The judges offered no immediate comment, saying they would issue a written opinion later. Amendment backers could seek a rehearing, but there apparently are no other routes for state appeals. Amendment 5 would create a state ethics commission. It also would reduce the 163-member House to 103 members by 2003, shorten legislative sessions, and appropriate money for ethics commission operations ahead of other spending. Democrats contend the measure is an attempt by Republican Gov. John Ashcroft, a major financial backer of Amendment 5, to reduce legislative strength. ``No other governor in recent memory, Democrat or Republican, has undertaken such a blatant campaign against the elected members of the Senate and House under the guise of `ethics.' Luckily, the Missouri Supreme Court has seen through his duplicity,'' said Senate President Pro Tem James Mathewson, a Democrat. Ashcroft had no immediate comment. The court's decision - issued 15 days before the election - was distributed to reporters within 90 minutes after it concluded a hearing appealing Cole County Circuit Judge James McHenry's order. Attorney John Bardgett Sr., representing amendment opponents, told the state's highest court that Amendment 5 unconstitutionally deals with too many subjects. It placed voters in the confusing position of voting for ethics while reducing their legislative representation, he said. ``Do you think people ought to have to swallow one to get the other?'' asked Bardgett, the court's former chief justice.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeking Restitution from Florida Banker
DOC.TEXT: The Office of Thrift Supervision said today it will seek $30.8 million in restitution from David L. Paul, the former chairman of the failed CenTrust Bank of Miami. OTS officials told a news conference it was the second-largest amount they are seeking in a savings and loan case. They said Paul's ``insatiable vanity and greed'' were a major factor in the failure of CenTrust, which will cost taxpayers an estimated $1.7 billion. The thrift agency said it is serving Paul with an order demanding restitution to CenTrust and barring him from selling or transferring any assets of more than $5,000. The OTS also is seeking an order that would prohibit Paul from working for any savings and loan. The regulators are seeking the return of $15 million from a legal defense fund set up by CenTrust to pay legal fees in lawsuits filed against Paul and other directors. The $30.8 million also includes $4.9 million from a special retirement plan created mainly for Paul. The assets of the plan were transferred out of the country and managed by Edward D.G. Davies, a British financier and former director of CenTrust. The OTS officials said Paul will have until Nov. 1 to pay the money or to post bond in that amount. However, they said, they do not know his whereabouts. ``We believe he still has a residence in Miami, Florida,'' said Faith Hochberg, a senior deputy chief counsel of OTS. She said the order will be sent to that address. There is speculation that Paul is currently in Israel. If Paul does not answer the request, the regulators said they will go to federal court in Miami to compel him to do so. The largest amount sought by federal regulators in an S&L case was $40 million, from Charles Keating, Jr.

DOC.HEAD: Better Male Contraceptive Cited By WHO
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization said Monday that tests on four continents show weekly hormone injections for men could be a more effective birth control method than the pill. The agency said the technique used a hormone preparation, testosterone enanthate, that is already in use for other purposes. It halts sperm production. The WHO said the research involved 271 men, of whom 157 received weekly injections of the hormone. Their partners stopped using any other form of contraception for a year. ``There was only one pregnancy during 1,486 months of exposure, an extremely high contraceptive efficacy, comparable to that of female injectable contraceptives, better than that of oral contraceptives and intrauterine devices, and substantially better than that of condoms,'' the WHO said. The tests were conducted in seven countries - Australia, China, Finland, France, Sweden, Britain and the United States. The WHO said there were ``few side effects directly attributable to the hormone'' but did not elaborate. It said a number of volunteers withdrew from the project because they found it impractical to get weekly injections. ``WHO's four-continent trial devised to examine a hormonal antifertility technique in men has produced a major breakthrough,'' a WHO statement said. More practical ways of dispensing the hormone, perhaps requiring only three injections a year, are being developed, WHO said.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Plan Ignores Conventional Economic Theory
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Congress are about to turn economic wisdom on its head with a plan to raise taxes and slash spending with the nation seemingly on the verge of a recession. Yet despite occasional jeers from supply-side disciples in Congress, many economic experts say it's precisely the right thing to do. ``Under normal conditions, you don't want to be cutting back on government demand at the same time that private demand is dropping in a recession because that gives a double whammy to the economy,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. ``But when things are this far out of kilter, the benefits of solving the underlying structural problem outweigh the short-term damage,'' he said. Economists are afraid rising government borrowing needs will push U.S. interest rates higher and make it difficult for American companies to finance the modernization needed to compete in a world economy. The emerging budget deal in Congress would cut spending throughout the government, raise income taxes on the wealthy and increase the federal gasoline tax, all contrary to the traditional economic theory that says spending should be increased and taxes cut during slow times in the hope of stimulating the economy. Critics of the deal are warning it will turn George Bush into Herbert Hoover, another Republican president who preached the need for budgetary prudence as a response to an economic downturn. But a large number of private economists believe Congress and the president are doing the right thing in putting together a program to trim the federal deficit by $500 billion over the next five years although they admit it goes against the economic gospel as preached by John Maynard Keynes. Keynesian economics holds that the government through its spending and taxing policies should stimulate the economy when it's weak and restrain it when it's strong. Supporters of the deficit program make these arguments: While the combination of tax increases and spending cuts will remove purchasing power from the economy at a critical time, the Federal Reserve has promised to offset those adverse impacts by lowering interest rates to stimulate economic activity. In addition, the impact of the deficit-cutting package is relatively small in the immediate future. It calls for a small down payment of only $40 billion in deficit-cutting medicine in the current fiscal year, at a time when the economy is expected to be weakest. The really big tax and spending changes won't begin to bite until later years, when the economy will supposedly be in better shape because of the Fed's efforts to push interest rates lower. Harvard economist Martin Feldstein, whose arguments for tax increases got him into hot water during his days as head of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, is one of many economists supporting the deficit reduction package. ``To the extent that it is contractionary, it is fairly easy for the Fed to offset that and the longer term results of the package will be expansionary,'' Feldstein said. Many economists said they believed the $40 billion in deficit cuts called for in the first year was about the right size - large enough to be credible but not so large that it would too seriously dampen a $5 trillion economy. However, there is debate on that point. Some analysts contend that the recession they believe is imminent will be made worse by the deficit package. ``The simple fact is that Congress and the administration waited too long to get serious about deficit cutting,'' said David Jones, chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer. ``I think it is incorrect to think that interest rates will fall far enough to offset the negative effects of raising taxes and cutting spending that are in the plan.'' Jones said he believes a recession, the first one in eight years, started in August and could last for up to 18 months. The trouble Bush has had selling the deficit-cutting package to House Republicans reflects a belief among supply-side enthusiasts that tax cuts, not tax increases, are what an ailing economy needs. ``The deficit cutters have a simplistic notion that if the medicine doesn't taste good then just swallow hard and you will feel better in the morning. I don't think that is true,'' said John Makin, an economist with the conservative American Enterprise Institute. But other economists argue that economic peril lies in continuing to ignore the string of budget deficits. Next year's deficit is expected to total nearly $300 billion without any changes. They contend this legacy of debt has driven U.S. interest rates higher, increased the country's dependency on foreign capital and curtailed the critical investments America needs to boost productivity. ``We need more deficit reduction, not less,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``It is not so much for us but for our kids and their potential standard of living that this is so important.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Air Force Major Escapes; Headed for Reunion with American Wife
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For $6 and a pack of cigarettes, Saddam Hussein's troops looked the other way as Ruthie Schaeffer's husband - a Kuwaiti Air Force major - joined a 100-car convoy in slipping into Iran from Iraq. ``My heart was beating out of my chest when they looked at my identification papers - all fake,'' the 12-year military veteran said Monday in a telephone interview from Tehran, Iran. ``I tried to say anything nice.'' So, to an Iraqi soldier, Kazem stammered: ``You are heroes.'' ``And the Iraqi, he looked at me. He said `Do you really believe we are heroes?''' ``And I said `Yes, I believe you are.' I gave him some chocolate. He took it and then said: `We are not.' Then he let me go.'' The father of three, who asked that his last name be withheld to protect family still in Kuwait, plans to join his American wife and children in Germantown, Tenn., after securing a new passport later this week. ``When I left I really felt I would never see him again. He was torn between his country and his children,'' said Ruthie Schaeffer, who fled Kuwait with her young children about a month after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``I had very little hope that he'd get out alive,'' she said. ``But after all the waiting, waiting day by day, it's over. We're going to start over.'' An estimated 1,000 U.S. citizens are still trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, their relatives remain hostages of Saddam, who on Monday reportedly said he would release some elderly and sick Americans. For Kazem, the prospect of leaving Kuwait was wrenching. Returning to the United States meant a reunion with his wife and children. But for a career military officer and patriot, it also was a personal admission of defeat. ``I did not want to go. If I leave the country and my friends in the military leave, who's going to fight the Iraqis?'' Kazem said. ``But we were like animals ... hunted and with no where to hide.'' The decision to leave finally was made for Kazem. ``My uncle said I was endangering my family,'' he said. ``The Iraqis were looking for me.'' So at dawn on Oct. 8, Kazem took a set of false Iranian identification and joined a caravan at a highway outside Kuwait City for a seven-hour journey through Iraq and into Iran. Kazem said Monday that he'd learned through friends that Iraqi officials last week put an end to the daily convoys, which were led by Iranian Embassy officials ostensibly bringing their own citizens home. ``There were at least a hundred cars in front of me and many more behind,'' Kazem said. ``When I got to the border I saw some friends there. They were hugging and kissing me. They'd heard two days before that I had been killed.'' Kazem, who never stayed in once place longer than 12 hours, said at least three of his relatives - many of whom are in the military - have been murdered by Iraqi troops. ``And many, many of my friends - my best friends - in the military,'' he said. ``The Iraqis, they are looking in all the houses ... pulling out nails, cutting ears, burning with their cigarettes,'' Kazem said. ``We in the military have to leave. What else to do? ``We fought; we did our best. But there are about 400,000 Iraqi soldiers and we are what? Between 20,000 to 30,000. We are a small country, a peaceful country. We've never had to fight before.''

DOC.HEAD: Paper: Saddam Reportedly Dreamt of Mohammed Saying Invasion Wrong
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti newspaper reported that Saddam Hussein dreamed the prophet Mohammed appeared before him and told the Iraqi president his country's missiles ``were pointed in the wrong direction.'' Reports on the dream that circulated in international financial circles are said to have accounted in part for the largest one-day drop ever on New York markets of oil prices - a fall of $5.41 a barrel to $28.38. Oil prices plunged $5.65 a barrel to close at $26.75 in London. Saddam is said to have told an audience of top aides who murmured ``God be blessed'' how Mohammed appeared before him swathed in white robes, the newspaper Al-Seyassah said Sunday. ``The prophet Mohammed visited me in my sleep all dressed in pure white, but appearing concerned about something,'' Al-Seyassah said. It quoted Saddam as relating: ```O prophet of the Lord,' I told him, `what is it you require of me?' And he replied `I've come, Saddam, to call your attention to a big mistake.' ```What is it O Prophet,' I asked, and he said `I see your rockets deployed wrongly.''' Iraqi missiles have been reported to be pointing south toward the hundreds of thousands of Western forces massed in and around Saudi Arabia, which abuts the Kuwaiti border. ```How?' I asked, and he replied, ``They are not pointed in the right direction,''' the paper said of Saddam's purported remarks. ```What is the direction you want, O Prophet of the Lord?' I asked and he replied, `You know the direction and you should correct it.''' Saddam then reportedly said, ``Suddenly the Prophet disappeared, and it seems he only came to make that remark.'' Al-Seyassah, whose report could not be independently confirmed, is an arm of the ousted government of Kuwait, and has been active in trying to discredit Saddam. Al-Seyassah is published in Saudi Arabia where the Kuwaiti government fled after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Al-Seyassah said the story was being spread around Iraq's capital of Baghdad by Iraqi intelligence in an apparent attempt to prepare Iraqis psychologically for a pullout from Kuwait. There have been unconfirmed reports in recent days that Iraqi troops were being pulled from major parts of Kuwait and amassing around a fenced area that surrounds two northern Persian Gulf islands and an oilfield that Saddam covets.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant's Outburst Disrupts Second Jogger Trial
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age defendant disrupted the second Central Park jogger rape and attempted murder trial Monday when he began sobbing and yelling that the prosecutor was lying. ``No! No! No! I can't deal with this,'' Kharey Wise, 18, cried when Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer finished her opening statement. Wise then bent forward and vomited next to the defense table. As court officers led him out of the courtroom, Wise screamed: ``I can't take this! It isn't true! She's lying! She's lying!'' Wise is one of two teen-agers on trial in connection with the gang rape and savage beating of a woman who was attacked during her nightly run and left for dead in Central Park. In an earlier trial, three youths were convicted of rape and assault but acquitted of attempted murder. Howard Diller, attorney for co-defendant Kevin Richardson, 16, asked Acting Justice Thomas Galligan for a mistrial or a separate trial for his client. Diller said Wise had become ``stressed out'' and was ``foaming at the mouth.'' The judge denied the motion, noting that the outburst occurred just after he called a break in the session and the jurors had left the courtroom. Galligan warned Wise he would be removed from the courtroom if he disrupted the trial again. Shortly before Lederer finished her opening remarks, Wise had rocked in his seat, talked to himself and held his hands to his face. He bit his lip and pounded his forehead with his fist. Lederer said Wise and Richardson were among 30 youths who went into Central Park the night of April 19, 1989, ``to beat, to rob, to assault, to attack anyone they found in the park.'' She said the defendants' guilt will be proved by the testimony of bicyclists, joggers, police officers, medical and scientific experts, and by their own written and videotaped statements. She said Richardson described in a videotaped statement how he and the other youths hid in the dark and attacked the jogger when she ran past. The prosecutor said Richardson describes how they ripped the jogger's shirt off, how she screamed for help and how she scratched Richardson's face. ``He tells how everyone was feeling her, how they took her pants off and raped her,'' Lederer said. She said Wise made two videotaped statements because he admittedly lied in the first one. In the second tape, he describes how he held the victim's leg and fondled it while others raped her. Diller, who began his opening remarks immediately after the 15-minute break, told the jury that police put words in his client's mouth. He suggested that Richardson confessed to things he did not do, that he was tricked. Wise's lawyer, Colin Moore, told the jury in his opening that the prosecution's case was ``an optical illusion, a conjurer's trick, done with smoke and mirrors.'' He said the prosecutor was promising more than she can deliver. ``I want you to compare the preview with the actual thing,'' he said. Wise and Richardson are among six teen-agers who were charged in connection with the attack on the female jogger and two male runners that night. The first trial ended in five-to-10-year sentences - the maximum for juvenile offenders - for Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana and Antron McCray, all 16. They were convicted of rape, assault, robbery and riot, but acquitted of attempted murder and sodomy. The sixth defendant, Steven Lopez, 16, will be tried separately on the charges early next year. Wise, 16 at the time of the attacks, faces adult penalties that could total up to 57 years in prison if he is convicted on all counts. Richardson, 14 when he was arrested, faces the same five to 10 years as the three convicted in the first trial.

DOC.HEAD: Record Cold On Southern Plains, Very Wet In East
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dropped to record-tying lows Monday in Texas and New Mexico, and rain fell across much of the East and into the Ohio Valley. San Angelo, Texas, hit a record low of 33. Records were tied at 32 in Abilene, Texas; 30 at Albuquerque, N.M.; 31 at El Paso, Texas; 33 at Midland and Odessa, Texas; and 32 at Wichita Falls, Texas. Afternoon rain and showers extended from northern Maine and northern Vermont across central and western New York state, much of Pennsylvania, the southeastern half of Ohio, West Virginia, western Maryland, the western half of Virginia, southeastern Indiana, Kentucky, Tennessee and western North Carolina. Showers and occasional thunderstorms spread across South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, the Florida Panhandle and east-central Florida. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 3.07 inches at Mary Esther, Fla.; 2.32 inches at Valparaiso, Fla.; 1.52 inches at Pensacola, Fla.; 1.36 inches at Greer, S.C.; 1.17 inches at Hickory, N.C.; 1.12 inches at Chattanooga, Tenn.; and 1.04 inches at Anniston, Ala. Elsewhere, showers also were scattered over east-central South Dakota, southeastern Idaho, northwestern Montana, the southern coast of Washington state, and the central coast of Oregon. At higher elevations, by afternoon there was 2 inches of snow at West Yellowstone, Mont., and 5 inches of snow at Washington's Stampede Pass. Cape Hatteras, N.C., warmed to a record high of 82. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 3 above zero at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 36 at McCall, Idaho, and Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 91 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Confirms Iraq Has U.S.-Made Missiles
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi military forces captured some of Kuwait's cache of U.S.-made Hawk anti-aircraft missiles and apparently are trying to learn how to use the weapons, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Monday. A State Department spokeswoman in Washington said most of Kuwait's Hawk missiles were captured in Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The United States had sold Kuwait five Hawk batteries and more than 150 Hawk missiles. The Hawks are said to be superior to other anti-aircraft weapons in the Iraqi arsenal. ``We don't know precisely how many they have. We do know that the Iraqis captured some Hawk missiles that the Kuwaitis previously acquired and they now have them,'' Cheney told journalists after meeting President Francois Mitterrand. ``Whether or not they're able to make them function or not at this point, we don't know,'' he said. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said: ``We assume that the Iraqis are attempting to learn to use the Hawk systems.'' Ms. Tutwiler said Jordan had given assurances at ``the highest levels'' that it was providing no assistance to Iraq in learning how to use the Hawks. ``We have no collateral information to dispute those assurances,'' she said. The Washington Post reported Sunday that concerned U.S. officials inquired after Israeli reports appeared saying Jordanian technicians were teaching Iraqis how to use the missiles. The Post reported Iraq brought the Hawks back to Baghdad, where Iraqi technicians were trying to learn how to use them. Many U.S. and allied military aircraft in the gulf region have no ready means of protection against the Hawks, the newspaper cited U.S. officials as saying. Cheney spoke to reporters after 45 minutes of talks with President Francois Mitterrand. The talks completed Cheney's 10-day European tour, which also included stops in London and Moscow. He headed back to Washington late Monday. In an interview earlier Monday with the French television network La Cinq, Cheney said ``there is no particular calendar'' for the U.N. sanctions against Iraq to drive Baghdad's troops out of Kuwait. ``We believe that the sanctions are getting more and more effective,'' he said. ``They're beginning to hve an impact on the economy and to have an impact on their ... military potential.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Prime Minister Met Sister in North, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon secretly visited a sister he had not seen in 45 years during last week's high-level talks in North Korea, according to Tuesday newspaper reports. Two other senior Seoul officials also saw relatives, Korean newspapers said, citing as their source North Korean reporters now in Seoul for an inter-Korean soccer match. There was no confirmation. All three - Kang; National Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul; and Limb Dong-won, chairman of the state-run Institute for Foreign Affairs - were originally from North Korea and all have said they wanted to meet their separated family members. The reports said Kang, 65, saw his 64-year-old sister Yong-sun and her son for an hour at the government guest house where he was staying in Pyongyang. Kang fled to the South in 1945 when the peninsula was divided. Hong and Limb also met relatives during the four-day stay, the reports said. A spokesman for Kang had denied speculation Kang would see his sister during the second round of talks. The spokesman said it would be inappropriate to mix personal matters with the talks. The peninsula was divided in 1945 and the two nations fought a 1950-53 war. An estimated 10 million Koreans are separated from family members on either side of the tightly sealed border.

DOC.HEAD: Ailing Robbery Suspect Returns to Face Authorities
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two weeks after he took $125,000 at gunpoint from a currency exchange, a janitor who believes he has cancer returned to New York to surrender, saying he did it to ``provide for my family.'' ``It's no life on the run,'' Bernard Gamble, 59, said in an interview published Monday. ``Stay with the ones you love for the little time you have left. Give them all the love you can. Because when you are alone, you have nothing.'' Gamble robbed the Deak International currency exchange at Kennedy International Airport of $125,000 on Oct. 7 while keeping his co-workers at bay with a gun, authorities said. He told employees he was dying of cancer and needed the money for his wife and five children. Before fleeing, he dropped off $85,000 at his daughter's home in the borough of Queens. He told New York Newsday he then spent most of the time riding Greyhound buses between Chicago and Florida. His family immediately turned the money over to police and made public appeals for their father to come home. Gamble returned to the city Thursday and checked into a hospital on Friday for tests for stomach cancer, said his attorney, Barry Slotnick. ``I'm sorry. I never meant to hurt anyone,'' Gamble told Newsday. ``All I wanted to do was provide for my family, give my wife something to live on after I am gone.'' Slotnick, who refused to divulge his client's whereabouts, said Gamble would be arraigned on robbery charges Tuesday. ``There are no developments,'' said Richard Piperno, a spokesman for Queens District Attorney John Santucci. He said he could not comment further on the case. Slotnick said the family would return the rest of the money by the end of the week. Gamble told Newsday that while on the run, he carried a slip of paper with the name of his daughter and her telephone number, as well as the phone number of his wife, Joanne, for notification in case he died. He also said he did not read his family's appeals for his return because he lost his glasses. Donna Chiorando said her father ``is back with the people who love him. Now we're waiting to see what the doctors say. We're waiting to find out how long he will be with us.'' Gamble said he never planned a getaway, and was finally persuaded to stop running when his only grandchild, 2-year-old John Chiorando Jr., spoke to him on the phone. ``He said, `Grandpa, I love you. Come to my house and play ball with me,''' Gamble said.

DOC.HEAD: Performances of `A Few Good Men' Canceled After Fire
DOC.TEXT: ``A Few Good Men'' resumes performances at the Wednesday matinee after a weekend electrical fire in Broadway's Music Box Theater forced cancellation of the military courtroom drama. The electrical equipment fire apparently started about 11:30 a.m. Saturday, setting off the sprinkler system, said David Powers, a spokesman for the show. Water damage was confined to the wings and basement of the theater, Powers said Monday. No monetary damage estimate was available. The producers canceled both performances Saturday as well as performances on Monday and Tuesday. ``A Few Good Men,'' which stars Ron Perlman and Bradley Whitford, opened last November.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleds Guilty to Organizing Alien Smuggling Ring
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of organizing a ring that smuggled illegal aliens across the Niagara River from Canada in small rubber rafts pleaded guilty Monday to conspiracy. The ring, which smuggled mostly Chinese aliens, operated from the summer of 1988 until the end of that year, when a raft sank in the icy river. Two bodies were recovered and two others are believed killed. Yick Tak Cheung, 41, of New York, faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine for the conspiracy count. Another ring member, Wai Wei Cheng, 31, pleaded guilty Friday to one count of transporting illegal aliens, U.S. Attorney Dennis C. Vacco said. U.S. District Judge John T. Elfvin was scheduled to sentence both in January. U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service officials estimated that the ring ferried several dozen aliens across the fast-running river. The aliens entered Canada on real or phony tourist visas, then paid smugglers up to thousands of dollars apiece to be smuggled into the United States, authorities said. Taxi drivers James Dullan and Richard Kephardt testified in pre-trial proceedings that they met aliens near the riverbank in Lewiston, about 30 miles north of Buffalo, and drove drive them either to the Buffalo airport or to New York City. U.S. authorities said the rafts had cellular telephones the aliens or their escorts could use to arrange to be picked up upon arrival. Authorities began investigating the ring in the fall of 1988 after groups of wet, bewildered Asians were seen in the small border village of Lewiston. The case was cracked when the raft sank. Dullan and Kephardt pleaded guilty to conspiracy in the summer of 1989 and became government witnesses. Minh Hoang, accused of ferrying the aliens across the river, pleaded guilty in Canada to negligent homicide and is serving a 21-month prison sentence there. INS officials said Tick and his wife, Cheng Chui-Ping, each ran separate smuggling rings catering primarily to Chinese destined for New York. Ms. Cheng pleaded guilty over the summer to conspiracy to transport illegal aliens and was sentenced to six months in prison.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Raise Long-Distance Rates.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph will raise its basic night and weekend long-distance phone prices by 2.2 percent, beginning Nov. 2, the company said on Monday. ``The change is necessary to bring prices in line with costs,'' said Merrill Tutton, vice president of AT&T Consumer Services. The company said the increase will result in about $39.4 million in increased annual revenue. That amounts to about five cents on an average $16 monthly long-distance bill, the company said. AT&T said the increase applies only to out-of-state direct-dialed long distance calls made during night and weekend hours. These are after 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday and all weekend until 5 p.m. Sunday. The company said that overall its out-of-state direct-dialed long-distance rates have gone down about 42 percent since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: External Examination of Cassette Recorder Wouldn't Reveal Bomb
DOC.TEXT: The radiocassette recorder packed with explosives that blew up Pan Am Flight 103 could have worked normally and the bomb would have been difficult to detect, an explosives expert said Monday. Anyone examining the Toshiba twin-speed recorder would have seen nothing suspicious on the outside, said Alan Faraday, head of the forensic explosives laboratory at the Royal Armament Research and Development Establishment. He told a public inquiry into the Dec. 21, 1988, terrorist bombing that killed 270 people there was ``no reason'' why the recorder should not work normally even with the device inside. ``I am certain that if someone had seen it and turned it on it would have been insufficient to determine it had been modified,'' he said. Passengers carrying cassette recorders or radios at British airports are routinely asked by security personnel to turn them on. New security measures agreed on after the Pan Am disaster require security staff to make other checks, ``but we can't go into that because of security,'' a Department of Transport spokesman said on condition of anonymity.
