Asked by Scotland's chief law officer, Lord Advocate Lord Fraser, if the device would have shown up on airport X-ray machines, Faraday said it would have taken an extremely good operator to spot it. Faraday said experiments showed only a small amount of explosive could be hidden in the player, but that the cassette recorder would look like an ordinary machine without any external signs of a concealed bomb. Faraday said a number of items had been found in the wreckage that indicated a Toshiba recorder had been used to hide the device. He said examination of a luggage container from the jumbo's wreckage showed the ``unique characteristics'' of a close detonation. Specimens taken from the wreckage showed evidence of two types of chemicals that are manufactured as ``colorless, crystalized substances,'' he said. Both chemicals are used in the Semtex explosives made in Czechoslovakia, he said. ``I don't know of any other explosives that are manufactured including these two ingredients other than the Semtex range but there could be others,'' he said. Before Faraday gave evidence, the presiding judge, Sheriff Principal John Mowat, said it would be ``undesirable'' for Faraday to be photographed or sketched while around the court. The inquiry, expected to last into the new year, is focusing on the deaths of 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 and 11 on the ground in Lockerbie, and ways to prevent a similar disaster. Scottish investigators have said they are investigating several radical Palestinian groups, but the inquiry is not considering criminal responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused of Arsenic Poisoning Goes on Trial
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A woman accused of giving arsenic to two husbands and a boyfriend went on trial Monday for the boyfriend's death. But her attorney said it was yet another man who was responsible for the crimes. The prosecutor told jurors that Blanche Taylor Moore had forged a chain of overlapping relationships with men that led her to murder Raymond Reid, a boyfriend with whom she had worked at a supermarket. Defense attorney Mitchell McEntire insisted on the innocence of the 57-year-old grocery clerk, whom he described as a hard-working, churchgoing mother. ``Her life has not been above sin. Sin has touched her life,'' McEntire said. ``But she is free of guilt in any crime. For indeed, she is not guilty.'' Mrs. Moore is being tried in Forsyth County Superior Court on a charge of first degree murder in Reid's death. She also has been charged with killing her first husband, James N. Taylor, and trying to kill her second husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore. Those cases are being tried separately. McEntire pinned the crimes on Garvin Thomas, who apparently had an obsession from afar with Mrs. Moore and ``could not bear the thought of another man having her.'' The defense attorney said Thomas signed a letter confessing to the three poisonings, which took place over 15 years, but died before the letter reached the Alamance County Jail, where Mrs. Moore was being held. However, McEntire said Thomas had visited his office several weeks earlier. ``He said: `Your client didn't do these things. I know your client is innocent,' '' the defense lawyer told the court. In his opening arguments, Forsyth County District Attorney Warren Sparrow described Mrs. Moore's tangled web of relationships with men. He said Mrs. Moore's relationship with Reid began in the mid-1960s. Reid was divorced in 1971 and James N. Taylor, then Mrs. Moore's husband, died in 1973 of what investigators now believe was arsenic poisoning. ``Raymond Reid gave her money and jewels over the years to come,'' Sparrow said. ``But in January 1985, the defendant decided that Raymond Reid might not really be the man she wanted.'' During that time, Mrs. Moore was counseled by a psychiatrist, Sparrow said. ``The primary topic between the defendant and her psychiatrist was more her inability to get along with Raymond Reid,'' Sparrow said. McEntire said psychological tests performed during that time found that Mrs. Moore displayed no hostility, multiple personalities or any other similar traits. ``Blanche Moore is not deranged, nor does she carry a load of hostility or repressed anger,'' he said. Reid died on Oct. 7, 1986. At the time, his death was attributed to Guillain-Barre syndrome, the symptoms of which are similar to those of arsenic poisoning. Mrs. Moore married Dwight Moore in 1989. Three days after their wedding, Moore became ill with what doctors have described as a near-fatal bout with arsenic poisoning.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Retransmitting to fix category code
DOC.HEAD: Gantt Leads Helms By 8 Percentage Points
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Senate candidate Harvey Gantt leads incumbent Republican Sen. Jesse Helms with just two weeks to go until the Nov. 6 election, says a new poll. Gantt held a lead among likely voters of 49 percent to Helms' 41 percent, according to The Charlotte Observer-WSOC-TV poll published Saturday. Ten percent were undecided in the survey, which had a margin of error of four percentage points. The survey of 595 likely voters was taken Oct. 15-18. Gantt is a former two-term mayor of Charlotte and the nation's first black Democratic Senate nominee.
DOC.HEAD: Avenson May Leave Church Over Abortion Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Don Avenson said Monday he may leave a church his family founded because the minister threatened to expel him for continuing to support abortion rights. Avenson said he's discussed resigning from the church with his family and has written to the church hierarchy explaining his stance. Avenson belongs to Peace Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod. The Missouri Synod of the church opposes abortion rights. The controversy began on Sunday when Avenson released a copy of a letter from the minister of his church criticizing his ``persistent outspokenness for abortion.'' The minister, Rev. Bruce Scarbeary, said he wanted to talk with Avenson about abortion rights ``in view of your continued membership in the congregation.'' Avenson said the dispute ``is exactly why we ought not to be drafting into statutes the theology of any given church. It leads to problems for people who don't believe that theology.'' Though the letter didn't directly threaten to expel him from the church, Avenson said that's the way he interpreted the letter. ``I'm not going to get involved in a private matter between Don Avenson and his minister,'' said Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, who said there should be no ``mixing of church and state.'' Branstad opposes abortion rights.
DOC.HEAD: Five Women Run for Four Top State Offices
DOC.TEXT: The old boy's club of California politics may become a thing of the past. Five contenders for four top offices are women. If they win, women candidates for governor, lieutenant governor, treasurer and secretary of state would in a single election quadruple the gains that women have made in top-level state politics over the past 34 years. Democrat Dianne Feinstein is waging an aggressive battle for governor against Republican Pete Wilson. And Democratic challenger Kathleen Brown - the daughter of one former governor and the sister of another - is leading appointed GOP incumbent Thomas Hayes in the race for treasurer. California is virtually assured to retain a woman for secretary of state. Democratic incumbent March Fong Eu, only the second woman elected to top state office, is opposed by Republican Los Angeles City Councilwoman Joan Milke Flores. For lieutenant governor, Republican state Sen. Marian Bergeson is in an uphill race against Democratic incumbent Leo McCarthy. Women currently hold 15 of the 80 seats in the state Assembly, and five seats in the 40-member state Senate. Of California's 45 representatives in Congress, only two are women.
DOC.HEAD: Ballot Number Scramble, Omission of Candidate Name, Force Reprint
DOC.TEXT: The state of Washington will pay $200,000 to reprint 900,000 voter pamphlets that contain errors. One pamphlet contains the wrong numbers next to three ballot measures. Some pamphlets omitted the name of a Libertarian Party congressional candidate. The state prints over 2 million pamphlets and ``you're going to make some mistakes now and then,'' said Donald Whiting, assistant secretary of states. Whiting attributed the mistakes to the tight production schedule for the pamphlet, printed after the Sept. 18 primary.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Apologizes For `Housewife' Slur
DOC.TEXT: State House candidate Don Chenhall apologized for referring to opponent Cheri Davis as ``a housewife who doesn't even drive a car.'' Chenhall, an independent, called his response on a written questionnaire a lapse of judgment. In a hand-delivered letter to Davis, Chenhall, said his remark was ``an indelicate and tasteless remark and I apologize for it.'' Davis is the Republican incumbent.
DOC.HEAD: Gay Lobby Gives Record Amount to Republican Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest gay and lesbian lobby has given a record $76,000 to Republican candidates for the U.S. House and Senate, a spokesman said Monday. The Human Rights Campaign Fund made the contributions because support for gay causes can be found in both parties, said Timothy McFeeley, the fund's executive director. The $76,000 accounted for 18 percent of the lobby's total contributions this election cycle, McFeeley said. The fund gave the legal limit - $10,000 - to three GOP candidates: Rep. Ron Machtley of Rhode Island, Trudy Coxe, who is running for the seat being vacated by Rep. Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island; and Rep. John Miller of Washington. Rep. Bill Green, a moderate New York City Republican with strong ties to the gay community, received $7,000.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Kept Out of Jerusalem; Teen-Ager Dies In Clash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to UPDATE with another attack, comments from Washington. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `On Monday...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1-3
DOC.TEXT: Israeli forces blocked Palestinians from entering Jerusalem on Monday to prevent clashes following the murders of three Jews by a knife-wielding Arab. A Palestinian teen-ager was killed and 19 others were hospitalized with wounds suffered in clashes with Israeli troops Monday throughout the occupied West Bank, Arab reports said. Despite the heightened security in Jerusalem, a Palestinian stabbed a Jew, slightly injuring him. Police searched a nearby village for the assailant. Also Monday, an 18-year-old Palestinian died of wounds suffered in an August 1988 clash. Mohammed Naim Abu Akar was known among Palestinians as ``the living martyr'' for surviving on intravenous feedings after Israeli bullets destroyed his intestines. Later, police in downtown Jerusalem arrested a 23-year-old Palestinian after he tried to stab one of the officers, police spokesman Aharon Elchayani said. Israel television said the attacker came from the West Bank in spite of the travel ban. Jews angered by Sunday's killings stoned Arab cars and beat several Arab pedestrians, Israel radio said. It blamed members of the anti-Arab Kach Party, saying they were bent on inciting trouble. After the violence, national police headquarters announced the ban on Palestinians entering Jerusalem would continue for at least a second day Tuesday ``in view of the present tension in the city.'' The blockade does not affect the 140,000 Palestinians living in Jerusalem, but does apply to thousands who come from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to work in the city. Police spokesman Ron Yishayahu said that in addition to a ``massive deployment of police forces'' in Jerusalem, night patrols by police and paramilitary troops would be stepped up. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir blamed the violence on ``a terrible atmosphere of incitement'' in the Arab world following President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``There is some kind of delusion that redemption will come from Baghdad and that once and for all, the Arabs will get rid of the `Zionist satan,''' Shamir told reporters. He said Israel was prepared to take tougher steps to stop attacks, adding the Jewish state would ``surmount this wave of hostility and terrorism.'' Shortly after Shamir spoke, his right-wing coalition survived its second no-confidence motion since taking office June 11. The 53-51 vote, with two abstentions, was forced by left-wing parties angered by Shamir's handling of the economy, relations with the United States and Soviet immigrants. Serious clashes in Jerusalem began Oct. 8, when police fired on Moslems on the Temple Mount after they stoned Jewish worshipers at the nearby Western Wall. At least 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded. On Sunday, a knife-wielding Palestinian apparently sought to avenge the killings on the Temple Mount, known to Arabs as Haram es-Sharif. He attacked Jews in Jerusalem, killing three and wounding a 13-year-old boy. Two victims, a woman soldier and a gardener, were buried Sunday. The third, an off-duty policeman who died stopping the attacker, was buried Monday. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the 19-year-old man arrested for the Sunday stabbings ``obviously had gone temporarily insane.'' ``The president deplores the tragic killings of three Israeli citizens,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``These killings make it all the more important that the cycle of violence be ended. We urge all parties to act to reinforce peace and calm in the region.'' The Bush administration supported an Oct. 12 U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israeli police for the slayings and authorizing Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send investigators to the city. On Monday, a Palestinian armed with a bayonet-style blade attacked a Jewish man delivering meat to a supermarket in a Jewish neighborhood of Arab east Jerusalem. The victim, Moshe Koren, 46, was slightly wounded in the back. Police pursued the attacker, who worked at the market, to nearby Hizmeh, his home village. Door-to-door searches were reported. Police poured reinforcements into Jerusalem and set up army and police roadblocks to bar Palestinians from the occupied territories from entering the city.They said they wanted to prevent further attacks on Jews and head off possible revenge attacks on Arabs. A soldier was stabbed by an ax-wielding Palestinian inside a military government building Monday in the Gaza town of Rafah, the army said. The army spokesman's office said the soldier was slightly wounded. Scattered stone-throwing clashes with Israeli troops were reported in a half-dozen towns and refugee camps in the occupied territories. Arab hospital officials said at least 19 Palestinians were admitted with gunshot wounds. In the West Bank town of Jenin, Mahmoud Lahlouh, 14, died after a live bullet hit him in the chest, the army said. His death and the death of the so-called ``living martyr'' raised to 763 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 34-month uprising against Israeli occupation. An additional 284 were slain by fellow Arabs, most for allegedly collaborating with Israel. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.SECOND: AM-NEA Grant Rejected, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0636,0737
DOC.HEAD: Gallery Director Fumes Over NEA's Grant Rejection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-15, `Ross said with five grafs to UPDATE with NEA saying National Council rejected the application and clerical mistake failed to inform the museum, INCLUDE description of Kelley's work; picks up 16th graf pvs, `Ross said Kelley's ...'; contents of 18th graf may be offensive to some readers
DOC.TEXT: The head of a museum that displayed photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe says politics is the reason why the hea of the National Endowment for the Arts rejected a grant for another exhibit there. ``A week ago I would have said no, but now I would say that maybe there is an informal blacklist,'' said David A. Ross, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art. The institute drew protests this summer with the Mapplethorpe show. In Cincinnati, a gallery and its director were acquitted of obscenity charges after showing the same photos. NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer told Ross he was rejecting a $40,000 grant to fund an exhibit by Los Angeles mixed-media artist Mike Kelley. The grant had been approved by an NEA selection panel. ``It is almost unprecedented in the history of the NEA that an application for a gallery is approved by a peer review panel and then gets rejected by the director,'' said Arthur Cohen, the institute's marketing director. An NEA spokeswoman denied that. ``It's not unusual for grants to be rejected at any level because of last-minute information or whatever,'' said spokeswoman Virginia Falck. Falck said NEA policy prevented the organization from saying why it rejected the grant, out of consideration of the artist's privacy. ``We get 18,000 applications a year, and we have money for only about 4,000,'' she said. Ross, however, cried foul. ``I see this action as an insult to the peer review system and to the artist as well as integrity of the Institute,'' he said. ``I am both saddened and angered by it.'' ``We will do the show no matter what,'' Ross said. Traditionally, NEA grants are recommended by a peer panel and referred to the National Council on the Arts, the agency's 26-member advisory board, but the chairman has the authority to approve or deny grants on his own. A late afternoon statement by the NEA said the council rejected the application in May, and Frohnmayer accepted that recommendation, but didn't tell the Boston museum because of a clerical error. ``Owing to an administrative oversight, the Institute for Contemporary Arts in Boston was not notified,'' the NEA said. ``The Art Endowment deeply regrets the error. It always is our intention to notify rejected grantees as soon as possible so that they can go on with their business.'' Before the statement was issued, Ross said: ``It appears that a fully political decision was made to reject this grant because the work may be considered controversial to some. ... It deals with any number of aspects of the dissolution of American society on a social and psychological level. (Kelley) deals with great humor and great wit and with great force and darkness as well.'' Kelley's work includes pen and ink drawings, painting, film and other mediums, such as arranging stuffed animals in a room to appear as though they are having conversations. Cohen said the only piece of Kelley's art that people might consider offensive was a cartoonish drawing of a man defecating. Kelley's drawings also include depictions of disembodied sexual organs. Ross said Kelley's work is part of several museums' permanent collections, including the Hirschhorn Museum in Washington, New York's Museum of Modern Art and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. The NEA controversy began last year when Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other conservatives in Congress objected to NEA funding of works they considered obscene. Helms singled out the Mapplethorpe exhibit, ``The Perfect Moment,'' for its sexually graphic photographs and nude children. Last week, a House compromise that would have allowed the NEA to award grants without content restrictions was derailed by the Senate Appropriations Committee, which reinstituted an anti-obscenity pledge that artists must sign before they receive grant money. The Kelley exhibit is scheduled to be shown in Boston in October 1992 and tour other museums across the nation and in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Rio Montt Accuses President of Hijinks in Guatemala Elections
DOC.TEXT: Former dictator Jose Efrain Rios Montt, himself banned from running, was said Monday to have accused President Vinicio Cerezo of planning to fix Nov. 11 elections to favor his Christian Democratic Party. The newspaper Prensa Libre said the retired general leveled the charge at a political rally last weekend in Chiquimula, 104 miles east of Guatemala City. It quoted Rios Montt as saying Cerezo plans to stack the balloting in favor of Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the presidential nominee of Cerezo's centrist Christian Democrats. Rios Montt offered no evidence, the paper said. ``King Vinicio and his court are preparing the throne for prince Cabrera because they think we are still 450 years back, and they are trying to manipulate the law,'' Rios Montt was quoted as saying. He urged his supporters to write his name on ballots ``to show that it is you who want me in power.'' By law, this would automatically invalidate the ballot. Enough invalid ballots could scuttle next month's election. Rios Montt also said he was robbed of victory when he ran for president on the Christian Democratic ticket in 1974. He said the election was fixed to put conservative Gen. Eugenio Kjell Laugerud in power. There was no immediate response from Cerezo or the Christian Democrats. Rios Montt was prohibited from running in next month's election because he became president as a result of a military coup 7{ years ago. Cerezo completes his five-year term Jan. 14, the first civilian elected president in 17 years in a country convulsed by a leftist guerrilla insurrection the past three decades. All the rest have been rightist military men. A born-again Protestant, Rios Montt headed a military junta that overthrew President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia, an elected army general, in March 1982. Three months later, he forced out the junta's two other officers and stayed on as president until the military forced him out in August 1983. While in power, he cracked down on crime and the guerrillas. He had more than a dozen suspected rebel leaders summarily executed by firing squad. Until banned under provisions of a constitutional reform enacted by Cerezo, Rios Montt was a frontrunning candidate who advocated a war on crime. He was the nominee of a three-party rightist coalition. Public opinion polls indicated he appealed most to middle-class people fed up with a crime wave that has been sweeping Guatemala the past three years. Efforts to negotiate an end to the leftist insurrection plan have failed so far. Human rights organizations estimate more than 100,000 people have been killed since the early 1960s. Rebel leaders say they back none of the 12 presidential candidates, but are meeting in Mexico with representatives of Guatemalan political parties, labor unions and other popular groups.

DOC.HEAD: Six Student Protestors Slain in Chandigarh
DOC.TEXT: Assailants in a car shot to death six students on a protest fast and left another person dead and 14 injured when they sped away in a blaze of gunfire, police said Monday. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said the gunmen were suspected Sikh extremists fighting for a separate state in the northern Punjab. The killings occurred in a downtown market in the state capital of Chandigarh. The victims were among a group of upper-caste students sitting under a tent on a hunger strike to protest federal job quotas that reserve half of 18 million government jobs for low-castes. The spokesman said the students were all 17 or younger. The seventh victim was a street vendor who died when the gunmen fired at onlookers while fleeing, he said. Six of the injured were reported in serious condition. Immediately after the shooting, a mob set fire to two government-owned buses and hurled stones at a police vehicle. Curfew was imposed and the army arrived to assist police, United News of India news agency said. Thousands of students across northern India have been protesting the job quotas announced Aug. 7 by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. At least 67 students have committed suicide in protest and another 67 have died in street clashes with police. Student groups in Punjab were reported to have rejected offers for help by Sikh extremists. Earlier Monday, Sikh extremists lured a government patrol down an isolated road and detonated a land mine that killed four police officers and wounded 10 others, authorities said. The three-jeep patrol was headed to Vadalakan village to investigate a reported shooting attack by militants on a police post. The village is 100 miles east of Chandigarh. No one was injured in the shooting attack on the police post, police said. Press Trust of India said nine other people were killed in Sikh militant violence in the state Monday. It did not give details. Sikh militants have killed at least 2,439 people this year. The separatist revolt started in 1983 with Sikh militants accusing India's Hindu-dominated government of economic and political discrimination. Sikhs hold a slim majority over Hindus in Punjab, but account for only 2 percent of India's 880 million people while Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Inspector, Boss Suspended in French Wiretap Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The city suspended a finance inspector and his boss for illegally wiretapping municipal officials during investigations into alleged fraud, officials announced Monday. Assistant Mayor Jean Tiberi said the pair had been removed from their workplaces following an internal probe sparked by a newspaper report of the illegal wiretaps. The weekly Le Canard Enchaine reported last week that wiretaps had been conducted by Paris' General Inspection department without required court authorization. Mayor Jacques Chirac ordered an immediate investigation into the department, which is assigned to police against financial irregularities in the city government. Tiberi reported the wiretaps stemmed from ``individual initiative'' during a probe into alleged fraud into the city department dealing with the restaurant industry. The squad investigating the wiretaps found a tiny transmitter the size of a matchbox in the telephone of Maurice Guilmault, chief of the restaurant department, Tiberi said. The agent, Hubert Rosenzweig, and his superior, Guy Legris, who was apparently unaware of the operation, have been suspended from their duties, Tiberi said. No other wiretaps appear to have been planted, Tiberi said. Tiberi added that the probe into the restaurant department would continue and that an official report will be made public. The case follows two other recent wiretapping controversies. In one, the chief executive and several employees of the Century surveillance company were charged with illegal wiretapping. In the other, questions have been raised about police wiretaps of a maverick pastor, Joseph Douce, who has been missing since July. He was under surveillance by officers suspicious of his associations with homosexuals. The national government is considering possible changes in its wiretapping law. The existing law, requiring a judge's consent, is believed to be widely defied, both by government agencies and private firms.

DOC.HEAD: American Woman Tourist Jailed for 3{ Years on Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: A female U.S. microbiologist was sentenced to 3{ years in prison Monday for attempting to smuggle four pounds of heroin strapped to the inside of her thigh out of Cyprus. The 41-year-old woman from New York, identified only as Ms. Landau, was arrested at Larnaca airport in southern Cyprus on June 6 just before boarding a flight for New York. A body search revealed she had a bag of heroin strapped to the inside of her leg, officials said before sentencing. Defense Attorney Nicos Clerides told the court Ms. Landau was forced to carry the heroin by her Lebanese boyfriend ``who hit her and threatened to kill her'' when she initially refused.

DOC.HEAD: Homeowners Urged to Buy a Reversing Door
DOC.TEXT: At least 46 children have died over the last eight years when they were struck by closing automatic garage doors, government safety experts said Monday. They urged homeowners to replace doors without automatic reverse. The children were killed when garage doors did not reverse automatically, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. The agency urged homeowners to help save children's lives by checking garage door openers and to have them repaired or replaced immediately if they fail to reverse after striking an object. Many garage-door units manufactured before 1982 do not have automatic reverse. ``Some older door openers are euipped with a device that only stops the closing door and does not reverse it when it strikes an object,'' the commission said. Some of the older doors doors may have a device intended to cause the closing door to reverse but, because of wear, poor maintenance or a bad installation, may not be safe enough to prevent child deaths, the commission said. It said these door-closing devices cannot be adjusted or repaired to provide the safety available in garage door openers produced in 1982 and after. Homeowners concerned about their doors can safety by placing a two-inch wooden block in the path of the door, the commission said. ``If the door does not promptly reverse on striking the block, the unit should be disengaged and a service technician called to see if repairs are needed,'' it added It said the old garage door should be replaced if it does not have a working automatic reverse. The commission advised that additional safeguards now are available to protect children. It said closing units made after 1982 can be improved with an ``electric eye'' near the floor to reverse a closing garage door automatically whenever an object crosses the path of the door. It also advised homeowners to relocate wall switches out of the reach of young children and to keep remote control units in the glove compartment of the car.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Al-Assaad Appointed as New Arab League Chief
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League on Monday formally appointed Assaad el-Assaad of Lebanon as secretary general, a post he has filled since Chedli Klibi quit last month amid criticism of his handling of the gulf crisis. The appointment is for two years. Sources close to the 21-member League said the Council of Ministers named Ahmed Adel Ismail of Egypt, Adnane Omrane of Syria and Mongi Fakih of Tunisia as assistant secretaries general. The sources did not say how the League members voted. Under Article 12 of the League's constitution, a two-thirds majority is required for appointments. The council was meeting in the Tunisian capital to discuss the transfer of the League headquarters to Cairo and the financial compensation of employees who cannot make the move. The sources said Iraq opposed the move. Egypt is one of the main countries opposing it in the Persian Gulf conflict. The five-nation Union of Arab Maghreb including Algeria, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco and Tunisia has asked that the move be postponed from the scheduled move Oct. 31. Transfer to Cairo, approved earlier this year, turned into a bone of contention with the onset of the gulf crisis, which has seen the group split into pro- and anti-Iraqi camps. El-Assaad, 70, the doyen of the former secretary-general's assistants, has been running the League's executive and administrative functions since Klibi resigned on Sept. 3. Klibi, a Tunisian, had come under severe criticism for his inability to prevent a fracture in the League over the crisis. His government has aligned itself with Iraq and opposed the relocation. Tunisia boycotted the League meeting in Cairo on Sept. 10 where a majority of countries endorsed the sending of foreign troops to the gulf to counter Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. Klibi had been secretary general of the League since it moved from Cairo to Tunis in 1979. He was reappointed to a five-year term in March.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Sentenced to Death, 3 to Life Imprisonment at Public Rally
DOC.TEXT: Twelve people were sentenced to death and three to life imprisonment at a public rally in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, an official report said. The Intermediate People's Court of Urumqi, the regional capital, publicly sentenced the criminals on Sept. 13, the Xinjiang Daily reported in its Sept. 16 edition, seen in Beijing on Monday. The report gave details of only four of the criminals. On July 23, Zhou Xinxu, Zhou Xijian and Ahbulaiti, from one of China's ethnic minority groups, charged into the home of the Chai family, tied them up and demanded money. The Chai's 11-year-old son began crying, and Ahbulaiti shot him in the chest with a stolen submachine gun, wounding the boy's mother and uncle, the paper said. In another incident, Yumiti-Yibulayin, also a minority, was already serving a seven-year prison term when he ordered a cellmate to attack a newcomer to their cell. Zhang Weimin was so badly beaten that he went into shock from loss of blood and his heart stopped. He was sent to hospital but doctors were unable to save him, the report said. The four were sentenced to death along with eight others that the report did not give details about. It said the court ordered them to be immediately executed. Executions in China are by a single bullet to the back of the head. Three others were sentenced to life in prison and four to jail terms of 3-15 years, the paper said without giving details of their crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Gibbs Looks for More Scoring from Redskin Drives
DOC.TEXT: Coach Joe Gibbs wouldn't mind trading some of the long drives the Washington Redskins have gotten so good at for a few more points on the scoreboard. The Redskins 13-7 victory over Philadelphia on Sunday highlighted the nagging trouble Washington has had getting the ball in the end zone this season. ``If you put teams on the 20 every week, they're going to have a tough time getting it in against anybody,'' Gibbs said Monday. The Eagles ``had a hard time getting it in against us and we had a tough time against them. ``That's what happens when you don't score from outside on long plays,'' he said. ``We hurt ourselves in scoring opportunities because we had some key third down shots down around the 30 that hurt us,'' Gibbs said. ``We missed a blitz read and dropped two balls in there that cost us big plays.'' The Redskins moved deep into Philadelphia territory on their first six possessions in Sunday's game, but they stalled on all but one of the drives and had just a 7-0 lead to show for the effort. Their first two drives got to the Eagles' 31. But Earnest Byner lost two on a 3rd-and-1 play on the first possession and quarterback Stan Humphries tossed a pass into the hands of safety Wes Hopkins, who dropped it, on 3rd-and-3 the next time and the Redskins got no points. Finishing drives has been one of their problems in close games this year. Throw out their 38-10 rout of the Cardinals' porous defense, and the Redskins had scored three touchdowns the eight times they have gotten inside the 20. Their lone TD Sunday, a 1-yard plunge by Gerald Riggs, was set up by a big play - Art Monk's diving reception inside the 1 for a 44-yard gain. ``Normally against Philadelphia you expect to hit a couple of big plays. We just hit one,'' Gibbs said. Their lack of a finishing touch was magnified against the Eagles by four missed field goals by Chip Lohmiller. The kicker is now 10 of 12 on attempts inside the 40 and 2 of 7 from beyond the 40. Humphries drove the Redskins back to within sight of the goal posts in the fourth quarter and Lohmiller connected from 33 and 39 yards for the final winning margin. ``We do not want to do something stupid like turn the ball over'' near the end zone, Gibbs said. ``We're getting our shots. When you miss field goals, it hurts you dramatically against good football teams.'' The offense has had to adjust to a second quarterback after Mark Rypien went down with a knee injury in the third week. Humphries' three starts since then are his first in the NFL. Humphries was 14-of-31 for 200 yards against Philadelphia and has thrown two TDs in his three starts. ``Stan made some very good plays,'' Gibbs said. ``There were also several times there when he got balls in their hands. There's good news and bad news there. There were three balls we could have gotten in trouble with.'' Meanwhile, defensive end Markus Koch's sprained left knee was examined by doctors on Monday and coaches said it was doubtful he would be able to play against the New York Giants this Sunday. Gibbs said he would decide later this week whether to place Koch on injured reserve, which would idle him for at least four weeks. Koch's spot on the roster would likely be taken by defensive tackle Jumpy Geathers, who has recovered from major knee surgery and is ready to be activated.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon's President Works To Disband Militias, Free Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Lebanese blast at France, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1,2
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's government worked on plans Monday to disarm gunmen in Christian and Moslem militias who are involved in the 15{-year-old civil war, and to gain the release of Western hostages held by Moslem extremists. Prime Minister Salim Hoss branded as ``interference in Lebanon's domestic affairs'' a French request that the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council convene to discuss the Lebanese conflicts. He said he communicated this official position to the five permanent members - France, the United States, the Soviet Union, China and Britain. France's request was announced Monday by French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. France considers itself the protector of Lebanon's Christians, who supported France's mandate from 1920-43 in Lebanon. Dumas said the assassination of Christian leader Dany Chamoun with his wife and two small sons at their home east of Beirut on Sunday ``shows the extent of the horrors'' of Lebanon's civil strife. Leaders of France's right-wing opposition have held Syria reponsible for the killings that followed the ending of Gen. Michel Aoun's mutiny on Oct. 13. Aoun, who operated from an enclave in the Christian heartland, has taken refuge in the French Embassy after being driven out by Hrawi's troops and the Syrian army. ``The only issue Lebanon wants the Security Council to discuss is Israel's occupation of the border enclave in south Lebanon and the implementation of Resolution 425 calling on Israel to withdraw,'' Hoss said. ``We are in the process to preparing a demand for the application of U.N. sanctions against Israel for refusing to pull out.'' Hoss issued his statement after returning from daylong talks in Damascus with Syrian leaders to speed up reunification of Beirut now that Aoun, the major foe of an Arab League-brokered peace plan, has been removed. A Hrawi aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the president himself returned from the Syrian capital Sunday night with plans to disband the militias and gain the hostages' release. Hours before, gunmen had killed Chamoun, younger son of the late President Camille Chamoun, and his family. The Christian area staged a daylong strike Monday to protest the slayings. Chamoun was a key supporter of Aoun. Aoun had opposed the peace pact because it did not guarantee complete withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops, in Lebanon since 1976. In New York, the Council of Lebanese-American Organizations asked the Security Council to convene an emergency session to move a battalion of U.N. peackeeping forces from southern Lebanon to Christian areas to halt purported violence by Syrians and militias. The Hrawi aide said ``filling the security vacuum'' in areas formerly held by Aoun is the government's No. 1 priority. The official Syrian Arab News Agency reported Monday the Lebanese army will now assume security tasks in Aoun's former areas. Pro-Syrian groups blamed the Chamoun killings on Christian warlord Samir Geagea, whose Lebanese Forces militia fought unsuccessfully with Aoun's troops for mastery of the Christian heartland this year. Geagea denied involvement. He joined other Christian and Moslem leaders in urging Hrawi's government to bring peace to the area that had been controlled by Aoun's forces. Hrawi told Syria's state television network over the weekend that ``all militias will be disbanded by peaceful means, but we'll use other means if we face objections. I warn everybody that no opposition by the gun or the cannon will be tolerated.'' A dozen major militias are blamed for most of the 150,000 deaths in the civil war. The Hrawi aide said among the areas to be cleared of fighters are the south Beirut slums, stronghold of the fundamentalist Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is the umbrella for pro-Iranian extremists holding most of the 13 missing Westerners, including six Americans. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Hrawi's aide said the Syrians will discuss plans to move into the slums with Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati when he visits Damascus later this week. ``This will definitely include the fate of the Western hostages, whether they're held in the slums or have been smuggled out to the Bekaa Valley,'' a Syrian-controlled area in eastern Lebanon, the aide added. ``There's a Syrian-Lebanese understanding that the hostage issue should be resolved in parallel with the creation of a greater Beirut.''

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Kennedy Center Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation Monday authorizing up to $47 million for maintenance, repairs and alterations at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts over the next two years. It would allow more than $30 million to be spent in the current fiscal year and the year following for deferred maintenance and repairs at the arts center on the Potomac. It also authorizes $6.75 million this year and $9.9 million next year for annual maintenance, repairs and other costs. The measure passed both houses by voice vote.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaits Asks Civil Aviation for Return of Planes Taken by Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait on Monday appealed to the International Civil Aviation Organization to condemn Iraq for stealing 15 of its aircraft and registering them as part of the Iraqi Airways fleet. ``On the morning of Aug. 2, Iraqi warplanes bombed the Kuwait International Airport where 18 aircraft were on the ground,'' Sheik Jaber Mubarak Al-Sabah, head of Kuwait's Civil Aviation Authority, told a news conference here. ``Iraq unlawfully seized aircraft owned by Kuwait, Lebanon, Morocco and the United Kingdom. Aviation equipment - essential to the operations of an international airport - were systematically dismantled. ``And you may find it hard to believe, but even the immigration counters in the terminal have been stolen and taken to Iraq.'' The head of Iraq's delegation to ICAO, Tariq Salbi, refused Monday to comments on the charges. Al-Sabah said among the 15 Kuwaiti aircraft taken were five Airbus 310s and three Airbus 300-600s - all multimillion-dollar widebodied jets made by a British-French consortium. Kuwait has eight aircraft now flying out of Cairo while the country is occupied by Iraq. The 162-member organization, which is concerned with airline safety and security, took up the matter in a session Monday when Kuwait asked for the group to consider its resolution. The only dissenting voice was Iraq. Eight nations abstained. Following 10 resolutions imposing an economic embargo on Iraq, passed last month by the U.N. Security Council in New York, Kuwait's resolution asked ICAO delegates to: -Condemn Iraq for violating Kuwaiti airspace; -Declare the registration of Kuwait's planes as part of the Iraqi fleet to be null and void; -Demand all states that may find the stolen aircraft on their soil turn them over to the Kuwaiti authorities; -Request all states refrain from supplying Iraq with any spare parts, equipment, supplies or services for the stolen aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ship: What Cargo?
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi vessel apparently dumped its cargo overboard rather than have it seized under U.N.-approved economic sanctions, U.S. military officials said Monday. Following a 48-hour chase that included three rounds of warning shots, sailors who boarded the vessel al-Bahar al-Arabi in the Gulf of Oman on Monday found ``no prohibited cargo,'' a Navy spokesman said. On Saturday in the Persian Gulf, crews from the destroyer USS O'Brien reported the 5,700-ton Iraqi ship was carrying steel pipe and plywood, which are blocked by the embargo. ``We don't know what happened to it, and can only assume that it was dumped overboard sometime between the first boarding and the second boarding,'' said Cmdr. J.D. van Sickle, a Navy spokesman. After the second inspection, the ship was allowed to continue, he said. The ship's captain, who was not identified, originally said his destination was Aden, Yemen, at the southern tip of the Arabian peninsula. Yemen is among a handful of countries supporting Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The embargo, imposed two weeks after the invasion, cover trade from Iraq and en route to the nation. The slow-moving vessel was first intercepted as it sailed southward toward the Strait of Hormuz, linking the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. The ship's master agreed to return to Iraq after the piping and plywood was discovered, but the vessel resumed its course when the boarding party left, the Navy spokesman said. The vessel refused orders to stop, and the destroyer fired three volleys across its bow on Sunday. Van Sickle said the 7,800-ton destroyer fired its 5-inch and 25-millimeter deck guns and .50-caliber machine guns. Shadowed overnight by the Italian frigate Libeccio as it passed through the strait, the Iraqi ship stopped again when challenged in the Gulf of Oman by the American frigate USS Reasoner and the Australian missile frigate HMAS Adelaide, van Sickle said. Fifteen men from the Adelaide and 11 from the Reasoner were dispatched and ``thoroughly searched the ship and found no prohibited cargo,'' van Sickle said. U.S. officers said they did not know the Iraqi captain's reason for defying the order to return to Iraq or divert to another port. ``Maybe it was because he knows what would happen to him if he did go back,'' said one officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Reasoner and Adelaide have been operating in the Gulf of Oman and north Arabian Sea the past month as members of the multinational fleet enforcing the U.N. embargo. About 12 nations have sent ships to the region. According to the U.S. military, more than 2,500 commercial ships have been challenged, 250 boarded and about a dozen diverted on grounds their cargo was Iraq-related. U.S. warships had a role in 191 of the boardings. The British, Australian, Spanish and Greek navies have also participated.

DOC.HEAD: Two Charges Filed Against State Treasurer in Phone Incident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with response from Marsh in 4th graf and DELETE outdated material in 8th graf. Picks up 9th graf, ``I'm glad ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nebraska's state treasurer was charged Monday with theft by deception for allegedly misusing state phones. The felony charge alleges Treasurer Frank Marsh used a state credit card to make more than $300 worth of personal phone calls, said Lancaster County Attorney Mike Heavican. If convicted, Marsh could face up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine. Marsh, a Republican seeking a fourth term, also was charged with a misdemeanor filed jointly by the prosecutor and the state accountability commission, said Heavican. Reached at his home Monday, Marsh said he was unaware of the charges and declined to comment on them or on whether he would resign. The Democratic candidates for auditor and treasurer last month accused Marsh of using state phones for personal calls. The next day, Marsh reimbursed the state $1,663 for calls he said might be in question and authorities began an investigation. ``The voters in Nebraska are due an apology for this mistake in judgment,'' Marsh said then. He said many of the calls were business-related. He said he made monthly estimates of his personal calls and offset the costs by using his own car for state business, purchasing gasoline and stamps with his own money, and buying miscellaneous office supplies. However, he kept no records of such reimbursement. ``I'm glad that they were able to complete part of the investigation before the election,'' said Dawn Rockey, Democratic candidate for treasurer. ``It's important for the voters to understand the gravity of the situation. The voters will decide if the public trust has been violated,'' she said. John Breslow, Democratic candidate for auditor, joined with Ms. Rockey in bringing up the issue, and noted that an audit by Republican Ray A.C. Johnson of the treasurer's office did not find the questionable calls. State Republican Party Chairman Norm Riffel declined comment, as did Gov. Kay Orr and Attorney General Robert Spire, both Republicans. The misdemeanor under the statutes of the state Political Accountability and Disclosure Commission deals ``with a specific phone call made for his own personal gain,'' Heavican said. It is punishable by up to three months in jail and a $500 fine. ``I think it's safe to say there are further investigatory things to be done, but I don't want to speculate further on that,'' Heavican said in response to a question of possible further charges. Marsh, 66, has said that, if re-elected in November, it will be his last term. The former secretary of state and lieutenant governor was first elected treasurer in 1975. He served until 1981 when he resigned to become state director of the Farmers Home Administration, then was elected treasurer again in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's Government Accepts Changes in Draft Constitution
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai on Monday said the government has accepted ``certain changes'' proposed by King Birendra in this kingdom's constitution. But the prime minister refused to say if the concessions included Birendra's key demand that the monarchy share sovereignty with the people and retain emergency powers. The Cabinet has ``acceded to certain changes suggested by the palace, but all other clauses in the draft constitution would be kept intact,'' Bhattarai told reporters before he entered the palace to present the draft constitution. Birendra earlier rejected a draft constitution approved by Bhattarai's Cabinet that seeks to make him a constitutional monarch. Instead, he submitted amendments, prompting Bhattarai to say he would rather resign than accept the king's draft, which he said were against his political and moral beliefs. Asked if he had changed his mind about resigning, Bhattarai said ``not so far,'' indicating the Cabinet's changes did not include Birendra's main demands. The king had bowed to pro-democracy demonstrations and yielded his absolute power last April after a mass people's uprising and a subsequent police crackdown that left at least 200 people dead. ``I am going to the palace to request the king to accept the draft constitution submitted by the government,'' Bhattarai said after a three-hour Cabinet meeting. He refused to elaborate. ``We will inform you when the time comes,'' he said. But Health Minister Mathura Prasad Shrestha described the king's draft as ``illegal,'' saying, ``We will accept only certain changes provided they are not against the fundamental spirit of the constitution.'' Earlier Monday, the palace issued a statement that it had ``no knowledge of the prime minister having any wish to resign.'' It said the king would deal with all issues of national importance with the advice and knowledge of the prime minister. The official Gorkhapatra newspaper repoted Monday that Bhattarai has informed the king's chief secretary, Rebati Raman Khanal, that he could not have the king's draft approved by the Cabinet or by his Nepali Congress Party. Therefore, it had no chance of being accepted by the people. Birendra's amended draft would reserve the king's right to exercise emergency powers in case of threat to the country's sovereignty, economic distress, failure of the constitutional organs or external threats to the country. ``This is a serious point under which the king can stage a comeback under the smallest pretext,'' said a Nepali Congress party official who did not want to be further identified. Party General Secretary Girija Prasad Koirala said ``the king should fulfil his historic responsibility by promulgating the constitution before the people waiting for a democratic constitution lose their patience.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC Recommends Mandela-Buthelezi Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress recommended Monday that Nelson Mandela meet rival black leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a breakthrough that could help ease the violence in black townships. The ANC proposed a meeting between itself and Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha Freedom Party ``in the near future,'' but did not specify a date. The ANC statement said both Mandela and Buthelezi should attend. Buthelezi said he welcomed the offer and was ready to consider a suitable time and place for the talks. Mandela is in Australia and will be traveling throughout Asia until early November. Since his release from prison in February, Mandela has turned down invitations from his old friend Buthelezi despite the ongoing violence between their supporters in the eastern province of Natal and in black areas outside Johannesburg. ANC leaders have harshly briticized Buthelezi and accused him of orchestrating the violence to obtain a meeting with Mandela and enhance his stature. Buthelezi has denied the charge and accused the ANC of trying to destroy all rivals. The ANC was conciliatory in its statement Monday. The group said ``it welcomed the steps being taken jointly by the ANC and the Inkatha Freedom Party'' to stop the violence. The two sides have been holding periodic peace talks, but neither Mandela nor Buthelezi has attended. About 5,000 blacks have died in the ANC-Inkatha power struggle since 1986 in Natal Province. The fighting spread to the Johannesburg area in August and has claimed 800 lives. The ANC and Inkatha, the two largest black opposition movements, both oppose apartheid but differ over tactics and a future South Africa. The socialist-oriented ANC has employed boycotts, strikes, protests and waged an armed struggle, recently suspended, in its battle against the government. Inkatha does not endorse any of those measures and favors capitalism. The ANC draws support across tribal lines, while virtually all Inkatha members are Zulus. The ANC also has opposed Buthelezi's role as leader of the KwaZulu homeland in Natal Province. The ANC considers the 10 black homelands part of the apartheid system. Buthelezi, meanwhile, sees the limited self-government in the homelands as an interim step on the road to black majority rule.

DOC.HEAD: `Henry & June' Impresses Moviegoers, Critics
With AM-Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``Henry & June,'' the sexually charged film that earned the first NC-17 movie rating, is generating vigorous business at the nation's theaters. ``Henry & June'' has been playing for three weeks in limited release. Last weekend, it grossed $1.2 million in 212 movie houses, Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc. said Monday. That placed it 12th on the box-office charts. To date, the Universal Pictures release has made $4.6 million, a considerable return for a production not aimed at teen-age audiences. ``I'm very pleased,'' said director Philip Kaufman. ``When you make a film, you have hopes there will be an audience for it. ... There are not enough adult movies for people to see.'' The film, a story of a menage a trois that earned the new no-children rating for a lesbian love scene and a shot of an erotic drawing, is based on the diaries of writer Anais Nin. Starring Fred Ward, Uma Thurman and Maria de Medeiros, it was originally rated X. Kaufman said the ratings flap may have helped the film but maintained that wasn't solely responsible for its strong performance. The film is promoted in some advertisements with the line, ``Completely uncut in its original version.'' ``It obviously has good word of mouth and it got some good reviews,'' Kaufman said in a telephone interview from San Francisco. ``We might have had better reviews without the controversy - some people say it isn't sexy enough.'' Kaufman noted that the recent Spanish film ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' originally was given the X rating, too, but didn't perform well at movie theaters. ``So you cannot say the controversy worked for it,'' he said. Kaufman and Universal both felt ``Henry & June'' deserved the less-harsh R rating, rather than the X originally given it by the Motion Picture Association of America. When the MPAA announced Sept. 26 that it would replace the X with NC-17, which excludes children under 17, Kaufman and Universal canceled their appeal of ``Henry & June's'' X rating and accepted the new classification. Many newspapers and hundreds of television and radio stations reject advertisements for movies rated X. Filmmakers said that the X mark was synonymous with hard-core pornography, and the NC-17 was created to resolve that economic impasse. ``Henry & June'' was pulled from one theater in Dedham, Mass., when two civic leaders protested its exhibition to the theater owner. Newspapers in Sacramento and in Birmingham, Ala., have refused to run advertisements for NC-17 rated films.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Ships 19,000 Tons of Wheat To Famine-Threatened Sudan
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. World Food Program on Monday said it had delivered 19,000 tons of wheat to Sudan where severe drought has threatened millions of people with famine. The total food needs in the vast, impoverished nation are not yet known as a full crop assessment will not be completed until the end of November, the Rome-based organization said in a news release. However, the United Nations has said 1 million tons of relief supplies may be needed. As an interim measure, the government of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir has requested 75,000 metric tons of food for emergency distribution to 2.4 million people in northern Sudan. Relief workers in Sudan say the country is facing a situation potentially as bad as a devastating famine that wasted much of the country in the mid-1980s and killed at least 250,000 people. The World Food Program said the wheat at Port Sudan will be used for 800,000 people in the Red Sea province of eastern Sudan, in the western regions of Kordofan and Darfur as well as the country's central El Butana region. It is part of a preliminary emergency allocation of 25,000 metric tons to be supplied for immediate drought relief, WFP said in the release sent by Telex to news organizations in Nairobi.

DOC.HEAD: $52 Billion Farm Bill Includes Half-Million for Welk Home
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf, bgng, ``Among the,'' and 6th graf, bgng, ``It's money,'' to CORRECT spelling to Strasburg sted Strasberg.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Monday to spend $52.2 billion on farming, nutrition and rural development programs, including a half-million dollars to renovate the former home of retired bandleader Lawrence Welk and build nearby tourist accommodations. By voice vote, the House accepted compromises worked out by a House-Senate conference committee on the fiscal 1991 appropriations bill that pays for farm subsidies and most Agriculture Department functions, as well as the Food and Drug Administration. Among the $14.1 billion for rural development projects is $500,000 for Strasburg, N.D., the birthplace of Lawrence Welk. ``That's right `Ah one, ah two, ah three, ah four, ah half a million dollars,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., mimicking the way Welk used to direct his orchestra. The money was included in the bill by the Senate to help revitalize the 700-population community in the south central part of the state. But Conte and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., both conference committee members, went on record as opposing the appropriation before signing the compromise bill. It's money is to be used by Welk Heritage Inc. and the Strasburg Economic Development Corp. to renovate the Welk family home and help build a motel and other facilities to accommodate the tourist trade that is beginning to develop around the bandleader's former residence. Many rural communities where farms have been consolidated over the years, causing a loss of economic base, are looking to the government for help to develop other businesses. About half the money in the bill, $27.6 billion, goes for food programs, including $19 billion for food stamps and $2.5 billion for the Women, Infant and Children program, said Appropriations Committee Chairman Jamie Whitten, D-Miss. Food donations, the special milk program and child nutrition programs also are covered by the bill. The bill appropriates $5 billion for farm subsidies this year and continues the crop insurance program which Whitten had stripped from the original House bill. ``Since 1980 the (crop insurance) program has lost over $2.6 billion in indemnity payments,'' said Whitten. ``Administration in the past 10 years increased over $2 billion, an increase of over 450 percent.'' But, at the urging of the Senate, he agreed to allow the program to continue under certain conditions, including the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service taking control over policy sales and loss adjustments. The service had controlled the program before 1980 when it was expanded to allow private insurance companies to issue policies to farmers. The practice became costly because the private companies were reimbursed by the government for administrative expenses and operating losses. Other specific agencies and their appropriations included: -Farmers Home Administration, $11.5 billion -Rural Electrification Administration, $334.6 million. -Soil Conservation Service, $771.3 million. -Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service, $1.5 billion. -International programs, including food giveaways, $1.1 billion. -Food and Drug Administration, $824 million.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Employee Killed on `Haunted Hayride' Attraction
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who pretended to hang from a gallows as part of a Halloween hayride died while performing the stunt over the weekend. Hayride customers found the body of Brian Jewell, 17, about 8 p.m. Saturday, hanging from the gallows, his feet on the ground. The the stunt had worked other nights and there was no indication of foul play, Prosecutor James W. Holzapfel said. The gallows was being checked for flaws and an autopsy was performed Monday. ``The way it's supposed to work is he's supposed to have the noose around his neck, but it's not a noose that tightens,'' said Holzapfel. Jewell would step down about one foot to the ground, making it appear he had been hanged, Holzapfel said. During the ride, about 40 people sit in a hay-filled wagon drawn by a tractor, which takes them past a number of Halloween fright exhibits. The stunt went off without problems earlier Saturday. But the tractor driver became concerned later that evening when Jewell failed to give the speech he normally did as the wagon passed. Preliminary autopsy results were expected Tuesday, said Lt. Michael R. Murray of the prosecutor's office. Blood tests for drugs would take several weeks, Murray said. The hayride, which had been conducted every night this month, was suspended after the death of Jewell, a junior at Tom's River High School in southern New Jersey. Telephone calls placed to Haunted Hayrides Inc., based outside Syracuse, N.Y., were not immediately returned. An attorney representing the Lakewood Riding Center, where the ride was held, said his client had nothing to do with the Haunted Hayrides operation.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Rebel Writes Letter to President, Gets 60 Days' Arrest
DOC.TEXT: A renegade colonel who led a 1988 barracks revolt was arrested Monday for insubordination because of a letter he wrote to President Carlos Menem. Army chief Gen. Martin Bonnet sentenced former Col. Momahed Ali Seineldin to 60 days at the Fourth Army Corps base in La Pampa, 391 miles southwest of Buenos Aires. ``I can't give details,'' Seineldin said. ``Tonight, I leave for La Pampa.'' The cause of his arrest was a 5-page letter Seineldin delivered Saturday to the presidential compound at Olivos, a Buenos Aires suburb, while Menem was in Europe on a state visit. The letter said ``the state of unrest'' among officers and commissioned troops could lead to ``extremely dangerous'' incidents. But military officials and politicians have discounted the possibility of another revolt like the three that occurred between April 1987 and December 1988, undermining the government of former President Raul Alfonsin, Menem's predecessor. Seineldin's letter instead was considered insubordination. Defense Minister Humberto Romero said Seineldin's statements and arrest ``in no way ... can find an echo in the rest of that armed service.'' Vice President Eduardo Duhalde said, ``It seems that certain sectors would take advantage of the absence of the president to take ... liberties.'' He ordered Bonnet give Seineldin the harshest sanction applicable - 60 days arrest - for an officer who violates the military chain of command. Seineldin, a 56-year-old former commando, led a hard-line group within the army that opposed the trials of fellow officers for human rights abuses committed in the 1976-83 regime's crackdown on alleged leftist subversives. At least 9,000 Argentines disappeared during the military's ``dirty war'' against suspected subversives and are presumed dead. During Seineldin's 4-day uprising in December 1988, he demanded the army budget be increased and top generals replaced. According to Seineldin, then army chief Gen. Jose Caridi agreed to the demands, then reneged. Seineldin said he was prompted to write to Menem because officers who agree with him are being denied promotion, the army budget still is inadequate, and the shake-up in the military hierarchy never took place. ``I consider it a duty to tell the commander-in-chief of the armed forces about something I believe is extremely dangerous for the future of the armed forces and the Argentine nation,'' he said in the letter. Seineldin and cashiered Lt. Col. Aldo Rico, who led the first two uprisings in April 1987 and January 1988, both insist they are soldiers who want to return to uniform. Both have held public meetings and rallies this year in an apparent attempt to mobilize political dissent that stems from chronic economic problems and Menem's plan to sell money-losing state enterprises many Argentines consider the national patrimony. Rico is a minor-party candidate for governor of Buenos Aires Province, the country's most populous, in elections set for November 1991. Spokesmen for Seineldin distributed the Menem letter Saturday to reporters and asked them to cover his probable arrest on Monday.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS top three grafs with two grafs to specify grounds on which Bush acted and objection of other side; picks up 4th graf pvs, now 3rd graf: ``Sen. Edward,''
DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Major Civil Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush vetoed a major civil rights bill Monday and seemed assured of winning a battle in Congress to override him. Bush argued that the bill before him would force employers to adopt hiring quotas, a position disputed by backers of the measure. The president called on lawmakers to enact his version of the measure before they quit for the year, probably later this week. However, that appeared unlikely, as Bush's critics said his proposal would weaken current law. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the chief Senate sponsor, called the veto ``tragic and disgraceful.'' ``When the chips are down, the White House is against civil rights,'' Kennedy said. He urged Congress to override the president. Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, said Bush's veto ``will victimize his presidency forever. He joins Andrew Johnson and Ronald Reagan as the only presidents to veto a civil rights bill.'' The bill was passed by the Senate 62-34 and by the House 273-154 - strong majorities, but not reaching the two-thirds required to override a veto. Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., the prime House sponsor, said he would not even ask for an override vote without the two-thirds needed by supporters. ``I'm just not going to waste any more time,'' Hawkins said, adding that civil rights forces might even lose support in an override fight. In his veto message, Bush said, ``The temptation to support a bill - any bill - simply because its title includes the words `civil rights' is very strong. ``But when our efforts, however well-intentioned, result in quotas, equal opportunity is not advanced but thwarted,'' he said. ``The very commitment to justice and equality that is offered as the reason why this bill should be signed requires me to veto it.'' He said, ``I deeply regret having to take this action with a bill bearing such a title, especially since it contains certain provisions that I strongly endorse.'' The measure would nullify six Supreme Court decisions that have made it more difficult for women and minorities to prove and win job discrimination suits. It would ban racial harassment in the workplace and allow punitive damages in the most serious discrimination cases. Bush said there were many similarities between the bill he vetoed and the version that the administration supports, offered at the last minute to ease the veto. Civil rights advocates denounced the latest version of Bush's bill as a sham for permitting challenged hiring practices to stand if they could be justified on such grounds as ``customer relations,'' justifications they said were used to support the separate-but-equal ``Jim Crow'' laws of the first half of the 20th century that kept blacks in segregation. Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights, called Bush's bill ``a tired rehash of policies considered and rejected by the Congress. ... We have nearly compromised this bill to death.'' Summing up his key argument, Bush said, ``Despite the use of the term `civil rights' in the title ... the bill actually employs a maze of highly legalistic language to introduce the destructive force of quotas into our nation's employment system.'' He said that under Congress' bill, ``employers will be driven to adopt quotas in order to avoid liability.'' Bush said legal experts disagree over how to interpret important sections of the bill. He said that was a sure sign that the vetoed bill would have led ``to years, perhaps decades, of uncertainly and expensive litigation.'' Ron Brown, Democratic national chairman, said: ``The issue for the president isn't quotas - it's politics. George Bush got to the White House by pandering to fear ... Today he chose Willie Horton over Abraham Lincoln.'' Horton was the convicted murderer featured prominently in Bush campaign ads in 1988. In a last-minute appeal, black activist Dick Gregory marched in front of the White House on Monday carrying a sign that read: ``Mr. President, before you veto the civil rights bill, please think about the number of black African Americans you have sent to the Persian Gulf willing to die for someone else's human rights.'' The president's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said earlier he believed Congress could not override the veto. ``There are a lot of members of Congress who believe, as we do, that there can be a better bill,'' Fitzwater said. ``I think everybody wants a good civil rights bill.'' Despite the odds favoring Bush, Neas predicted a close override vote and said civil rights advocates would push through a bill early next year if they lose this time. ``It's only a matter of time,'' he said. ``The question is not if there's going to be a civil rights act, but when.'' Arthur Fletcher, head of the Civil Rights Commission, said the panel disagreed with Bush's stand. Tensions between the White House and civil rights supporters were reflected in the sharp language used by Fitzwater against Bush's critics. ``I think they are being unfair,'' Fitzwater said. ``A lot of them don't understand the legal implications of the bill.'' Fitzwater said the veto would not undermine Bush's campaign to improve his standing among blacks. ``I think they (blacks) understand that we want a good civil rights bill and they don't want a quota bill, either,'' he said. Fitzwater said Bush's bill was very similar to the measure adopted by Congress. ``The only difference is that our bill does not include the language that we believe has the effect of forcing quotas,'' he said. A key dispute has been language that would help those filing discrimination suits and make it more difficult for employers to defend themselves. Bush says those provisions are so stringent that companies would adopt quotas to have a ready-made defense - an argument sponsors dispute. Under the Supreme Court decisions at issue, a plaintiff had to prove that the hiring practices in dispute were not the result of business necessity. The bill would shift that burden of proof to the defendant employer. The White House plan would cap at $150,000 the total damages an employee could win in a job discrimination suit. As passed, the bill would allow unlimited compensatory damages in some cases and cap punitive damages at $150,000 or the total of compensatory damages plus back pay, whichever is greater. The White House previously had insisted on a $100,000 cap. The administration proposal also would allow those filing suit to press their cases if employers could not explain their hiring methods in legal terms.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Refuse to Decide Conrail-D&H Trackage Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3rd graf: ``Conrail immediately,'' Conail demands arbitration
DOC.TEXT: A special court refused Monday to decide whether the Delaware & Hudson Railway has the right to run its own trains on a short stretch of Conrail tracks between Buffalo and Niagara Falls, N.Y. ``The judges denied Conrail's petition,'' said Richard Eriksen, clerk of the court. ``They will explain their reasons when they issue their memorandum or opinion.'' Conrail immediately served the D&H trustee with a demand for binding prbitration, said Laurence Z. Shiekman, a lawyer for Conrail. He said Conrail would also assignment of trackage rights by a bankruptcy court next month. The decision came only hours after lawyers for Conrail argued that the special regional rail reorganization court has jurisdiction because the issue dates to 1976 when the federal government formed Conrail. The special court decides any cases arising out of that reorganization. But a lawyer for the D&H's bankruptcy trustee said the case should be decided in bankruptcy court because the trackage rights were conferred in a separate 1979 agreement. The approximately 15-mile stretch is key to a $25 million offer by Canadian Pacific Ltd. to buy the ailing D&H. Without access to the Buffalo-Niagara Gateway, CP would be unable to connect the D&H with its own lines in southern Ontario. Canadian Pacific wants the D&H system to connect Philadelphia and New York with the Canadian interior. If CP can put all the pieces together, it would compete directly with Conrail for freight in the Northeast. The Canadian company has been operating the D&H since August under an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission. Charles H. White Jr., lawyer for the bankruptcy trustee, pointed out that Conrail chose not to object to the D&H takeover in bankruptcy court or before the Interstate Commerce Commission. ``It is ironically using its own statutory court to throw grave doubt on the reorganization of its competitor,'' White said. ``I think we can see through the thin jurisdictional arguments exactly what's happening here.'' Chief Judge John Minor Wisdom called the case troubling, and asked both sides why they had never submitted the question to binding arbitration, as required by both the 1976 and 1979 agreements. Neither side had a clear answer. The D&H, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, filed in July 1988 for protection from its creditors under U.S. bankruptcy laws. The railroad, which runs from Montreal to Washington and between Albany and Buffalo, owes more than $100 million. This is the second time that Conrail has thrown up a roadblock in CP's effort to buy the D&H. Earlier this year, Conrail refused to negotiate the rights to its tracks between Hagerstown, Md., and Harrisburg, Pa. This led CP to withdraw its initial $35 million bid for the D&H.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Communists Become Legal Again After 17 Years
DOC.TEXT: Chile's Communist Party on Monday emerged from 17 years of repression and became legal again. The party, once one of the largest in the Western Hemisphere, now is badly split and weakened. Party members joyfully paraded through the streets of downtown Santiago as Secretary-General Volodia Teitelboim delivered 61,400 supporting signatures to the Election Board, a requirement for a political party's legal recognition. But the party faces the gravest crisis in its 68 years of existence. Leading members have resigned, unhappy with an old-guard leadership that they said failed to accept democratic changes. For many years, Chilean Communists were staunchly pro-Moscow, but local leaders did not go along as changes effected in the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev spread through the world Communist movement. Central Committee member Luis Gustavino was expelled after he publicly attacked the party's ``lack of internal democracy.'' Prominent members resigned, as did about 200 members of the youth branch. ``We have again a legal Communist Party in Chile,'' Telteiboim said. ``It was not easy, as the party lived for 17 years under ferocious repression.'' Under the 16{-year military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, which ended in March, scores of party leaders were killed, arrested or sent into exile. The party was outlawed. Other leftist parties received similar treatment. Under Pinochet's successor, President Patricio Aylwin, restrictions have been lifted. The Communist Party was a major member in the six-party coalition supporting the leftist government of President Salvador Allende, who died when Pinochet toppled his administration in a bloody 1973 coup. The Communists were especially strong among workers and attracted up to 16 percent of the vote in national elections. In last December's congressional elections, the party failed to elect one senator or congressman. Its total vote was estimated at 2.5 percent. Teitelboim on Monday described the crisis within the party as ``a process of deep renovation.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Orders Use of Island Stopped
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday ordered the Pentagon to stop using the Hawaiian island of Kaho'olawe as a weapons range and to open talks with the state about the future of the area. The directive was sent to Defense Secretary Richard Cheney just four days before Bush arrives in Hawaii for a two-night visit. Bush's order did not offer any explanation for his decision. ``This directive extends to use of the island for small arms, artillery, naval gunfire support and aerial ordnance training,'' Bush said. He instructed Cheney to establish a joint commission with Hawaii to examine the status of Kaho'olawe and related issues.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Pays $40 Million Toward U.N. Back Dues.
DOC.TEXT: The United States has paid $40 million toward its delinquent U.N. dues of $521.9 million, giving the world body enough cash to keep operating though November, officials said Monday. The payment was made Friday, but not announced until now. It reduces U.S. arrears to $481.9 million - about 80 percent of the arrears owed by all 159 member nations. America also owes more than $160 million to various peacekeeping operations, which come under separate budgets.
