The United States began withholding large portions of its U.N. dues in 1985, under President Reagan, to protest what it said was the organization's anti-Western bias, inefficiency and budget overruns. Reagan said in September 1988 he was pleased with the world body's progress toward budget reform, trimming its staff, and its new spirit of consensus and cooperation. He left details of paying the arrears to his successor, President Bush. The administration has proposed a plan for full funding of annual U.N. dues assessments and a repayment schedule in which about one-fifth of the arrears would be paid each year for five years.

DOC.HEAD: Staff, Residents End Two-Day Eviction at Nursing Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with standoff ending. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nursing home staffers and 33 residents agreed to end a two-day standoff Monday and comply with a corporate eviction notice that had already sent residents at two other Florida nursing homes packing. ``I would have done it if I could, as well as every staff member here,'' said acting administrator Kandi Kelly, praising staffers who continued to provide care even though their employer said they would not be paid. ``We've given our heart and soul, but there's nothing I can do,'' she said. Meanwhile, state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services officials were investigating evictions at all three facilities to determine whether residents were given the proper seven days' notice. Residents of three Village Green Centers - in Winter Haven, New Port Richey and Tallahassee - were given a day's notice to move Friday, when the manager, Universal Equities Inc., ordered the homes closed because of financial problems. While residents of the other homes complied over the weekend, administrators, staffers, relatives and 33 residents of the Winter Haven home banded together to keep Universal Equities executives off the property. Guards were posted outside the home's door. Ms. Kelly said she had been trying to find a ``white knight'' buyer for the home to prevent residents from moving. But with the fight over, she said new housing arrangements would be made for the residents. On the advice of attorneys, Ms. Kelly said she had no choice but to comply with the eviction demand. Village Green Inc. of Winter Haven filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, said attorney Thomas Woodward, who represents the company. The company is involved in litigation with First Federal Florida Savings of Osceola, which is foreclosing on the Village Green property, Woodward said. Village Green corporate officials did not immediately return telephone calls Monday from The Associated Press. Administrators at the nursing home fielded hundreds of offers of food and volunteer help, and residents passed the time inside watching television. ``I'm shocked at all this, I really am,'' said resident Edna Boddicker. ``I can't believe it.'' ``Their life is in an uproar,'' said Robin Marshall, a certified nursing assistant at the home. ``I don't think it's right to put these old people out. It's time the public take a look at what's going on with the elderly.'' Connie Cheren, HRS' director of licensure and certification, said residents at all three homes will be questioned to determine whether they were given the seven days notice required by law. She also said HRS attorneys will ask a Polk circuit judge to appoint a temporary receiver to supervise the Winter Haven eviction to ensure residents are given seven days to move out.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Tries to Avoid U.S. Veto on Israel Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council met on Monday trying to avert a U.S. veto of a resolution that would demand Israel cooperate with a U.N. team investigating the killing of 19 Palestinians on Temple Mount in Jerusalem. America, which often shields Israel with its veto, seeks a nonbinding consensus statement to be issued by the council president, expressing regret at Israel's refusal to cooperate with a U.N. probe and urging it to reconsider. Informal consultations were suspended Monday night until Tuesday. Israel has rejected any U.N. probe as an infringement on its sovereignty. The United States has sought to avoid using its veto power, as one of the five permanent council members empowered to kill any measure. The killing of three Jews by an Arab in an apparent revenge slaying Sunday appeared to complicate the situation and call for a broader resolution that also would implicate the Palestinians in violence. The council already has unanimously condemned the actions of Israeli security forces in killing 19 Palestinians two weeks ago. Members were seeking to preserve the unity of the 15-member council. The United States, Britain and other Western nations want to return the focus of the council and the international spotlight to the issue of Iraq's aggression against Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Briton Held in Iraq Dies of Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: A 62-year-old British engineer held hostage by Iraqi authorities has died of a heart attack, the Foreign Office and his family said Monday. ``We know nothing more than the fact that he died and that a doctor was with him at the time,'' said Ronald Duffy's widow, Christine. ``I'm terribly shocked.'' Duffy worked for a British company, Merz and McLellan, in Kuwait when Iraq invaded Aug. 2. A Foreign Office spokesman said the Iraqi Foreign Ministry reported Duffy's death to the British Embassy in Baghdad on Sunday, but did not say where he died. Duffy, who had no history of heart trouble, worked for the company for 26 years, mostly on foreign postings. His widow said she received a letter from him two weeks ago saying he was well. He was among hundreds of Britons held at various facilities in Iraq as part of President Saddam Hussein's policy of using Western hostages to deter an attack, British officials said. Earlier Monday, the Foreign Office said Iraqi troops in Kuwait have rounded up seven more Britons and are holding them at the Regency Hotel in Kuwait City to await transfer to Iraq. ``It is illegal and deplorable, like all the others (detained),'' said a spokesman, who requested anonymity. He said the men rounded up were ``almost certainly in hiding,'' but there were no details of how they were caught. The Foreign Office said there were 650 Britons left in Kuwait, most in hiding, and about 800 Britons trapped in Iraq, including 340 being held at strategic locations. Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath said Saddam promised on Sunday to release an unspecified number of sick or elderly Britons. An aircraft from British-based Virgin Atlantic airline is scheduled to fly to the Iraqi capital of Baghdad on Tuesday for Heath and to possibly return freed hostages. Duffy was the third Briton to die in Iraq or Kuwait since the invasion. A Scottish scientist, William Norrie Atack, 46, died in Kuwait this month. A 45-year-old businessman, Douglas Thomas Croskery, was shot to death in August while trying to escape from Kuwait. Three members of the Irish parliament were granted Iraqi visas Monday for a November trip to Baghdad to plead for the release of nationals trapped by the gulf crisis. The legislators are expected to meet Iraqi government officials, but it was not known whether they would talk directly with Saddam. Ireland's Gulf Relatives Support Committee asked the legislators to make the trip, which is not formally sanctioned by the Irish government.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Noriega Gunmen Hold Up Passenger Bus in Panama
DOC.TEXT: Five gunmen held up a bus in southwestern Panama, stripped the passengers of their belongings and spray-painted the vehicle with the initials of a little-known pro-Noriega group, police said Monday. None of the 27 people aboard the bus were hurt in Sunday's holdup, said a police official in Nata, 105 miles southwest of Panama City. Police said they found the bus on a mountain road near Nata, spray-painted with the initials M-20. M-20 is the acronym for the December 20 Movement, made up of loyalists to deposed dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. It takes its name from the date last year when the United States invaded Panama to remove Noriega, who is in Miami facing trial in federal court on drug trafficking charges.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Leader Seeks Peaceful End to Battle Over Religious Site
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh on Monday appealed for a peaceful resolution to a religious site dispute that has caused violent Hindu-Moslem clashes and could threaten the Singh's coalition government. ``Religious fanaticism is the first step towards the foundation for a theocratic state. It will be the death of India as a secular state,'' Singh said during a 20-minute televised speech. At least 80 people have died this year in battles over a 16th century mosque, the Babri Masjid, in Ayodhya, about 310 miles east of New Delhi. Hindus believe the town was the birthplace of a god, Rama, and want to dismantle the mosque, claiming it was built by Mogul rulers on the foundations of an ancient Hindu temple. The Hindu World Council has vowed to start rebuilding the temple Oct. 30, but a Moslem group had said it will protect the mosque. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems account for 12 percent. Singh said he has appointed five state chief ministers to help ``solve the issue.'' Chief ministers are the highest elected officials of a state. He also asked the Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party to work toward a nonviolent solution. There was no immediate reaction from the Bharatiya Janata, or Indian People's Party. Several other political parties and groups have unsuccessfully appealed to the party to call off its campaign. Singh's 10-month-old National Front coalition government needs the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Left Front, a conglomeration of communist groups, to remain intact. The Bharatiya Janata Party has threatened to withdraw support from the government if the proposed temple construction is disrupted. ``How can a country be governed in circumstances like this? Is it necessary that the country has to be plunged into communal chaos? Can't they wait to build the temple until a peaceful settlement has been reached?'' asked Singh, whose Janata Dal party comprises the largest part of the coalition government. ``Hundreds of governments can come and go but the nation should remain one,'' he said. ``Government is too small a consideration when people are involved.'' Clashes between the Moslems and Hindus escalated last month after Bharatiya Janata Party leader Lal Krishna Advani set off on a 6,000-mile van journey from a west Indian Hindu shrine to Ayodhya. Advani is scheduled to reach Ayodhya on Oct. 30. Authorities in Uttar Pradesh state have said they may arrest Advani when he crosses the state border. Fearing unrest, police already have detained more than 20,000 Hindu activists. Many road and rail links to Ayodhya have been blocked or subject to stringent checks.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leader Voted Out of Czechoslovak Parliament Presidium
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party chairman Vasil Mohorita on Monday was voted out of the Presidium, the highest parliamentary body, by legislators in the lower house, the state news agency CTK reported. The agency gave no reason for the ouster, but Mohorita's recent attack on planned government reforms stirred anti-Communist protests around the country. The reforms are aimed at dismantling structures left by four decades of Communist Party rule and introducing a market economy. Legislators in the House of the People, the lower chamber of the 300-seat, two-house national assembly, voted 117-86 to replace Mohorita, CTK said. Although no longer one of the 40 members of the Presidium, he will remain a deputy in the lower house. The Presidium, made up of deputies from both houses, can pass legislation when Parliament is not in session. In a speech published two weeks ago, Mohirita said high unemployment and inflation, probable side-effects of reforms, were unacceptable and urged ``a hard and uncompromising struggle.'' Also on Monday, President Vaclav Havel renewed his call for abolition of the Warsaw Pact as an ``outdated tool of Stalinist expansion.'' He said over state radio that Czechoslovakia would reiterate its proposal to abolish the pact's joint military command at a summit meeting of the military alliance in Budapest Nov. 3-4. The summit is to determine the future of the Warsaw Pact, formed in 1955 as the Soviet bloc's answer to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. In a bid to reform Czechoslovakia's army and break from its Communist past, Havel last week dismissed Defense Minister Gen. Miroslav Vacek and appointed a civilian, Lubos Dobrovsky in his place. CTK also reported that Miroslav Stepan, former Communist Party chief in Prague, was sentenced Monday to 2{ years in prison for abuse of power after appealing a four-year sentence. He was convicted of ordering the use of water cannon and tear gas against demonstrators on Oct. 28, 1988. The appeals court ruled his guilt in ordering the use of force in January 1989 against anti-Communist demonstrators in Prague could not be established. Stepan was a hard-liner against dissidents before the Communists were ousted in Czechoslovakia's peaceful November 1989 revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selected in Trial of State Attorney General
DOC.TEXT: A jury was seated Monday in the trial of Arkansas Attorney General Steve Clark, who is accused of using his state-issued Visa credit card to entertain friends, family and political supporters. The allegations in February forced Clark to give up his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor, improving Gov. Bill Clinton's re-election chances. The 43-year-old Democrat, the state's top legal officer since 1979, is charged with one count of felony theft by deception. If convicted, he could be sentenced to 20 years in prison and could be fined $15,000. During jury selection, Clark's attorney, Bill Bristow, quizzed potential jurors on their attitudes toward politicians and lawyers, and on whether they had expense accounts and how they spent the money. Bristow said his client had two strikes against him. ``One of the problems I've got with this case is my client is a lawyer,'' he said. ``Lots of people don't like lawyers. My client is also a politician, and I've heard people say they don't care much for politicians. The fact that my client is a lawyer and a politician, does that create any problem?'' A pool of 96 prospective jurors was called for questioning. Two pool members were dismissed because of their association with Clark. Pulaski County Circuit Judge Perry V. Whitmore said the trial would begin Tuesday. The jury of 10 women and two men included a meat cutter, an Army National guardswoman and an electronic technician for AT&T. Clark said he was glad the trial was under way so he could ``get a chance to tell my side.'' He declined to say whether he planned to take the stand. Bristow pointed out that prosecutor Chris Piazza is running for Whitmore's seat on Nov. 6. He also noted that the allegations surfaced about nine days after Clark announced his plans to run for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Clark is accused of improperly billing taxpayers at least $8,448.27 on his credit card for meals 56 times from 1986 to 1989. The amount included $2,012.38 for tips and alcohol. State law prohibits the purchase of alcohol on state expense accounts. He reported as business expenditures meals with people who say they didn't eat with him or that it wasn't business. Some who ate with him said they paid the tab. After the allegations arose, Clark reimbursed the state $3,951.29. He blamed poor record-keeping and said records of the meetings were reconstructed from notes, his calendar, receipts or memory every two to three months. Piazza has said he will show Clark spent state money in part to entertain political supporters. Money contributed to Clark's campaign ended up in his habitually-overdrawn checking account, Piazza has said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Confirm Asian-Strain Citrus Canker
DOC.TEXT: Experts confirmed that a canker infecting more than 200 citrus trees in this citrus-rich state is the highly malignant Asian strain, the state agriculture department said Monday. At least 214 trees in a three-block area of the commercial grove in Highlands County will be removed while authorities determine how to prevent further damage, a department spokeswoman said. Citrus is a leading crop in Florida, generating about $1.5 billion annually. The virulent bacerial disease causes citrus trees to drop their fruit. The affected 400-acre grove is near Central Florida's Lake Placid, about 30 miles northwest of Lake Okeechobee. It contains about 70,000 trees. ``We're sure it can be contained,'' said Maeve McConnell, information specialist for the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services. ``We've had good success on Florida's west coast where we've found it before.'' Removal and defoliation could also protect neighboring trees, Ms. McConnell said. A 1984 outbreak of what at first appeared to be the Asian strain prompted authorities to burn 20 million citrus trees. Scientists later determined the strain was not a threat to commercial citrus.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes College Disclosure Bill
DOC.TEXT: Congress took a first step Monday to require colleges to tell prospective students how many athletes graduate and how much crime there is on campus as well as how many football titles and Nobel Prize winners it has. By voice vote, the House approved a bill requiring colleges and universities that receive federal financial aid and grant athletic scholarships to provide graduation data to the Education Department. Academic institutions receiving federal student aid also must disclose to students and employees campus security policies and crime statistics. The bill was produced by a conference committee of the House and Senate that ironed out differences in versions passed by each House. The Senate must approve before the bill can go to the president. ``Choosing which college or university to attend is a difficult decision for parents and students,'' said Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., chairman of the Education and Labor subcommittee on post-secondary education. ``Surely they deserve as much information as possible.'' Under the bill, academic institutions must provide an annual report to the Education Department, starting in 1992, on how many students receive athletic scholarships and the graduation rate by race and sex for students on football and basketball scholarships. In addition, colleges and universities must provide the graduation rate for all students as well as the rate for students on other athletic scholarships, including baseball, track and all other sports combined. When a student is offered an athletic scholarship, the college must provide the information to the student, parents, coach and guidance counselor. The provisions on crime awareness and campus security take effect on Sept. 1, 1991 and require the college to provide statistics on crimes that have occurred during the past three school years, including murder, rape and robbery. The college also must report the number of arrests for liquor law violations, drug abuse and weapons possession.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Trial of Man Accused of Murder By Daughter
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday in the trial of a man whose daughter has accused him of molesting and murdering her young playmate 21 years ago. The crimes resurfaced last November when the man's daughter told investigators she suddenly had remembered she saw her father sexually attack, then kill, her best friend when she was 8 years old. Jury selection in the trial of George Franklin Sr. is expected to take up to two weeks, said Judge Thomas McGinn. Franklin faces a possible life sentence if convicted. Eileen Franklin-Lipsker testified during a preliminary hearing in May that she repressed her memory of the crimes for 20 years because her father had threatened to kill her if she told anyone. But she said she began having vivid flashbacks of the crimes in early 1989. Franklin, 51, a retired firefighter, was arrested last November at his apartment near Sacramento. He has pleaded innocent and is being held on $2 million bail in San Mateo County jail. Susan Nason, 8, of Foster City, disappeared on Sept. 22, 1969. Her decomposing remains were found in a remote area three months later. A pathologist found she was killed by two blows to the head. Ms. Franklin-Lipsker was not questioned about the murder at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Bishops Visit Rebel Territory
DOC.TEXT: A high-level delegation of Angolan Roman Catholic Church leaders visited the headquarters of guerrillas fighting the Marxist government, rebel radio reported Monday. A government official confirmed the visit and said the government approved of the bishops' peace visit to the rebel camp. The delegation was headed by the Most Rev. Franklin Costa Fernandes, archbishop of the southern city of Lubango and president of the Angolan Episcopal Conference. Costa Fernandes was joined by two other bishops on his visit to Jamba, the southeastern stronghold of the U.S.-backed UNITA guerrillas, said the rebels' Voice of the Black Cockerel radio station. In another development, the government began returning property confiscated from the church after Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975. A prestigious religious education center in Luanda was handed back to church authorities Friday, 13 years after its was expropriated. Almost half Angola's 9.4 million people are Roman Catholics. The Portuguese government has mediated at four meetings between the two sides since April. Rebel leader Jonas Savimbi said recently a cease-fire in the conflict could be signed before the end of the year. Portuguese officials say the two sides have reached broad agreement on the adoption of multiparty democracy and human rights. But there were several reports of fighting in Angola this week. An Monday army statement said rebels killed 150 civilians in the southern province of Huila the past 35 days, including 12 officials. The official ANGOP news agency reported Monday 12 rebels were slain Wednesday by government troops in Huila. The rebels from the the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, have been fighting the Soviet-backed government since Angola's independence in 1975. According to government figures, 350,000 people have died as a result of the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Strangled, Union Blames Salvadoran Army
DOC.TEXT: A militant teachers federation on Monday blamed the Salvadoran army for complicity in the strangling of a teacher in a small western town. Teacher Vilma Chavez, 42, was found strangled with a broken neck Sunday night at her home in Colon, 25 miles west of San Salvador, according to police reports. ``The colleague's murder corresponds to the accusations to which we have been subjected by President (Alfredo) Cristiani and the armed forces, who say that our labor activities are part of guerrilla plans,'' said Saul Sanchez, a leader of the National Salvadoran Educators Association. Chavez was a leader of the association, which traditionally has been critical of the Salvadoran government and has stepped up protests against the Cristiani administration in recent months. The administration last week issued a statement saying that ``some organizations of well-known political affiliation are developing a plan of social agitation and tension-building that coincides with plans the leadership of the FMLN's leadership has reiterated.'' The FMLN is the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, a rebel force that has been fighting a series of U.S.-backed administrations in an 1l-year-old civil war. The Cristiani administration contended in recent days that ``the use of arguments and demands that are impossible to meet by some leaders who are promoting strikes, work stoppages and street demonstrations confirms that these are political not labor movements.'' Sanchez, in an interview, said that ``with these accusations they are condemning to death all teachers and all colleagues who demand better living conditions.'' The Salvadoran war has claimed an estimated 72,000 lives, most of them civilian. Human rights groups say as many as 30,000 deaths have been at the hands of right-wing death squads. Authorities on Monday charged five people - among them one teacher add three university students - with participating in a guerrilla attack on air force headquarters in San Salvador on Wednesday. Judge Raul Armado Diaz said the five are accused of being members of the Armed Forces of Liberation, one of five military organizations that make up the FMLN. He said authorities seized Chinese-made rocket launchers from the group members. He identified the arrested as University of El Salvador students Jeny Ereli Lemus, Silvia Yanira Hernandez, Edith Emilia Gomez, physical education teacher Omar Eriberto Quintanilla and businessman Salvador Portillo.

DOC.HEAD: Two Labor Leaders Killed as Strike Looms
DOC.TEXT: Two labor leaders were killed Monday hours before militant unions announced plans for a nationwide general strike to demand wage increases. Military officials ordered armed escorts on buses in the wake of both attacks, which came one day after Communist rebels burned two buses in the Philippine capital of Manila in support of the strike. Police said Oscar Lazaro, 53, chief of an association of passenger Jeep drivers, was slain by at least four gunmen who entered his office in suburban Paranaque. In a separate incident, a lone assailant fatally stabbed Adriano Yumul, president of the Metro Port Worker's Union, as he was walking to a bus stop in central Manila. Police were uncertain if the attacks were strike-related. Lazaro's association had not announced whether it would join in Wednesday's threatened strike, called to demand a pay increase of $1.50 a day for all workers. President Corazon Aquino has called the proposed pay hike excessive. Lazaro's group refused to join a transport strike two weeks ago and had not supported protests called by more militant unions. During a press conference after the killings, leaders of the Labor Advisory Consultative Council, which claims 1.5 million members, announced plans for the strike unless the government meets pay raise demands by noon Tuesday. ``The workers have run out of patience so we have decided to go on with the strike,'' said council leader Fred Bentulan. On Sunday, rebels burned two buses in the suburbs of Makati and Pasig after ordering passengers to disembark. The Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the Communist New People's Army, said it carried out the attacks because the bus owners were anti-labor and had pressured drivers not to join previous strikes. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos on Monday ordered armed escorts on buses, and additional police checkpoints were seen late Monday on major thoroughfares. Last week, unions rejected a 68-cent-a-day increase, which they called insufficient to protect workers against spiraling costs of fuel, food and utilities. Early Tuesday, bombs exploded in the Manila headquarters of Caltex Inc. and Shell Cos. of the Philippines, both of which are seeking government approval to raise fuel prices because of the gulf crisis and the decline of the Philippine peso. Police said no one was reported injured in the bombings. In a radio address Sunday, Mrs. Aquino urged workers not to ``endanger the very existence of your employer firms by asking for unrealistic wage increases.'' Most national strikes called in recent years have had a limited impact. Only about 10 percent of the work force is organized, and the labor movement is divided. But military rebels in the past have sought to exploit labor unrest to launch attempts to topple Mrs. Aquino. Mrs. Aquino has survived seven military revolts since she took power in the February 1986 ``people power revolution'' that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a bill Monday that provides for the protection of Indian remains and other sacred or cultural artifacts on federal and tribal lands. By voice vote, the House adopted the measure which also requires federal agencies and museums that receive federal funds to prepare inventories of Indian remains and associated artifacts in their possession. If requested by Indian tribes, the remains, artifacts and other burial objects will be returned. Anyone seeking to excavate Indian artifacts or other items from federal or tribal lands must obtain a permit under the Archeological Resources Protection Act and consult with the appropriate tribe, according to the bill. Anyone who discovers Indian remains or artifacts on certain land must notify the appropriate agency or tribe.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Orders White Supremacist to Pay $5 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with quotes. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Judge Ancer...
DOC.TEXT: White supremacist Tom Metzger and others must pay $12.5 million in damages to the family of a black man beaten to death by racist ``skinheads'' Metzger is accused of inciting, a jury ruled Monday. Metzger, 52, a former grand dragon of the Ku Klux Klan, was assessed $5 million and his White Aryan Resistance was ordered to pay $3 million in damages. His son John, 22, was must pay $1 million in damages. Metzger was accused in the lawsuit of inciting the murder by sending an agent to Portland to organize skinheads and teach them how to attack minorities. Metzger, a TV repairman from aallbrook, Calif., who said his family lives on $1,200 a month, said he couldn't come close to paying the judgment and probably would appeal. ``I'll be broke, and under the Constitution I can advocate violence now and nobody can sue me anymore,'' said Metzger. ``So all the things I'm accused of that I didn't do I can do now.'' The jury decided that Kenneth Mieske and Kyle Brewster, two skinheads who pleaded guilty in the slaying, must pay $500,000 each in damages. The wrongful-death suit brought by the family of Mulugeta Seraw sought $12.5 million, and the jury awarded the entire amount. It wasn't immediately clear how the remaining $2.5 breaks down among the defendants. Seraw, a 27-year-old Ethiopian who planned to attend school in Portland, was attacked by three racist ``skinheads'' as he returned home from a party in November 1988. His head was split open by a softball bat. ``People from this country ... have avenged my son's death for me,'' Seraw's father, Seraw Tekuneh, said through an interpreter after the verdict was announced. ``This is the happiest I feel since my son died because I know he has not died in vain.'' The lead plaintiff's attorney, Morris Dees of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., noted the jury awarded all the damages he sought. ``Back home, we say, `It cleans his plow,' '' Dees said of the verdict. ``This jury, I believe, has said there will be a new season for justice in the Northwest and the hate and violence as preached by Tom Metzger hopefully will be shut down forever,'' Dees said. Jurors deliberated about five hours before reaching the verdict on an 11-1 vote. The Multnomah County Circuit jury found that the Metzgers and White Aryan Resistance conspired to do violence to minorities and that they were reckless in sending Dave Mazzella to Portland as their agent. Metzger, who served as his own attorney, said the white separatist movement wouldn't be deterred by the ruling. The verdict ``will cause the ire of a growing underclass of this country,'' Metzger said. ``They made a fatal mistake, I believe. I think they shot themselves in the foot and as conditions change in the country, I think you're going to see it.'' The Metzgers never faced criminal charges in the beating. Mieske pleaded guilty to murder and racial intimidation, in the beating, Brewster to manslaughter and racial intimidation and a third skinhead, Steven Strasser, to manslaughter. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million jury verdict against the United Klans of America after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. Judge Ancer Haggerty told the jury that in order to return a verdict against the Metzgers, they must find that the Metzgers, through their agents, substantially assisted or encouraged conduct leading to the fatal beating. Metzger told jurors that if he is found liable, their own freedoms could be eroded. As an example, he said a juror could be sued for sending a co-worker out for coffee if that person then held up a convenience store. ``Under this loose idea of agency, you're all in trouble,'' he said. Metzger attacked the credibility of Dave Mazzella, 21, a former vice president of John Metzger's Aryan Youth Movement who was the plaintiffs' star witness. He contended that Mazzella lied when he said the Metzgers sent him to Portland to stir up the local skinheads, members of East Side White Pride. Mazzella said he since has changed his racist ways. Metzger noted that other witnesses said Mazzella was the leader of a southern Oregon skinhead group as recently as a few months ago. ``Mazzella exaggerates and wants to be in the spotlight in the center of the stage,'' he said. ``Without Dave Mazzella, there is no case.'' ``The only thing you're here to decide is if there was a meeting of minds to specifically radicalize East Side White Pride and specifically find a black person and kill him,'' Metzger said. ``If that didn't happen, there's no case.'' Elden Rosenthal, an attorney for the plaintiffs, said in his rebuttal that the First Amendment wasn't the issue. ``We have no evidence that Tom or John Metzger said, `Go kill Mulugeta Seraw.' We're not required to prove that,'' he told the jury. He said the plaintiffs had proven that the Metzgers and Mazzella conspired to create random acts of violence ``and the fact that in one of those random incidents a man died, and that's why we're here.'' Metzger said the case is a conspiracy to destroy him. ``Do you want to make me a martyr?'' he asked jurors. He also claimed he has few assets. ``In many cases I could qualify for the poverty level,'' he said. Rosenthal said the plaintiffs' intent is not to become wealthy, but to stop racist violence. The way to do that, Rosenthal said, is to strangle it financially. ``This community, indeed this country, is going to remember your verdict for a long time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: N-Plant Officials Release Documents, Say Plant Will Be Safe
DOC.TEXT: Officials at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant on Monday released a summary of a report critical of management and denied that safety was being jeopardized in the rush to restart plutonium reprocessing. A consulting firm, Cermak Fletcher Associates Inc. of Gaithersburg, Md., has done a study for EG&G Inc., the plant contractor, citing serious management problems at the plant in the last five months. The plant makes plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. A summary of its report, completed in August, was released Monday after The Associated Press last week reported parts of the document. Rocky Flats workers who spoke on condition of anonymity told the AP that managers were endangering safety at the plant in a rush to restart operations, which have been suspended since November 1989 because of safety and environmental concerns. The summary said the plant's civilian management team ``failed to establish and implement a comprehensive management control program for procedure development'' for resuming operations. EG&G Inc. operates the plant outside Denver for the Department of Energy. Plant officials acknowledged Monday there was a push to get safety problems fixed at the plant, but denied there is a rush to restart plutonium reprocessing at the expense of safety. ``Obviously, we'd like to get all the things fixed here that need fixing,'' Bob Nelson, plant manager for the Department of Energy, told a news conference. ``We have a budget and a certain number of dollars, and we'd like to get all we can for the money.'' Nelson denied there is a rush to restart plutonium reprocessing at the expense of safety. John Davis, an assistant EG&G manager who commissioned the report, said it was ordered after he twice tried to submit procedures for DOE approval that failed to meet federal requirements. Plant officials denied the report was responsible for the firing on Friday of plant manager Phil Warner. Warner was replaced by James O. Zane, an EG&G vice president. Plant officials said in a statement that the company felt it was time for a change. Workers at the plant claimed problems are even worse than the report indicates. One worker said that when he questioned whether he should install a fire door before checking if it standards for a nuclear plant, a supervisor ordered him to go ahead and install because checking would take too long. The worker said he checked records later and found it failed to meet federal standards. Workers also said so-called red-line drawings, which are used to identify critical operations at the plant, were improperly drawn up over the past six months and many will have to be redone. They said it could cost as much as $130 million to redo the work. Francis Allhoff, assistant general manager for administration and planning, acknowledged that some of the drawings will have to be done over. But he said most could be used in resuming operations of the plant, even though they don't meet industry standards. ``All of the red-line drawings may not have been done correctly. They will have to be redone, but it's not a big number,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Maintains Lead Over Karpov After Pair Agrees to Draw.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with game Game 5 ending in draw. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Chess Algebraic, a list of the moves.
DOC.TEXT: Chess champion Garry Kasparov sustained his edge over challenger Anatoly Karpov as the two agreed to a draw Monday in the fifth game of the world chess title match. Kasparov went into the game leading by 2{ points to Karpov's 1{ points. When the game ended just after 10 p.m. after Karpov's 36th move, the score was 3 to 2 in Kasparov's favor. The champion's Game 2 victory was worth a full point. The three other games were draws, worth one-half point each to the two contestants. ``Kasparov is trying to create many problems for Karpov in each game,'' said grand master Sergey Kudrin, of Stamford, Conn. ``Even when they draw, Karpov has to work very hard for it.'' Kasparov took one of his three allowed timeouts on Friday, postponing Game 5 until Monday. Karpov had used one of his timeouts a week earlier to recuperate from his Game 2 loss. The first player to reach 12{ points in the 24-game series will win the championship. Kasparov, who dethroned Karpov in 1985, would retain his title if the match ended in a 12-12 tie. The first 12 games are being played in New York and the remainder will be played in Lyons, France. The winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser will get $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Troubled Sale of MGM-UA Nearly Completed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to put total purchase price in lead, move down today's payment of $967 million. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Of the...' A version moving on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: The long-delayed sale of MGM-UA Communications Co. neared completion Monday when Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. delivered the balance of the $1.3 million price. MGM-UA's board of directors scheduled a meeting Tuesday about the sale of the historic studio, the two companies said in a news release. Pathe, a Beverly Hills-based entertainment conglomerate, said if the board gives its approval, Pathe anticipates closing the deal Friday. The deal was negotiated by Parretti and Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who owns 80 percent of MGM-UA and has been trading its various pieces for several years. The deal with Pathe had been hung up over concerns Parretti wouldn't be able to come up with the money. Pathe paid $967 million, representing the balance of the purchase price of MGM-UA, into an escrow account. Combined with previous installments totalling $353 million, the payments fulfill the purchase price. Of the additional $967 million, Pathe said almost $600 million was raised through a sale of stock in the combined company. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said details of the offering would be revealed in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission later this week. He declined to identify the new investors. Pathe on Sunday sold English-language television rights for nearly 1,000 MGM-UA films to Turner Broadcasting System Inc. That transaction was valued at a reported $200 million. MGM-UA is responsible for the Oscar-winning ``Rain Man,'' and the James Bond and Rocky films. Its television arm makes the shows ``thirtysomething,'' ``In the Heat of the Night,'' ``The Young Riders'' and ``Dark Shadows.'' Over the last two years, production at the studio has slowed to a crawl as MGM-UA has gone through a variety of aborted takeovers. Parretti, Pathe's co-president, is an elusive figure. The son of a olive merchant, he made his fortune, he says, by buying, restructuring and selling troubled European companies. He has predicted that one day he will preside over ``the biggest film group in the world.'' He has been Liberia's ``ambassador at large,'' has dodged published reports accusing him of making anti-semitic comments and has been convicted of a fraudulent bankruptcy in a Naples court. Parretti bought the financially strapped Cannon Group movie studio, purveyors of exploitation titles like ``River of Death,'' in 1988 for $200 million. Other holdings include a French real-estate concern, European theater chains and movie production and distribution companies. MGM-UA executives declined to comment on Monday's announcement. Ever since Kerkorian placed MGM-UA on the block in April 1988, the sale has been an odyssey of failed financing, lawsuits and juicy gossip. Kerkorian, who owns 80 percent of the company, has been courted by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., Australia's Qintex Entertainment Inc., PolyGram N.V., MCA Inc., Japan's C. Itoh and Co., Barris Industries Inc., several unidentified foreign investors and the Walt Disney Co. A March 1989 deal with Qintex appeared to be one of the most likely to be completed. But the $1.5 billion transaction fell apart when Qintex was unable to raise the money. If he is successful in selling the company, MGM-UA Chairman Jeffrey Barbakow will receive a bonus of $21.4 million. He declined to be interviewed Monday, but has said previously that he will remain at the studio.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Official Launches Write-In Campaign as Alternative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with six grafs to UPDATE with lawmakers' reactions to state auditor's write-in campaign. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Among the...'
DOC.TEXT: A popular Republican launched a write-in campaign for governor Monday, offering himself as an alternative to the GOP candidate under fire over allegations he once asked teen-age girls to go skinny dipping. The entry of State Auditor Arne Carlson as a write-in candidate ``kind of took the wind out'' of a move by some state lawmakers to pressure Jon Grunseth to get out of the race, said Sanate minority leader Duane Benson. His candidacy became controversial last week when two women stepped forward to say that when they were teen-agers, Grunseth tried to get them to swim nude with him in the pool at his home. At least nine Minnesota newspapers have run editorials calling for Grunseth to step aside. The entry of the well known Carlson offers Republicans a choice, some relieved party leaders noted. ``A lot of people are kind of comfortable with two (Republican) people in it,'' said Benson said. ``But it would have really boiled had Arne waited another day.'' Prior to Carlson's announcement, State Rep. Elton Redalen warned that Grunseth could drag down the rest of the Republican ticket unless he quits. Redalen's call for Grunseth to step aside came three days after an internal Republican poll indicated that five state Republicans could defeat Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich in the Nov. 6 election, but that Grunseth could not. Among the five was Carlson, who led Perpich by a 55-to-29 percent margin in the poll. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., said he helped initiate the survey, and has urged Grunseth to ``make a hard-minded, objective decision about his own chances and the chances of all the other candidates around him.'' Carlson, who finished second to Grunseth in the Sept. 11 primary, announced his write-in candidacy at a news conference. ``We can win,'' he said. Carlson pledged a ``totally upbeat, positive campaign. ``This news conference is not to blame anyone but to allow all Minnesotans to know full well that they are entitled to a campaign that will dedicate itself to the high road,'' he said. A statewide bipartisan coalition of voters known as Minnesotans for the WRITE Choice had rallied earlier in the day to encourage Carlson to run. The nude-swimming allegations concern a 1981 Fourth of July party at Grunseth's house. Two women who were 13 and 14 years old at the time alleged in sworn statements that an apparently intoxicated Grunseth encouraged them, his 13-year-old daughter, Nina, and a 16-year-old girl to join him for a nude swim. One of the women said Grunseth tried to pull down the strap of her swim suit and to touch her breast. Grunseth has said that if any nude swimming occurred at the party, it was after he went to bed. ``Have I ever been skinny-dipping in my life?'' he said Sunday. ``Yeah. So what?'' He also referred to a period in the late 1970s and early '80s as his ``wild years,'' a remark that Redalen cited in calling for his departure from the race. ``That's not acceptable to me or to my constituents down here,'' Redalen said. He added that he finds unacceptable a ``lifestyle of fun and heavy drinking and womanizing ... even though it's in the past.'' Grunseth's continued presence in the race, Redalen said ``could bring down the entire (Republican) statewide ticket, and we could lose many of the seats we thought we could pick up in both the House and Senate.'' The Republican poll showed Grunseth trailing Perpich, 41 percent to 24 percent. But Grunseth campaign chairman Leon Oistad said another GOP poll, taken Friday night and Saturday morning, showed that margin narrowing to a 37-to-27 percent Perpich lead.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chairman Peter MacDonald Sentenced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `MacDonald is...,' to CORRECT name of tribal organization that changed election date, DELETE Jan. 6 because board didn't specify the date, just the length of the delay.
DOC.TEXT: Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald was sentenced Monday to nearly six years in a tribal jail and fined $11,000 for bribery, ethics violations and conspiracy. His son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., was given a 1{-year sentence and fined $2,500. MacDonald, 61, who was suspended as tribal chairman last year, was convicted in tribal court Wednesday of 41 counts of bribery, conspiracy and ethics violations for taking cash, loans, plane rides and use of an car from businessmen trying to curry favor with him. His 36-year-old son was convicted of 23 counts of bribery, theft by extortion, ethics violations and conspiracy. Judge Robert Yazzie sentenced MacDonald to 5 years and 335 days in a tribal jail in Window Rock, the Navajo reservation's capital. MacDonald also must do four years and 340 days of labor, similar to community service, after his jail term, and his son must serve one year of labor, Yazzie said. MacDonald is seeking the new office of president of the nation's biggest Indian tribe. The tribal council on Friday voted to authorize the election board to postpone the election, originally scheduled for Nov. 6, for 60 days. He will remain in jail for at least a week until Yazzie rules if he can be released on bail or his own recognizance pending an appeal, said defense attorney Val Jolley. ``You have not admitted to any wrongding and shown no remorse,'' Yazzie said. ``I truly say you were a great leader and made valuable contributions to the Navajo people.'' MacDonald, a former aerospace engineer, showed no emotion as he stood before the court. MacDonald's opponent in the election is former tribal chairman Peterson Zah. Whether the conviction will remove him from the ballot, as tribal law apparently requires, won't be known until Tuesday at the earliest, when the tribal election board meets. The board is reviewing a proposed amendment to its code to allow interim tribal leader Leonard Haskie, who finished third to MacDonald and Zah in a non-partisan primary election, to run in MacDonald's place. MacDonald's second trial was scheduled to begin Tuesday, but a judge on Monday postponed it until Nov. 27. That case involves conspiracy charges stemming from the tribe's purchase of a ranch for $33.4 million from a company which paid $26.2 million for the property only five minutes earlier. His son, an unemployed lawyer, is a co-defendant. Last week, Byron ``Bud'' Brown, a Scottsdale real-estate agent who allegedly was the middleman in the ranch sale, and his brother were indicted on federal money-laundering and fraud charges in the case. In another case, MacDonald faces 93 fraud counts stemming from the tribe's 1986 primary and general elections. Suspended Vice Chairman Johnny R. Thompson is a co-defendant. About 180,000 Navajos live on the 21,100-square-mile reservation, the nation's largest. It covers a large portion of northeastern Arizona and extends into southeastern Utah and northwestern New Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Up at McGraw-Hill, Media General; Down at Scripps, Pulitzer
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc. said its third-quarter profit edged up 5.1 percent from a year ago, as strong operating performances from its financial services and book publishing businesses more than offset lower results from broadcasting and information services. Media General Inc., meanwhile, reported its profit climbed 87 percent in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with a year earlier. The E.W. Scripps Co. posted a 3.3 percent decline in its third-quarter profit, and Pulitzer Publishing Co. reported a 56 percent drop in profit, its third straight quarter of falling profits.

The diversified New York-based media company said it earned $67.4 million, or $1.38 a share, in the third quarter compared with $64.1 million, or $1.31 a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 11.2 percent to $502.8 million from $452.2 million a year earlier. Overall operating profit was up 20.4 percent to $98.3 million, including $10 million in pretax savings from the 1989 corporate realignment. Operating earnings rose 40 percent from financial services, which include the Standard & Poor's debt ratings service and MMS International market research. Its educational and professional publishing business posted a 36.5 percent rise in operating profit for the quarter despite disappointing results in the college segment. But operating profit slipped by less than 1 percent in broadcasting because of the sale of syndicated programming in 1989. Operating profits from information and publications services were down 7.1 percent due to the adverse impact of economic uncertainty on advertising in Business Week magazine and the costs of automation at the F.W. Dodge segment.

Media General, based in Richmond, Va., said its profit rose to $7.3 million, or 28 cents a share, from $3.9 million, or 15 cents a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 6.9 percent to $152.1 million from $142.3 million in 1989, including gains in all three business divisions - broadcast, newspapers and newsprint. Advertising in the company's newspapers remained generally sluggish, but The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune gained from strong national account campaigns, the company said. Media General also owns the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch, The Richmond News Leader and the Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal. The company owns three television stations and cable TV operations and has newsprint interests. For the first nine months of 1990, net income edged up to $22.4 million, or 86 cents a share, from $21.9 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 3.8 percent to $458.2 million from $441.5 million last year.

E.W. Scripps of Cincinnati reported its profits for the third quarter slipped to $17.4 million, or 23 cents a share, from $18 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 5.7 percent to $321.7 million from $304.3 million last year. Lawrence A. Leser, president and chief executive, said operating income rose for the quarter despite a very difficult advertising revenue environment at the company's 19 daily newspapers. He cited a strong increase in cable television income, and said the broadcast group performed well. Scripps owns nine television stations, five radio stations and cable systems with 595,500 basic subscribers. The company also syndicates and licenses news features and comics, such as ``Peanuts'' and ``Garfield.'' For the first nine months, Scripps earned $27 million, or 35 cents a share, down 53.7 percent from $58.3 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.4 percent to $951.1 million from $920.1 million.

Pulitzer, based in St. Louis, had net earnings of $1.4 million, or 13 cents a share, down from $3.2 million, or 31 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenues of $98 million were up 3.5 percent from $94.6 million. The cmpany, which reported a 33 percent decrease in profits last quarter and a 70 percent decrease in the first quarter, continued to blame soft newspaper advertising conditions. In addition, third-quarter profits were affected by costs related to the purchase of WDSU-TV in New Orleans in December. ``While our third-quarter results are disappointing, we are optimistic over the long term as we continue to emphasize market share and cost control,'' said Joseph Pulitzer Jr., chairman of the board. For the first three quarters, net income was $6.9 million or 66 cents a share, down from $13.2 million, or $1.26 a share, last year. Revenue increased to $297 million from $256 million. Pulitzer's newspaper operations include the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson, and newspapers and shoppers in the Chicago area. Pulitzer's broadcasting operations consist of network-affilitated TV stations in Greenville, S.C.; Lancaster, Pa., Winston-Salem, N.C.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Omaha, Neb.; Louisville, Ky.; and New Orleans. Pulitzer also owns two radio stations in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Profits Down at New York Times Co., McClatchy Newspapers, Affiliated
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times Co. said its after-tax profit skidded 95.6 percent in the third quarter from results a year ago, which were fattened by a large, one-time gain on the sale of its cable television operations. Affiliated Publications, owner of The Boston Globe, reported its net earnings dropped by more than 50 percent, add McClatchy Newspapers Inc. said its profit was down 14.8 percent.

The newspaper, magazine and broadcast company said it earned $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $210.8 million, or $2.68 a share, a year earlier. Revenue edged up 1.3 percent to $420.7 million from $415.3 million. The 1989 results included $2.47 a share from the sale and results of NYT Cable TV, which was sold in August 1989. Even without counting the cable sale gain, Times said its income from continuing operations was down 43.9 percent from a year ago because of a decline in advertising linage at its flagship newspaper and costs related to two new plants. Income from continuing operations amounted to $9.2 million, down from $16.4 million a year earlier. Operating profit in the newspaper group dropped 43.8 percent to $19.6 million in the quarter from $34.9 million a year earlier. Ad linage was down 10.7 percent at The New York Times, but up 4 percent at the company's 35 regional newspapers. Depreciation and interest expenses on a new production center in Edison, N.J., and a new facility for the Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News reduced earnings by 9 cents a share in the quarter. For the first nine months, the company earned $52.6 million, or 69 cents a share, down 81.6 percent from $285.6 million, or $3.63 a share, from a year ago. The 1989 results included $2.52 a share from the cable sale and operations. Revenue rose 1.5 percent to $1.32 billion from $1.3 billion.

Sacramento, Calif.-based McClatchy earned $7.5 million, or 26 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with $8.8 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 12.8 percent to $107.0 million from $94.9 million. The company said the profit decline stemmed from the costs of buying six newspapers in South Carolina in January and losses on its investment in a new newsprint mill. It said profit would have risen slightly otherwise. For the first nine months, McClatchy earned $17.7 million, or 62 cents a share, down 25 percent from $23.6 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent to $309.7 million from $279.1 million.

Boston-based Affiliated reported $4 million in net income, or 6 cents per share, on revenues of $130.40 million for the third quarter. In the same period last year, the company earned $8.48 million, or 12 cents per share, on $126.96 million in revenues. For the nine-month period, Affiliated reported $17.91 million in earnings, or 26 cents per share, on $396 million in revenues. That compares with $2.88 million in earnings, or 4 cents per share, for the same period in 1989. Affiliated also said operating income at its BPI Communications subsidiary was negatively affected by start-up costs of its broadcast monitoring service and costs from its acquisition of A-S-N Communications Inc.
DOC.HEAD: Phillips Plans To Retire as Dow Jones Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Warren H. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of Dow Jones & Co. Inc., plans to step down next year. Phillips said Oct. 17 that he would relinquish his chief executive duties Jan. 1 and retire as chairman July 1. Phillips, 64, has been chief executive of the media and financial information company since 1975 and chairman since 1978. He will be 65 by the time he retires as chairman. Peter R. Kann, the company's president and chief operating officer, is to succeed Phillips as chief executive. Kann also is publisher of The Wall Street Journal. Spokesman Roger May said Phillips' decision to leave was based on the customary retirement age of 65 and was unconnected with recent financial troubles at the company, which reported a sharp drop in third-quarter earnings. Dow Jones has no mandatory retirement age except for its directors, who must step down at 70, May said. The timing of Phillips' announcement came as a surprise to some Dow Jones employees. It followed the bad earnings report and the disclosure of a severe cost-cutting plan. But May said the company's outside directors knew of Phillips' plans for more than a year. Phillips will remain on the company's board of directors. No date was set for election of a new chairman.

DOC.HEAD: UPI, Reuters, Settle Photo Dispute
DOC.TEXT: United Press International and Reuters settled their court dispute over photo services, agreeing Reuters will continue to supply UPI with foreign news photos but will cover the United States for itself. A 1984 agreement called for UPI to supply Reuters with photographs from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. Reuters later sued to void the picture exchange, and UPI filed a counterclaim saying Reuters had negotiated in bad faith. No compensation or monetary damages will be paid by either organization under the settlement, the news organizations said Oct. 19. The announcement said UPI will have the option of ending the exchange agreement by giving Reuters 30 days' notice. Otherwise, Reuters will supply UPI with foreign news photos without charge until September 1992. After that, UPI will have the option of subscribing to the Reuter service. Reuters will cover the United States with its own resources and will not use UPI pictures, the announcement said. It said UPI will sell its news photo service outside the United States without involvement by Reuters.
DOC.HEAD: Suit Against Tribune Newspapers in Arizona Dropped
DOC.TEXT: A former Arizona State University football coach agreed Oct. 19 to drop a $2 million libel suit against Tribune Newspapers, which publishes in Mesa, Tempe and Chandler. An agreement to drop the suit by former strength coach Ronald Jones was signed by attorneys for Jones and the newspaper company and sent to Maricopa County Superior Court Judge Frederick Martone. The September 1989 suit concerned comments attributed to Jones in a story published in the newspapers a year earlier about steroid use by the Sun Devil football team in 1985 and 1986. Jones was quoted as saying steroid use on the team increased after head coach John Cooper took over in 1985. Jones, now a coach with the Philadelphia Eagles, later denied making the statements to reporter Mike Tulumello. The reporter said he tape-recorded the interview. The agreement to drop the suit stipulated that Jones was indeed the source of the statements and that he suffered no damages from the article. ``The suit was baseless, should never have been filed, and certainly should never have remained active this long,'' a statement from Tribune Newspapers said.
DOC.HEAD: Distributor Sentenced in Plot To Kill Oregonian Executives
DOC.TEXT: A former independent distributor of The Oregonian has been sentenced to 21 years in prison for plotting to kill two executives of the Portland, Ore., newspaper. Neither of the men was hurt. Marvin M. Clapp, 47, of Vancouver, was sentenced Oct. 19 for soliciting to commit murder and arson. He was convicted in June of hiring Billy Ray Robinson of Vancouver to kill circulation director Patrick L. Marlton and Robert J. Gillard, home-delivery zone manager. Gunshots were fired at the men's homes in August 1989. Marlton's home was firebombed Jan. 8, causing about $30,000 damage. Robinson, who testified against Clapp, was sentenced to five years' probation on a first-degree arson charge. Prosecutors said Clapp wanted revenge because his distribution contract was not renewed in 1982 when The Oregonian began using its own distribution agents. Clapp had blamed Marlton and Gillard specifically for the loss of his dealership, for which he had paid about $38,000. Clapp had sued The Oregonian twice earlier, charging breach of contract and slander. He lost both lawsuits.
DOC.HEAD: Dover Paper To Buy Evening Citizen in New Hampshire
DOC.TEXT: George J. Foster Co. of Dover, publisher of Foster's Daily Democrat, has signed a letter of intent to buy the Evening Citizen of Laconia, the two companies announced. The Evening Citizen is an 11,000-circulation newspaper serving the Lakes Region of central New Hampshire. The Daily Democrat is a 30,000-circulation evening newspaper serving southeastern New Hampshire and southern Maine.
DOC.HEAD: Amos Press Announces Purchase of Ohio Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Amos Press Inc. announced plans Oct. 15 to purchase the Ohio Communications Corp., a group of eight publications in suburban Dayton. The publications are the Beavercreek Daily News, Belmont Times, Business Life, Centerville-Bellbrook Times, Fairborn Daily Herald, Greene County Shopper, Kettering-Oakwood Times and West Carrollton Shopper. The purchase price wasn't disclosed.
DOC.HEAD: Hurdle Buys Weekly in Leland, Miss.
DOC.TEXT: The owner and editor of the weekly Deer Creek Pilot in Rolling Fork, Miss., has bought the weekly newspaper in Leland. Frank Hurdle, who has owned the Pilot since 1988, bought the Leland Progress from Charles M. ``Mac'' Gordon, who has been editor and publisher of the newspaper the past 12 years. Terms of the sale were not released. Hurdle said the name of the Leland Progress will be changed to The Deer Creek Progress.
DOC.HEAD: Daily American Republic in Poplar Bluff, Ark., Sold
DOC.TEXT: Woodward Communications Inc. has sold the Daily American Republic to Butler County Publishing Co. No purchase price was included in the announcement Oct. 19. The Poplar Bluff newspaper has a circulation of 15,200 and publishes Monday through Friday afternoons, and Sunday mornings.
DOC.HEAD: AP Reporter at World Series Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press sports writer Ronald Blum was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest Oct. 17 while covering the World Series. Richard L. Creighton Jr., Blum's attorney, filed written pleas of innocent the next day with Hamilton County Municipal Judge Joseph Luebbers. The court scheduled a Nov. 9 trial before Municipal Judge Albert Mestemaker. Blum was arrested in a dispute with police at Riverfront Stadium immediately after the Cincinnati Reds' 5-4 victory over the Oakland Athletics. He was released on his own recognizance. Police said Blum, who is based in New York, became disorderly and used profanity when a stadium security woman attempted to keep him from getting onto a crowded elevator with other reporters returning to the press box from post-game interviews. Blum, who has been with the AP since February 1986, denied being abusive, disorderly or resisting arrest. ``I was just trying to do my job. I told them I had to write a story and went on the elevator,'' Blum said. ``When the elevator got upstairs and I tried to get off, they pulled me back and told me I was under arrest.'' ``He was on deadline and was trying to get back up here with some quotes,'' said Terry Taylor, the AP's deputy sports editor who directed the news cooperative's coverage of the game. A spokesman for Major League Baseball declined comment on the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Journalists Speak on Drug Terrorism
DOC.TEXT: The drug cartels have made the news business deadly for journalists in Colombia, the editor in chief of the newspaper El Tiempo said. Enrique Santos Castillo said his nephew, Francisco Santos Calderon, had planned to attend the Oct. 16 meeting of the Inter American Press Association with him in Kansas City, but had been kidnapped and is said to be a captive of the Medellin drug cartel. ``We walk around with armed guards. We have armored cars. We have soldiers in our homes. It's an incredible situation,'' Santos Castillo said. At latest count, the cartels hold seven Colombian journalists captive as a means of intimidation. ``All the newspapers of Colombia have assumed a very courageous posture against the drug mafia,'' he said. Luis Gabriel Cano, owner and editor of the Bogota daily El Espectador, has seen his brother murdered and his paper bombed on orders of the drug cartels. El Espectador may compete for readers with El Tiempo, but the two are united in their stand against the grip cocaine cartels have on Colombia. ``I am convinced that the free press will come through, as it has always come through,'' Cano said. Edward Seaton, president of IAPA, which monitors press freedoms in the Americas, said drug violence had killed 19 Colombian news media employees in 1989 and seven so far this year. Also attending the special conference on Colombia were Jorge Hernandez, general editor of El Colombiano, a daily in the cocaine capital of Medellin, and Luis Fernando Santos, general manager of El Tiempo and the son of Santos Castillo.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Faces Ban for Comparing Mohammed with Celebrities
DOC.TEXT: The government of this mainly Moslem country said Oct. 19 it was considering banning a weekly tabloid for listing the prophet Mohammed with other ``admirable public figures.'' In its edition for the week of Oct. 15, the 400,000-circulation tabloid Exemplars contained an article listing 50 well-known figures, including Mohammed, President Suharto, Cabinet ministers, film stars and singers. Indonesia, the world's most populous Moslem nation, prohibits publishing material that could trigger religious or racial disturbances. ``Prophet Mohammed is not a common figure. Therefore, it is not proper to compare him with film stars or other figures,'' said Hamdan Abbas, a senior Moslem scholar. The newspaper's chief editor, Arswendo Atmowiloto, apologized and said the publication would take more care in the future.
DOC.HEAD: Journalists Charge Government Trying To Take Over Opposition Paper
DOC.TEXT: Romanian journalists charge that the government is trying to muzzle the press by keeping it under state control. A front-page statement Oct. 19 by the Journalists' Union in the mass-circulation daily Tineretul Liber charged that ``some members of the government are attempting to subordinate the independent press to (the government's) own interests.'' It called on the government to reverse an Oct. 10 decision making the newspaper and some 30 other publications part of the state-owned National Publishing House. Tineretul Liber's editorial board maintains the staff should be given de facto collective ownership, since the paper has run itself and paid salaries from profits. After meeting editors of several papers, media minister Adrian Sirbu said Oct. 19 that the government's position would not change. He accused the journalists of trying to steal state property. State-run TV has declared its support for the journalists. TV news director Victor Ionescu urged the government ``to stay out of matters which are not its business.''
DOC.HEAD: FTC Challenges Sales of Printing Company
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission on Oct. 15 challenged R.R. Donnelley & Son Co.'s acquisition of a smaller publishing-printing partnership, saying it could substantially lessen competition in the high-volume publication field. Donnelley, which has its headquarters in Chicago, bought the Meredith-Burda companies for $570 million in a deal completed Sept. 4. The previous week, a U.S. District Court judge denied the FTC's request for a preliminary injunction blocking the sale. ``We were convinced at the very beginning, when this sale was agreed upon in December 1989, that it did not present legal obstacles,'' said James Ratcliff, Donnelley's vice president for corporate affairs. ``We think we were right on the facts of the law, and that we have a good case, and we will press on.'' The FTC issued an administrative complaint that the acquisition ``created a firm whose share of the market is so high that it has become a dominant firm.'' It said the deal will eliminate competition among other firms in the market. Donnelly is a printing firm specializing in high-volume publication gravure printing of the type used for long runs of magazines, newspaper inserts and catalogues. Meredith Corp., based in Des Moines, Iowa, is a magazine publisher that also owns seven television stations. It is a partner in printing operations with the Burda family of Germany.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Closing Bureaus in Three Cities
DOC.TEXT: Although it's still earning money, ABC News will close its bureaus in Chicago, Boston and Dallas because of lean times, but will maintain reporters in all three cities, an ABC spokesman said Oct. 18. The spokesman, Scott Richardson, said no further cuts were expected. The bureaus will be closed by Dec. 31. The move, which leaves ABC with nine U.S. bureaus, comes as ABC News is undergoing belt-tightening as a result of Persian Gulf coverage costs and lower-than-expected advertising revenues that affect all three networks. In Dallas, correspondent Charles Murphy will work from his home. In Boston, a two-person staff will be kept to work with ABC's medical correspondent, Dr. Tim Johnson, who reports for several ABC shows. In Chicago, correspondent Chris Bury will work out of ABC-owned WLS-TV. Twelve off-camera staff members are affected by the closings. Some will be reassigned or offered other jobs and others will be let go, Richardson said. He said it was not yet known how many would be laid off. CBS, which has seven domestic bureaus, and NBC, which has nine, have no plans to close any offices, spokeswomen for those networks said. ABC's action was expected. The network earlier put on hold a planned 1 a.m.-6 a.m. news feed to its affiliates that would have begun in January. That operation would have employed 40 people. ABC News officials have said the division will show a profit this year despite the lean times, although it probably will earn about $25 million less than the $75 million that had been anticipated. NBC News recently said it would let go 25 staff members, but it isn't a cutback, said NBC spokeswoman Peggy Hubble. Their skills were just not needed for various projects being planned. Ms. Hubble said NBC is hiring an additional 100 staff members, the majority for the 24-hour NBC News Channel for affiliates it is starting next year. The remainder would work for the new ``Real Life With Jane Pauley'' series that NBC says it will add to its schedule as a midseason replacement.
DOC.HEAD: Gynecologist Refiles Suit Against CBS
DOC.TEXT: Former gynecologist James Burt has refiled his $250 million defamation suit against CBS Inc. Last month, U.S. District Judge Walter Rice dismissed a portion of Burt's suit, saying Burt has no private right of action under the FCC's personal-attack rule. However, Rice said he would consider further arguments on the question of whether the statute of limitations had run out on the CBS broadcast in question. Attorney Earl Moore said the suit was refiled Oct. 12 in U.S. District Court without the arguments on the FCC issue. Burt filed the original suit in March, alleging he was defamed by a CBS television program on his sex-related surgery. The October 1988 episode of ``West 57th Street'' featured interviews with Burt and several of his patients. Burt is facing scores of medical malpractice suits for his self-described ``love surgery,'' in which he physically altered the genitals of his female patients to allegedly enhance sexual responsiveness. The suits allege Burt performed the surgery either without patient consent or by fraudulently obtaining consent. In January 1989, Burt surrendered his medical license to the State Medical Board after being charged with gross immorality and other violatons.
DOC.HEAD: Newswoman Files Sexual Discrimination Suit Against Dees
DOC.TEXT: A newswoman filed a sex discrimination lawsuit against ``Into the Night'' TV host Rick Dees, claiming she was publicly humiliated by risque jokes during his appearance on a TV show. Liz Fulton said in her Superior Court suit filed Oct. 16 that Dees humiliated her by appearing on ``The Wally George Show'' in 1988 with a scantily clad, buxom woman he identified as Miss Fulton. ``This is only the tip of the iceberg on how women are forced to endure sexual stereotypes in broadcasting. But many don't file lawsuits because they fear they will be blackballed by the industry,'' said attorney Gloria Allred. Dees, a KIIS-FM radio personality who worked with Miss Fulton until she was fired in April, recently began as host of the late-night variety show ``Into the Night Starring Rick Dees.'' Jack Silver, a spokesman for KIIS-FM, referred all calls to Gannett Radio, which owns the station. ``We have received the documents from Liz Fulton's attorney and we are now reviewing them,'' said Jay Cook, Gannett Radio president. ``We will respond when appropriate.'' While acting as his radio show sidekick, Ms. Fulton said Dees frequently referred to her as ``Liz Rugburn Fulton.'' ``In addition,'' the suit said, ``Dees humiliated and damaged her when he appeared on `The Wally George Show' . . . accompanied by a woman purporting to be Ms. Fulton who was dressed in a scant bikini. ``The impostor behaved in an inappropriate and embarrassing manner and was eventually led off the set in handcuffs.'' Ms. Allred said her client, now a newswoman at KFI radio, never consented to the impersonation. Additionally, the suit states Ms. Fulton, 37, believes she was fired because ``she was perceived as too old and family oriented and not sufficiently sexy enough to satisfy Mr. Dees.'' Dees was accused of employment discrimination on the basis of sex and age and unauthorized commercial use of Miss Fulton's name, invasion of privacy, intentional misrepresentation and defamation. Ms. Fulton asked for general, compensatory and punitive damages for humiliation, mental anguish, anger and emotional distress. The dollar amount would be determined at trial.
DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Raise $30,000 To Send Radios to Mideast Troops
DOC.TEXT: U.S. radio stations have received pledges of $30,000 and are seeking more donations to buy radios and batteries for use by American troops in the Persian Gulf region, the National Association of Broadcasters said Oct. 18. The first shipment of radios already has arrived in the gulf from the AIR-LIFT listener donation campaign. The association launched the effort last month in conjunction with Westinghouse Electric's Group W Radio. An additional 6,000 batteries and receivers, including 5,000 sets from Sony, will be en route to the Middle East the week of Oct. 22, the trade group said. The radios can be used to pick up the Armed Forces Radio and Television Service, which has begun broadcasting to American troops in the region.
DOC.HEAD: David Hartman Gets Syndicated Show
DOC.TEXT: Former ``Good Morning America'' host David Hartman is returning to daily television next year as host of a syndicated program to be called ``Realities With David Hartman.'' Hartman, the first host of ABC's morning show, left it in 1987 after 11 years. The new series will have a magazine format and probe ``the issues and experiences that affect people in their daily lives,'' according to the producers, Viacom Enterprises and Greystone Communications.

Stuart Greenspan, an art journalist and former editor in chief of Art & Auction magazine, died of AIDS on Oct. 15. He was 44. He edited Art & Auction from 1983 to 1987 and then became a contributing editor. He also wrote for House and Garden magazine and for the weekly newspaper The New York Observer. Survivors include his parents and two brothers.
DOC.HEAD: Winners of the Inland Press Association Contest
DOC.TEXT: The Oakland (Calif.) Tribune has taken top honors in two categories in the Inland Press Association's public affairs contest. The newspaper received first place in deadline reporting for its coverage of the 1989 San Francisco Bay area earthquake. The Tribune also came in first in investigative work among newspapers with more than 100,000 circulation for ``its relentless reporting leading to the exposure of a complex scandal in the Oakland school district.'' The Kansas City (Mo.) Star captured second place for deadline reporting, while the Star-Tribune of Minneapolis was the runner-up in investigative reporting. The Wausau (Wis.) Daily Herald was named sweepstakes winner in the Editorial Excellence Award. Winners were to be honored Oct. 22 at Inland's 105th annual meeting at Chicago's Drake Hotel. The other writing award winners were:

Class C (25,001 to 100,000 circulation): first, Gary (Ind.) Post-Tribune; second, Traverse City (Mich.) Record-Eagle. Class B (10,001 to 25,000): first, Marion (Ind.) Chronicle Tribune; second, Rock Island (Ill.) Argus. Class A (10,000 and under): first, Canon City (Colo.) Daily Record; second, Paxton (Ill.) Record.

Class C: first, Lafayette (Ind.) Journal & Courier; second, Chicago Southtown Economist. Class B: first, Hays (Kan.) Daily News and Ottumwa (Iowa) Courier; no second. Class A: first, Wheaton (Ill.) Daily Journal; second, Canon City (Colo.) Daily Record.
