DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Vargas Llosa Takes on Sex
DOC.NOTE: Eds: T is upper case in ``Conservation in The Cathedral.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mario Vargas Llosa has said goodbye to the rigid world of politics to publish an erotic novel that caused him trouble during his quest for Peru's presidency. Few political hopefuls would admit to writing about an adolescent's affair with his stepmother. Vargas Llosa said he did not write ``In Praise of the Stepmother'' (Farrar, Strauss and Giroux, $18.95) as a provocation. It's just that there was no reason for him to hide his literary views. ``It was used against me in the campaign,'' he said of the novel, which is being released in English this month. It was published last year in Spanish. ``Announcers on television would warn people, `Get your children out of the room,' then they would read sections of the book,'' he said. The book, however, did not cost him the election, Vargas Llosa said. A Peruvian-Japanese engineer, Alberto Fujimori, defeated him because of differences in their plans for Peru's bankrupt economy. John Updike called Vargas Llosa's loss a gain for literature. Reviewing the novel in the New Yorker, Updike said ``Praise'' would have been a startling document in ``our erotically retrenched nation.'' ``Not only would an American Presidential candidate not have written it but the National Endowment for the Arts wouldn't have given it a grant,'' Updike wrote. In an interview from a 38th-floor hotel room overlooking Manhattan's Central Park, Vargas Llosa said his life and works often got in the way of his short political career. ``As a writer, you are your own master. The political life is very different - bodyguards, rigid schedules. Not having control of your life, becoming very dependent. It was a great effort just to get used to this...'' Vargas Llosa said several of his earlier novels, including ``Conversation in the Cathedral,'' ``The Green House'' or ``The Real Life of Alejandro Mayta,'' advocated a more radical political change than his moderate political campaign offered. ``In politics, I think the reformist path is the best of all possible evils,'' he said. ``But not so in art. I am for the excess. In art, I think it is important to open the door, release all that is repressed in life. It is very dangerous to do this in real life.'' ``In Praise of the Stepmother'' tells the story of Don Rigoberto, an art-loving insurance executive; his wicked but cherubic son, Alfonsito; and the stepmother, Dona Lucrecia. Chapters alternate between the destruction of the family and erotic fantasies based on paintings by Titian, Jordaens and Fra Angelico. ``The erotic world is a world in which you add art to the physical world,'' he said. ``So there are two levels in which the love relationship develops, the realistic one and the imaginary one.'' Vargas Llosa wrote it in 1987 and early 1988 and then ``got rid of it.'' ``You write trying to create something that you don't know what it is until it's finished. You fight your own ghosts. You find something that opens mysterious doors in your own personality.'' Updike called the book an ``impish and delicate yet fiercely serious work'' about ``the dark complexity of sex.'' Vargas Llosa's most popular novel, ``Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter,'' also dealt with a romantic relationship between a younger man and an older woman. The author only smiled when asked about the role of past experiences in his writing. A film version of ``Aunt Julia,'' renamed ``Tune in Tomorrow'' and starring Peter Falk, opened last month in U.S. theaters. It will broaden the author's exposure in the United States, and Vargas Llosa said he was pleased with the adaptation. ``They have changed the story, and they have moved it from Lima to New Orleans, but the atmosphere is quite similar. I think it will do well.'' However, Vargas Llosa was uncertain how his new novel would fare in the ``complex American society.'' ``On one hand, there is something that is great in this society - its freedom, its possiblity to change things. At the same time, it is difficult to understand these movements to repress. ``What is so obvious is that it is not books or art that corrupt men; it is men who corrupt an idea by trying to censor it. Repression won't solve it, it will just come out in more dangerous ways, such as violence.'' Vargas Llosa, saying he would ``never again'' enter politics and staying out of Peru since his electoral loss in June, says he has salvaged something from his two-year quest for the presidency - material for his next novel. ``I had this idea before going into politics - how violence, little by little, can take over society. This is something that fascinates and terrifies me. Violence has become the atmosphere in which the society breeds.'' He mentioned the increase in drugs, which has ripped apart societal structure in Peru, Colombia and - to a lesser extent - much of the developed world. In his two-month runoff campaign against Fujimori, more than 100 of his campaign workers were killed, mostly by Maoist Shining Path guerrillas intent on disrupting the elections. When asked about a Rand Corp. report predicting that the Maoist guerrillas would take over Peru within two years, Vargas Llosa paused for a moment and leaned back on his sofa: ``I wouldn't prophesize, but you must recognize that the increase in violence is terrifying.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Nov. 2-4
For Release Weekend Editions, Nov. 2-4, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Snow Relishes Performing for Troops
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Country music pioneer Hank Snow, who performed for American soldiers in Korea and Vietnam, would be eager to entertain U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf if he were younger. The 76-year-old Snow established himself as one of country music's ambassadors by making several overseas tours to perform for U.S. armed forces between 1950 and the mid-1960s. Besides Korea and Vietnam, Snow also sang for military personnel in Germany, France, Norway, Italy, England and Japan. ``If I was 20 years younger, I'd jump at the chance to go over again,'' said Snow, celebrating his 40th anniversary on the Grand Ole Opry country music show. ``I've seen what good it can do. When we entertained over there before, the amount of good you could feel you were doing made you want to go back. They just needed a touch of home. ``It's one of the things that stays in my memory. This was a great experience, one that money couldn't buy. It was the most important part of my life as far as entertaining is concerned.'' While in Korea, he offered to write letters if soldiers would give him the names and addresses of their loved ones. He expected to get a few hundred, but 7,000 were turned in. When he returned to the United States, a secretary was needed to send form letters to the soldiers' relatives. ``Someone came up to me at the Opry not long ago and thanked me for the letter I wrote to his mother,'' Snow recalled. Snow, known as ``the singing ranger'' because he prefers cowboy attire, has been a performer for more than 40 years. RCA Records has just released the ``Hank Snow Collector's Series,'' reissuing eight of his records. Bear Records of Germany is putting out every song he ever recorded. This is a mammoth undertaking. Snow has sold an estimated 70 million records and made more than 100 albums. His ``I'm Moving On,'' which he wrote, was No. 1 on the country music charts for almost a year in 1950. Emmylou Harris, one generation younger, brought it back with her version six years ago. The song, about boarding a train to leave a wayward lover, has been recorded by about 60 other performers. The ``Hank Snow Collector's Series'' includes ``I'm Moving On,'' his version of the pop music classic ``Sentimental Journey'' and ``Today I Started Lovin' You Again,'' which was a hit for Kenny Rogers. Snow has had more than 40 songs in the Top 10 of the country music charts. His heyday was the '50s and '60s. He was born in Liverpool, Nova Scotia. He left home at age 12 and became a cabin boy on a freighter for four years. As a teen-ager, he used $30 in earnings from a two-week stint unloading salt from a ship to buy his first guitar. He moved to the United States in the '40s and began singing in Dallas. Country music star Ernest Tubb helped him get a spot on the Grand Ole Opry in 1950 and he's performed on the show ever since. ``I think it gets in your blood,'' Snow said about the Opry in an interview in his office at his modest home in suburban Nashville. ``Sometimes you say, `I'm tired of going to the Opry.' But if you didn't go over there and laid off for three or four weeks, you'd want to get back there again.'' A proud and plain-spoken man, Snow has been involved in several ontroversies during his long career. In 1986, he had a dispute with CBS-TV and the Opry. He refused to appear on a TV special saluting the Opry because he felt slighted when asked to sing only one verse of ``I'm Moving On.'' In another tiff, he has said he lost $2 million to $3 million in royalties because he did not have an attorney and accountant to keep track of the amount due him from RCA Records. He ordered an audit and feels it contributed to the fact RCA dropped him from its recording roster in 1980 after 45 years under contract. Snow and Col. Tom Parker, Elvis Presley's longtime manager, operated a talent agency in the '50s, and Snow has long claimed that he was not compensated fairly as Presley's agent. Looking back on his lengthy career, Snow is uncomfortable when called a legend or pioneer. ``There are legends, living legends, dead legends and all that. I don't go for that. I appreciate it when people say I'm a pioneer, but you have to earn that right.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Nov. 2-4

DOC.TEXT: In the Soviet Unon's most radical departure from Communist economics in 70 years, the legislature has voted to transform the economy into the market-oriented system advocated by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But a rift with the country's largest republic threatened to disrupt the effort which was approved Friday. Gorbachev's plan to free most prices of government control, end most government monopolies and encourage free enterprise is an ambitious outline for ending chronic shortages of food and housing, integrating the Soviet Union in the world market and encouraging people to work harder and enjoy the benefits. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Michael Milken stammered and rose from his desk after learning speculator Ivan Boesky was cooperating with the government's insider trading investigation in late 1986, a Milken subordinate testified. Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond salesman Terren Peizer described on Friday a climate of fear after the Boesky deal. The comments came during a pre-sentencing hearing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on a series of alleged crimes the government says were committed by Milken beyond those to which he has pleaded guilty. Prosecutors hope to convince Wood that Milken deserves a stiff punishment. --- DETROIT (AP) - Executives of General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union have signed a new three-year labor contract guaranteeing the wages of about 300,000 U.S. workers. GM Chairman Robert Stempel and UAW President Owen Bieber signed the documents Friday. Bieber is now expected to turn up the heat on Chrysler Corp. when bargaining with the No. 3 automaker intensifies next week. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Midway Airlines says it will sell off its unprofitable hub operations at the Philadelphia International Airport and end 61 daily flights by April 30 as it faces even greater losses due to fuel prices. The selloff, said Midway President Thomas Schick said, would cost his airline about $30 million. David Hinson, Midway chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement that the sale was necessary to stabilize the airline's financial condition and return it to profitability. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The consumer group Public Citizen has admitted it made a mistake in putting the ITT Hartford Insurance group on a list of five insurance companies it said could fail in the event of a recession. ITT Hartford said it was Public Citizen, not the insurance company, that ``flunked the test.'' The consumer group, affiliated with Ralph Nader, on Friday issued a statement acknowledging the error. Public Citizen said Monday that the Hartford, Aetna, American International Group, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty each failed four of six tests that it used to measure vulnerability to insolvency. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Senate backers of a bill to regulate cable TV prices say the compromise measure is dead for the year, after they failed to move it to a floor vote. Friday's defeat marks the end of three weeks of private negotiations between Sens. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and Tim Wirth, D-Colo., to soften language in the bill to prevent cable programmers from making exclusive contracts with cable system operators. It also culminated a two-year effort to meld two dozen cable bills into a law that would address rising concerns about shoddy service and cable charges, which have risen 43 percent in the last three years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Lawmakers who for more than a year have wanted to use trade to punish China's repression of democracy say they have pretty much given up the idea in the waning days of the Congressional session. The House voted 247-174 Thursday to overrule President Bush's decision in May to allow China to retain ``most favored nation'' status. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he disagreed with Bush's decision, but Mitchell said supporters lacked the two-thirds majorities needed in both houses to override what administration officials said would be a sure veto by Bush. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An international panel said it would include in a list of chemicals to be reviewed in 1992 a drug that could induce cows to give more milk. The drug, bovine somatotropin or BST, is still under review by the Food and Drug Administration for possible use by U.S. dairy farmers. Tests indicate the synthetic hormone could increase a cow's milk production by 10 percent to 25 percent. The Codex Committee on Residues of Veterinary Drugs in Foods met in closed session Friday. --- BOSTON (AP) - More bad news surfaced for one of New England's largest banks. The Bank of New England Corp. reported a loss of $123.2 million or $1.78 a share in the third quarter, due largely to a $100 million provision for possible credit losses. The company blamed its losses on the slowdown of the New England economy, worsened by rising oil prices and Middle East uncertainties. ---

Stocks advanced Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 68.07 to 2,520.79 on top of Thursday's 64.85-point gain. The dollar finished stronger in domestic trading. Oil futures skidded. Precious metal futures prices rose for the third straight day. Copper futures rose sharply; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybean were mixed. Bond prices rose.

DOC.HEAD: From Blades To Shades, Forschner Group Expands Product Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: The company that brought the all-purpose Swiss Army pocketknife to America is now offering products that do more than open wine bottles, strip wire or gut fish. Forschner Group Inc., the U.S. distributor of the multiblade red knives with silver crosses, has expanded into the sunglass and watch business with its new subsidiary, Swiss Army Brands Ltd. The company is banking on consumers' familiarity with the Swiss Army name to get these products off the ground. ``There is a high-quality imagery associated with the knife,'' said Forschner President James Kennedy. ``It has always been known as a useful, utilitarian product and we were able to transfer that to the watch's image.'' Sales of the Swiss Army Brand watch totaled around $4 million since its debut last fall, double the projections, said Kennedy. The simple watch with a large face, big numbers and black strap was designed in the United States and manufactured in Switzerland. It sells for $95 retail. The Swiss Army Brand aviator-style sunglasses were introduced in April and sell for around $115 retail. But sales have been disappointing thus far, totaling just $385,000 in the first nine months of this year. Kennedy said the glasses came out too late to be included in many retailers' summer catalogs. The new products are targeted at upscale, outdoorsy types who frequent camping and hunting stores. The company does minimal advertising and its products are sold by exclusive retailers such as Hoffritz for Cutlery, Eddie Bauer and Hammacher Schlemmer. The Swiss-based Victorinox Cutlery Co., founded in 1884 by Karl Elsener, developed the original Swiss Army knife in 1891. Its patent on the pocketknife expired in 1908, and since then, many imitations have surfaced. About half the soldiers in the Swiss Army carry Victorinox knives. The rest are manufactured by their rival, Wenger, which also sells Swiss Army knives in the United States through retailers like K Mart and L. L. Bean. Victorinox makes 295 different models of the knife, but Forschner sells only about 50 in the United States. The ``Scientist'' model features a magnifying glass, while the ``Tinker'' contains two can openers and a Phillips screwdriver. A saw, pliers, scissors and a file are part of the ``Craftsman.'' Forschner became a distributor for the pocketknives shortly after World War II. The company started out 135 years ago in New Britain selling only butcher scales. In the 1930s, it added Victorinox butcher knives to its line. The butcher knives, sold almost exclusively to slaughterhouses and restaurants, accounted for 27 percent of Forschner's business last year. Another 23 percent came from Swiss Army knives printed with corporate logos. The other half came from the pocketknives. When Kennedy came to work at the company in 1975, it decided to stop selling butcher scales and to halt sales of the pocketknives to its 40 wholesalers. Forschner began selling the pocketknives directly to specialty retail stores. Imitation knives have plagued Forschner for years, but when knockoffs of the watches started showing up in stores for $20-$25, the company took immediate action against some Asian manufacturers for violating trade laws. Since the knockoffs were not manufactured in Switzerland, the companies making them were not allowed to call them Swiss-style or Swiss-like and were prohibited from using the trademark Swiss Cross. Such restrictions also have limited Forschner's growth. ``We have to have all our products made in Switzerland, where the factories are small, inefficient and expensive,'' Kennedy said. He added that the strength of the Swiss franc has added to his purchase price. Nonetheless, in the past 16 years, Forschner's profits have grown 4,000 percent. Last year, Forschner sold $33 million worth of knives, up from less than $1 million in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Under Siege By Union Negotiators, Stockholders, Car Buyers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Holding the battle lines these days at Chrysler Corp.'s headquarters is tough work. Executives of the financially struggling automaker are fighting on a number of fronts, any one of which can explode in their faces. Profits are sinking. Talk of some sort of merger deal with Fiat SpA won't go away. Criticism for lacking a new mid-size car persists. In some quarters at least, Chairman Lee Iacocca's once magnetic personality is weakening. But all's not dark and gloomy at the nation's No. 3 automaker. Chrysler has about $4 billion in cash to weather tough times. Much of the Fiat speculation centers on joint production of a vehicle that would cut costs for both companies. Chrysler's new minivan has been well received in showrooms. The company's advertisements featuring Iacocca stressing safety have coincided with increased American consumer demand for safe cars. Perhaps the company's most immediate problem is the United Auto Workers union. On the surface, the confrontation between Chrysler and the union representing about 63,000 of its hourly and salaried workers seems intractable. The UAW vows there will be no deviation for Chrysler from the contract it has reached with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. Some UAW members are wearing buttons saying ``Pattern or Picket.'' Chrysler insists the pattern agreement is too expensive. The company wants relief from what it calls spiraling health-care costs. But as in most negotiations, there's room to maneuver. ``The issue here isn't concessions,'' Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said in a recent interview. ``The issue here is moderation. ``Can we have some flexibility and move the furniture around in a way that is both appropriate and proper for the UAW and its membership and constructive for the company?'' he said. Chrysler is involved in a cost-cutting program begun in October 1989 designed to remove $2.5 billion in costs by next June. Despite those reductions, the company is expected to report later this month that losses during the third quarter will erase the $251 million it earned in the first six months of this year. The fourth quarter promises to be better, but some Wall Street analysts are wondering whether Chrysler will have made any money by year-end. Chrysler and Fiat executives have acknowledged they are discussing a range of associations, including joint development of the ``JJ'' small sport-utility vehicle, vehicle distribution arrangements and a Fiat investment in Chrysler. Through the first nine months of this year, Fiat held 14.3 percent of the Western European new car market, second only to Volkswagen AG's 15.1 percent. Third was Peugeot SA of France at 12.9 percent; GM and Ford European subsidiaries each held 11.7 percent, tied for fourth place. Chrysler held less than 1 percent of the market. Before Fiat would consider buying part of Chrysler, Fiat USA Inc. spokesman Gualberto Ranieri said, the company has other more pressing projects, including expansion into the emerging Eastern European vehicle market. Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, has said the Chrysler-Fiat talks must reach a conclusion soon, possibly within a month. Chrysler spokeswoman Karen Stewart said earlier this month the company had no reaction to Agnelli's comments. ``There's nothing new to report,'' she said. Although the specific nature of any joint vehicle hasn't been announced, it's unlikely to be a new mid-size car, seen as badly needed by Chrysler. As plans stand now, Chrysler will bring out a new high-volume sedan, codenamed ``LH,'' in late 1992 for the 1993 model year. Company officials have said the ``LH'' is likely to look like the Eagle Optima car Chrysler has been exhibiting at auto shows. If that proves true, it would point Chrysler in a new design direction away from the officially dead, but not gone, K-cars that helped pull the company away from bankruptcy in the early 1980s. No matter what cars or trucks come off drawing boards, Chrysler still must sell them. That's where Iacocca comes in. Bidwell concedes Iacocca's image may have slipped a bit in Detroit and Washington from overexposure. Chrysler research says that's not so elsewhere. ``According to their research, which is repetitive, in Dubuque (Iowa) and places like that, the image is still pretty good,'' Bidwell said. In Dubuque, sales manager Perry Pickel of Wilson Brothers Dodge agreed. ``It's not as strong as it was,'' he said, ``but I don't think it has lost as much as people think.''

DOC.HEAD: Restaurant Chain Tries Braille Menus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Shoney's Inc. is providing braille menus in 42 Tennessee restaurants and, if there's a demand, plans to insert the special menus in its 715 restaurants across the country. The concept is public service - and public relations. But if it generates a profit, that's all right too, company executives say. Making the notion work is another matter. ``The difficulty in preparing braille menus in one place and sending them out is you'll still have price variations. Prices in Dothan, Ala., might be a little cheaper than in New York City,'' said Oral Miller, executive director of the 40,000-member American Council of the Blind in Washington. McDonald's introduced braille menus and large-type menus 10 years ago and is updating the project. ``McDonald's didn't do a real good job at publicizing those menus. As a result, many blind people didn't know they existed. In many cases when a blind person asked for it, because the menu is such a rare thing, many employees didn't know they had it,'' Miller said. ``So, it's essential for the restaurant to keep the employees informed.'' Shoney's marketing director Jeff Sowell came up with the idea after talking with a visually impaired worker about placing orders in restaurants. ``He said `I know what I want or I take a sighted person with me,''' Sowell said. Problems arise when a busload of blind customers shows up at the family restaurant with only a driver or a couple other people who can see, Sowell said. ``We're just doing it in the Middle Tennessee right now as a test. Two menus at each location - two for breakfast, two for lunch and two for dinner,'' he said. The company spent less than $5,000 to have the six-page menus converted to braille, produced at the Tennessee School for the Blind and delivered to the midstate restaurants. Shoney's executives will decide within three months whether to extend the braille menus nationwide. ``I don't foresee us dropping it in this market because there is a large market in Nashville for visually impaired people,'' Sowell said. Such menus will make ordering easier for many blind people, but only 40 percent of the legally blind people in the country can read braille, Miller said. A volunteer network based in Austin, Texas - Sight through Helping Hands - provides braille menus for some McDonald's, Pizza Hut and Mr. Gatti's restaurant groups along with restaurants in the Marriott chain. A group of students from Tennessee School for the Blind prepared the Shoney's menus on computers, and Shoney's donated $1,750 to the school for computer classes. ``Of course, when you hear a menu there's no way in the world you can remember all the items and the prices. So, this is a way for them to read and feel more comfortable,'' said Harbans Dhindsa, the school's coordinator of special education.

DOC.HEAD: Students Give Channel One's News Spots A Failing Grade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Channel One, the news network for students, already has received mixed marks for running commercials. Now students at a high school here have staged a boycott against it after giving the news show a failing grade. ``Students feel Channel One is just another kid show, a senior high `Sesame Street,''' says Fargo North High School Principal Ed Raymond. Some 600 Fargo North students took part in the two-day boycott of Channel One last month by refusing to go to the classes showing the newscast. The following week, dozens took their concerns to the Fargo School Board. The matter was referred to a three-member curriculum committee, which is to make its recommendations Tuesday. Channel One always has been controversial since Whittle Communications announced its plan to provide free video equipment to schools that agreed to air the daily television news program, with two minutes of commercials wedged in each 10-minute program. Gary Belis, a spokesman for Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., says Fargo North High School is an aberration. ``Out of 4,000 schools on line, this is the only one raising a protest,'' he says. Raymond says the school, which has 850 students, needs the satellite dish, central control panel and 36 video monitors Whittle provides. But some students say they feel they were used as a bargaining chip. Jared Eide, a senior at Fargo North, says students are eager to learn more about current events, but Channel One presnnts the news in 30-second sound bites. ``There are only 2{ minutes of hard news,'' says Eide. ``You get more out of reading the newspaper headlines.'' Student body president Erika Hovland voted in favor of Channel One last spring after viewing a promotional program. But she said it's been a disappointment and she now wants to switch channels. Educational programming is also available from the Public Broadcasting Service, Cable News Network and other channels. Eide and Hovland say students are willing to raise the $30,000 needed to replace the equipment if they are allowed a choice of programs. A survey last spring by the Fargo Education Association showed 347 teachers opposed Channel One and 109 favored it. Most, like Joan Humphrey, rejected its commercialism. ``I just think it's unethical to close the classroom door when commercials are being aired,'' she says. Most Channel One commercials get titters from Humphrey's senior English students. An ad for acne medication gets a collective groan. ``I think everyone would agree that programming without commercials is better than one with commercials,'' Belis says. ``The problem is, how do you pay for it?'' Eleven North Dakota high schools in Fargo, Bismarck and Jamestown now tuning into Channel One. Whittle recently approached the Dickinson School District about becoming the 12th.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Of Oil Independents Finds Optimism And Higher Price Expectations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices should drop after the Persian Gulf crisis ends, but probably will still wind up higher than they were before the invasion of Kuwait, says a survey of independent oil executives. The survey, released Sunday, also indicates independent producers are not changing their plans based on current oil prices. Two-thirds of the 203 executives responding to The Roper Organization survey said they were ``somewhat optimistic'' about the long-term future of the petroleum industry, while another 20 percent said they were ``very optimistic.'' Seventy-three percent of the executives said the Gulf crisis will result in a permanent increase in the price consumers pay for oil; 94 percent said the crisis will spur interest in non-oil energy sources; and 97 percent said the demand for domestically abundant natural gas will increase because of the higher oil prices. While 80 percent said the crisis would increase North American energy insecurity, 66 percent of the executives said the conflict will not result in decreased use of oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cartel. Nevertheless, the executives said the crisis hasn't changed their plans: -71 percent said they have not increased production since Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait and 73 percent said they had not increased capital spending. -80 percent said they have not changed strategic planning since the invasion. ``The survey shows that though people are optimistic, they haven't changed their strategy because of what's happened in the Middle East,'' said Grant Porter, a managing director of Lehman Brothers, which sponsored the survey along with the Independent Petroleum Association of America. ``What the industry needs right now is stability,'' Porter said. ``They are not making planning decisions based on $40 a barrel oil. They may enjoy the cash flow, but they're not making plans.'' Asked where they thought the price of oil would stabilize once the crisis ends, 38 percent said it would settle at $25 a barrel, and 30 percent said it would return to between $21 and $24 a barrel. A barrel holds 42 gallons of oil On Friday, the near-term contract for light sweet crude, the benchmark U.S. grade, fell to $33.79 a barrel, down $3.01 from Thursday and $5.81 from a week ago. The price, which hit a record $41 a barrel earlier this month, was less than $20 in July, the month before the invasion. Porter said some people may be surprised at results showing that of the 92 executives who said their companies are reviewing new exploration areas as a result of the crisis, 89 of them, or 97 percent, were looking at the 48 contiguous states. In other findings, only 4 percent said they were considering expanding into alternative energy forms. The survey was conducted by telephone in September and has a margin of error of plus or minus 7 percent. The Independent Petroleum Association of America, meeting this week in Dallas, represents 10,000 independent crude and natural gas explorers and producers. Independents drill about 85 percent of all wells in the United States and produce about 31 percent of the domestic oil and 60 percent of natural gas production.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Economy is Evident as Bankers Open Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Veterans of American Bankers Association conventions say the lavish social events have largely disappeared this year as the banking industry meets amid soft earnings in a weakening economy. ``It's more, let's take care of business,'' said one longtime conventioneer. The attendance of about 4,500 is down 18 percent from last year as some banks decided to forego the meeting to cut expenses. There also are fewer exhibitors. Those who did come apparently are displaying a degree of frugality. At a makeshift marketplace on the convention floor, vendors selling modestly-priced items were doing far better than those with big-ticket goods. ``If they keep buying, we'll have to make more,'' said Darlene George of Newport Richy, Fla., who was selling linen and lace figurines. But Art LaBellman, an Orlando fur coat dealer, said Sunday he'd yet to make a sale. ``We had a lot of interest yesterday, but no sales,'' LaBellman said. ``But we're selling an expensive luxury item. Someone's not going to spend $500, $1,000, $2,000 very quickly.'' The banking industry has been racked by a spate of losses or reduced earnings caused in part by a decline in the economy and fallout from bad loans. Those problems are much on the minds of those attending the five-day ABA meeting, which continues through Wednesday. But the word here, repeated dozens of times over the first two days of the meeting, is that banking is nowhere near the type of crisis that engulfed the nation's savings and loan industry. ``I think banks are concerned. They're trying to find every avenue they can to cut back,'' said William S. Bushnell of Danielson Associates Inc., a consultant from Rockville, Md. ``But there are banks that are doing very well, thank you,'' said Bushnell, formerly a bank chairman in New Hampshire. ``Like everything else in this world, you hear about who's not doing well.'' Andrew C. Hove Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told a session on Sunday that bankers must emphasize to their customers that banking is much healthier than the S&L industry. Hove said that between 1985 and 1987, 600 of the nation's 2,400 thrifts had less than zero capitalization and those S&L's were holding $300 billion in assets. By comparison, he said, last year 81 of the nation's 13,000 banks had negative capitalization and those banks had only $11 billion in total assets, he said. ``Those are positive numbers,'' Hove said. Others are emphasizing that the banks are better capitalized and better regulated than the thrifts. Nevertheless, the slumping economy makes many banks vulnerable, said analyst Alex Sheshunoff of Austin, Texas. ``If we have a recession, which it looks like we're going to have, it will have an even greater impact because the country is so over-leveraged,'' said Sheshunoff, president of Sheshunoff & Co. ``There's no room to simply go ahead and prime the pump by telling banks to lend some more money.'' Government regulation also is commanding the attention of the bankers, with several seminars devoted to recent and expected changes in the system. Edward L. Yingling, executive director of the ABA's government relations group, said he expects at least a half dozen reform proposals to surface next year in Congress. Yingling said Sunday he anticipates major deposit insurance reform with new requirements for the amount of capital maintained by banks, restructuring of e products and services rules, changes in the S&L bailout legislation and a new interstate banking bill. ``Almost all the rules you are operating under could be changed in the next Congress,'' he said. ``Can something like this pass? No one knows the answer to it. There's going to be a real donnybrook in terms of the lobbying involved.''

DOC.HEAD: 777 Forerunner of 21st Century Planes, Industry Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: It's a late entry, but Boeing Co.'s new 777 jetliner should prove to be a strong seller and one of the aerospace giant's key products over the next decade, industry analysts say. ``In my way of thinking, it's the forerunner of the planes of the 21st century,'' says Paul Nisbet, who follows Boeing for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. ``I think we're in for an era of the `big twins' if you will.'' The two-engine 777, second in size to Boeing's four-engine 747-400, is the first all-new design by the Seattle planemaker in 12 years. Boeing also says the aircraft may be the basis of a new family of jets, and represents a change in philosophy in the way it develops planes. Last Monday, United Airlines became the first to order the jets, buying 34 777s and taking options on another 34. It also placed 30 orders and took 30 options on 747-400s. If it buys all 128 planes, the deal would be worth more than $22 billion, the largest commercial jet purchase ever. More orders may be on the way. All Nippon Airways says it is considering the 777 for a possible 30-plane purchase by the end of the year. Analyst Howard Rubel of Cyrus J. Lawrence in New York said he expects Boeing to receive about 100 777 orders in the near future. Nisbet said he thinks two or three orders may be placed by the end of the year and could help push the total value of Boeing's 1990 orders to more than $50 billion, a sixth consecutive record year. Still, that would be only a beachhead in one of the most fiercely competitive markets in commercial aviation: high capacity, medium- to long-range jets. Boeing thinks the market will be huge. Between now and 2005, it estimates, 10,000 commercial jets will be delivered with a total value of $626 billion in 1990 dollars. A quarter of those planes will be large-capacity aircraft, Boeing says, but will account for 43 percent of the dollar value - about $268 billion. The first 777 is to fly in 1994, with deliveries to customers the next year. That gives Boeing's two competitors, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Airbus Industrie, a long head start. McDonnell Douglas plans the first deliveries of its three-engine MD-11 by year's end, spokesman Donald Hanson says. It has 173 firm orders from 32 customers for the plane, a reworked successor to the DC-10. Airbus has firm orders for 88 of its four-engine A340 and 129 of the twin-engine A330. The A340 enters service in 1992 and the A330 the year after, spokeswoman Sandy Smith said. The two models are basically the same design, except for the number of engines. The A340-200 can carry 262 passengers in two classes 8,600 miles, the stretched A340-300 can carry 295 people 7,700 miles, and the A330 can take 335 passengers 5,400 miles. The MD-11 carries 293 passengers up to 8,000 miles, while the 777 will haul 360-390 passengers up to 4,800 miles. Chris Longridge, executive vice president for sales for Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, says it is studying a 300-320 passenger version of the 777 with a range of 7,200 miles. All three manufacturers say they have the best planes. All make advances in aerodynamics, avionics and cabin design and will be far more fuel-efficient and quieter than the DC-10s and Lockheed L-1011s they aim to replace. But Boeing might have an edge by getting into the game late, says analyst Bill Whitlow of Gallagher Capital Corp. in Seattle. With no deliveries until 1995, Boeing should be able to produce a more modern and economical plane, Whitlow says. Nisbet agreed. ``I think these big twins are going to be considerably more efficient and therefore more attractive,'' he said. ``I think the 777 is going to be the leader because of its size and expandability and it's somewhat later technology.'' The 777 will feature folding wingtips to fit in at more airport gates, extensive use of lightweight composite materials and a high-efficiency wing to let it take off with heavier loads under more adverse conditions. Longridge told a news conference last week he wasn't too concerned the plane will debut after his competitors'. The long lead time also dissipates short-term concerns about high fuel costs, Longridge said. Airlines have been hurt by fuel prices, Nisbet said, but if anything, it should spur them to buy more efficient planes.

DOC.HEAD: TBS Buys Rights To Televise 1,000 MGM-UA Films
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. has agreed to buy the rights to nearly 1,000 MGM-UA movies from Pathe Communications Inc. if Pathe can complete its attempt to buy the MGM-UA Communications Co. The l0-year license agreements cover classic films in the United Artists library as well as MGM films produced in 1985-1988 and some in 1989. In 1986, TBS paid $1.5 billion to buy the MGM library of films prior to May 1985. The package includes the first 16 James Bond movies and the ``Rocky'' through ``Rocky IV'' series. TBS and Pathe did not release the value of the agreements announced Sunday. TBS spokeswoman Kitsie Riggall said the value of the package was greater than a similar deal TBS made with Columbia Pictures last year for $22 million, but not nearly as expensive as the 1986 purchase of the MGM catalogue. The deal hinges on Pathe completing its purchase of MGM-UA. So far, Pathe has paid $353 million toward the purchase price of about 1.3 billion. Questions still surround how Pathe's principal, Giancarlo Parretti, will finance the remaining $900 million. The license agreements will allow TBS to show the films exclusively for 10 years on its cable television channels, WTBS Superstation and Turner Network Television. In addition to the James Bond and Rocky movies, the agreements cover movies such as ``Rainman,'' ``A Fish Called Wanda,'' ``Wargames'' and ``Yentl,'' as well as classics like ``West Side Story,'' ``The Good, The Bad and The Ugly,'' ``Annie Hall,'' ``Fiddler on the Roof,'' and ``Some Like It Hot.'' The agreements do not include any future MGM-UA productions.

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Accord Reached
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 8 grafs to provide additional details of what legislation would require, editing for transition; picks up 9th graf, Negotiators reached . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators reached a tentative agreement today on a wide-ranging clean air bill that will require factories, automakers and utilities to cut pollution dramatically over the next decade. The legislation, which toughens federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years, was expected to be formally approved by a House-Senate conference, possibly later today, and then go back to the two chambers for endorsement. The bill's controls, aimed at cutting urban smog and ridding the air of millions of pounds of toxic chemicals, are expected to touch on almost every sector of industry and cost the economy between $22 billion and $25 billion when all its provisions go into effect. Under the legislation, pollution from automobiles would be cut 30 percent to 60 percent, oil companies would be required to provide cleaner gasoline, industries would reduce the amount of toxic chemicals released into the air and about 100 cities would be ordered to meet federal air quality standards. The compromise bill retains a five-year, $250 million aid program for workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The White House had objected to financial assistance and had threatened to veto the bill if it were included. But the administration appeared to soften its opposition to the provision after language was included to keep the program from becoming too costly. White House aides when departing from the talks did not repeat their veto threat and congressional sources said they doubt President Bush would scuttle the long-sought clean air legislation on that job-loss assistance issue. Congress began considering the clean air measure more than a year ago. Agreement on the last sections of the massive bill, which covers nearly 700 pages, came as House and Senate negotiators worked through most of night Sunday and much of the early morning today. Congressional leaders had wanted a bill by the end of the weekend to give it enough time to clear Congress before adjournment Friday. Negotiators reached agreement early Sunday on steep pollution cuts from electric power plants to reduce acid rain. Coal-burning power plants in 21 states will be directed to cut their sulfur dioxide releases almost in half, reducing annual emissions by about 10 million tons by the year 2001. The acid rain provision, which will hit utilities and consumers of electricity in the industrial Midwest the hardest, was the last major section of the bill to be resolved. Agreements had been reached previously that cut smog-causing emissions from automobiles and toxic chemical releases from factories and businesses. ``We're getting real protection. It meets the acid test on acid rain,'' said Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn., a leading proponent of acid rain curbs. The House-Senate conferees struggled since mid-July to resolve differences in separate bills approved earlier by the House and Senate. For weeks there was only modest progress, but the pace quickened in recent weeks with tentative agreements on key sections of the massive and technically complex legislation. Among the major provisions: - Utilities must reduce their annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons, or nearly in half, by installing ``scrubbers'' or switching to lw-sulfur coal. They also must cut nitrogen oxides, which also contribute to acid rain. - About 100 cities now considered to have unhealthy air must meet federal air quality standards within five to 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem, by reduce smog-causing emissions. Los Angeles is given 20 years. - Industry must install new pollution control equipment to cut the release of toxic chemicals into the air by 90 percent over the next decade. Only the steel industry's coke ovens would be given more time, until 2020. Even stronger pollution control measures could be required if the Environmental Protection Agency concludes that residents near a plant are not ensured ``an amble margin of safety'' from the risk of cancer. - Pollution from automobiles must be cut 30 to 60 percent through additional controls on tailpipe emissions and the phase-in of alternative fuel vehicles in fleets. A California pilot program also would require 300,000 personal cars powered by alternative fuels by 1999. It could be copied by other states. - Oil companies must provide cleaner gasoline blends in cities with the worst smog problems. The requirement is aimed at pushing the sale of ``reformulated'' gasoline or blends that include additives such as ethanol. The measures affecting factories, thousands of small businesses, automobiles and electric rates are acknowledged to be expensive. But environmentalists argue much of the cost will be offset by savings in health care because of the cleaner air. The controls on acid rain are expected to hit hardest in the industrial Midwest where electric utilities have the dirtiest plants because of their heavy reliance on high-sulfur coal. In final bargaining, Midwest lawmakers gained some additional credits that will ease the cost of installing new pollution devices, especially over the first five years. Negotiators, however, rejected efforts by the utility industry to roll back the sulfur dioxide reductions substantially, according to congressional sources. Early today, the House and Senate negotiators also agreed to impose for the first time air pollution restrictions on offshore oil rigs, an issue pressed by California lawmakers. Rigs off the Gulf of Mexico, however, are exempt. Meanwhile, a requirement to regulate visibility in federal parks was taken out of the bill. Several western senators had threatened to block the legislation on the Senate floor if it contained the visibility provision. The compromise calls for park visibility to be studied.

Stock prices were mixed today in a session marked by weakness in the blue chips. The Dow Jones average of 30 big-name industrials dropped 28.71 points to 2,492.08 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers held a narrow edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 604 up, 592 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 46.69 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said buyers were leery of chasing after the sharp runup in stock prices late last week, given persistent uncertainties over the business outlook. Government budget talks bogged down over the weekend, leaving a major problem facing investors unresolved. At the same time, however, brokers said the mood in the marketplace had been given a big lift by the recent downtyurn in oil prices. If inflationary pressures abate, many observers believe the Federal Reserve will be encouraged to relax its credit policy. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric fell 1{ to 54; Philip Morris ] to 48; Eastman Kodak } to 38|, and Coca-Cola 1 to 44}. Airline stocks advanced in response to the drop in oil prices. AMR gained \ to 48\; Delta Air Lines ~ to 61\, and UAL [ to 95}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .52 to 169.88. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .88 at 292.83.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Advance After Mixed Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices rose in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade as a rally led by the soybean complex overcame selling interest linke to the advancing harvest. Soybeans rallied modestly amid indications the Soviet Union bought up to 50,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal last week. There was no confirmation of a sale. Harvest pressure limited the gains, analysts said. ``We had real good harvest weather over the weekend and more of the same is expected this week,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. A weekly government report scheduled for release after today's close probably will show the harvest about 50 percent complete and still lagging behind the normal pace, he said. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64} a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.30} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $1.24{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 7 cents higher with November at $6.16 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of two Agriculture Department reports due out after the close: the quarterly cattle-on-feed report and the monthly USDA cold-storage report, which will provide an update on frozen pork belly stocks. Live cattle futures were .30 cent to .37 cent lower with December at 76.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .25 cent lower with October at 86.82 cents a pound; hog futures were .52 cent to .70 cent lower with December at 53.45 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.55 cents to 1.77 cents lower with February at 65.40 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Export Prices Cut by $6 a Barrel; Third Cut in a Week
DOC.TEXT: Egypt cut its oil export prices by $6 a barrel on Monday, reflecting a possible easing in the Persian Gulf crisis. It was Egypt's largest drop since the crisis began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The reduction was the second in two days and brought Egypt's prices $12 a barrel below levels a week ago. Prices last month reached close to $40 a barrel. A senior oil ministry official said the drop reflects the increasing possibility of a peaceful end to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He also said prices were driven down by indications that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is ready to release some foreign hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait. The new prices are $26.30 a barrel for the top-quality Khalig el-Zeit and Ras el-Bihar; $26 a barrel for the benchmark Gulf of Suez; $25.15 a barrel for Belayim; $24 a barrel for Ras Badran; and $23.70 a barrel for Ras Ghareb. Egypt is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries but generally sets its prices according to OPEC policies and world market conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chief Repeats Call for More Bank Capital
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, repeating a call he has made the last two years, told bankers at their annual convention today they must increase their capital base if the industry is to thrive. Greenspan declined to use the forum of the American Bankers Association convention to deliver any major policy statement. He left the Orange County Convention Center immediately after his speech and refused to answer reporters' questions. He said capital was a key to survival in the high-tech age. ``During the past year, as events have unfolded around the world, we have been continually reminded that capital is critical to the stability and competitiveness of the banking industry,'' Greenspan said in an address that primarily focused on the history of check-clearing technology. Greenspan's call for more capital repeated a theme he has brought to the past two ABA conventions and echoed concerns on the matter that have been expressed here during the first three days of the five-day gathering. Greenspan said changing technology has broad implications for the banking business. He said developments will eventually give banks more competition. ``The creation and delivery of financial services appear to depend to a greater and greater extent on technology that will not be the exclusive preserve of any single firm or industry,'' Greenspan told the bankers. He said if competing businesses have equal footing in technology, a strong capital base could be the factor that ensures survival. ``Business may well flow to firms that can combine these services with efficient and low cost access to credit and credit markets,'' Greenspan said. ``This in turn will require a strong capital base.''

DOC.HEAD: Carbide Earnings Drop 35 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. announced today third-quarter earnings fell 35 percent due to rising energy prices and a soft market for chemicals. The company said it earned $91 million, or 63 cents a share, on sales of $2.2 billion in the three months ended Sept. 30. That compared with earnings of $139 million, or 98 cents per share, on sales of $2.1 billion for the same 1989 period. The earnings loss was partly blamed on rising prices of energy used to produce chemicals, said Robert D. Kennedy, chairman of Union Carbide. The cost of crude oil and other fossil fuels has risen sharply since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August. Union Carbide primarily uses liquid natural gas to produce its chemicals, spokesman Thomas F. Sprick said, although some of its plants are equipped to use oil. Kennedy said the price for raw materials and general economic weakness ``will result in further pressures on margins and the need for continuing controls on capital spending and costs.'' He said third-quarter earnings included a non-recurring gain of 14 cents per share from the sale of the polysilicon business of Union Carbide's Chemicals and Plastics Company Inc. to Komatsu Electronic Metals C., Ltd. The gain was partly offset by non-recurring charges totaling 7 cents per share associated with several cost-reduction programs. In addition, costs associated with a power outage at Union Carbide's Taft, La., site were estimated at 4 cents per share. For the first nine months of 1990, earnings dropped 43 percent. For that period, earnings totaled $301 million, or $2.10 cents a share, on sales of $6.5 billion. That compared with earnings of $526 million, or $3.74 a share, on sales of $6.6 billion for the same 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Jumps By 33
DOC.TEXT: Texas, New Mexico and Oklahoma led an increase of 33 to 1,089 in the number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States, a widely-watched drilling industry index said Monday. The toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported the latest count compared with the year-ago tally of 992. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. In the most recent total, Texas gained 17 rigs while Oklahoma and New Mexico each increased by nine. North Dakota showed the biggest decline of six.

DOC.HEAD: American Exploration Acquiring Conquest Exploration in $160 Million Deal
DOC.TEXT: American Exploration Co. on Monday announced it was acquiring another Houston-based oil company, Conquest Exploration Co., in a deal estimated at $160 million. Under terms of the agreement, American Exploration, an independent oil and gas company, will pay $1.90 per share for about 12 percent of Conquest's common stock and exchange 0.44 shares of American Exploration common stock for each remaining share of Conquest stock. Conquest has more than 44.4 million shares outstanding. In addition, American Exploration will buy 5 million shares of Conquest voting preferred stock and assume Conquest's debt of about $55 million. The deal is subject to the approval of shareholders of both companies and regulatory agencies. ``The acquisition of Conquest will significantly increase our cash flow over the next few years and balance the very long life reserves added by our acquisition of Hershey Oil Corp. earlier this year,'' said Mark Andrews, chairman of American Exploration. At the end of 1989, Conquest had 6.4 million barrels of crude oil and 112 billion cubic feet of gas. Conquest also had 222,300 undeveloped acres in North America. American Exploration's reserves at the end of last year included 9.9 million barrels of crude oil and 184 billion cubic feet of natural gas, plus 84,700 undeveloped acres in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Narrowing Differences on Taxes, Medicare
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 3rd graf pvs, The meeting . . . to UPDATE with White House comment; picks up 4th graf pvs, ``The M&M...
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Congressional and White House negotiators resumed their search for compromise over new taxes on the rich and cuts in Medicare benefits today, hoping to end their budget stalemate by week's end. A weekend of dickering at the Capitol left bargainers ready to boost gasoline taxes by at least a nickel a gallon. Negotiators also seemed closer together on proposals for Medicare cuts and taxing the wealthy. The meetings also featured a well-timed walkout by an unusually talkative White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. But this morning, administration budget director Richard Darman returned to the deficit-reduction talks on Capitol Hill. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today that Sununu and Darman left Sunday's session to return to the White House to brief the president upon his return from a weekend at Camp David. He said Sununu's hasty departure did not signify White House pessimism or a new impasse. Fitzwater insisted that the White House aides were no longer part of the direct negotiations, but were only there ``as advisers'' so conferees will know what's acceptable to the White House. ``This is a matter between the House and Senate negotiators,'' he said. ``The M&M problem still remains,'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said today, referring to disagreements over taxing millionaires and cutting Medicare. ``It's a very difficult negotiation,'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, said as talks among congressional leaders ended late Sunday. ``Our problem is trying to put something together that passes both houses.'' Lawmakers planned to resume their search today for a compromise package that would also satisfy President Bush and allow Congress to go home for the year by week's end. Narrowing one important dispute, Democrats agreed to accept a nickel increase in the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, two cents less than Republicans wanted. The Senate last week approved a nine-cent boost, but the House insisted on no change. Divisions remained over how much new taxes the rich should pay. But the two sides seemed to be nearing an understanding - amazing progress considering Bush's opposition to any tax increases just a few months ago. Both sides were willing to boost the marginal rate on the wealthiest Americans - families with incomes above $180,000 a year - to 31 percent, up from the current 28 percent. And each party was willing to limit the deductions that people earning more than $100,000 can claim. But a big gap existed over a Democratic demand to levy an additional 7.5 percent surtax on those with incomes above $1 million. Republicans said they would not accept the plan, and instead offered a proposal - rejected by Democrats - to reduce deductions on incomes above $1 million by 8 percent. In addition, Republicans wanted to lower from 33 percent to 31 percent the tax rate on families with incomes between $80,000 to $180,000. Democrats opposed the idea. Negotiators also moved closer to each other on Medicare. Democrats would restrain the growth of the program by about $44 billion over the next five years. Republicans want the cuts to be $3 billion deeper. About one-fourth of the reductions would be borne directly by the 33 million handicapped and elderly people who use the program. Rostenkowski said the two sides were less than $2 billion apart on the precise cut to be aimed at beneficiaries. Democrats also want to boost the $51,300 wage cap from which Medicare taxes are deducted to $125,000. Republicans would increase the cap to $98,000. The 1.45 percent Medicare tax is part of the Social Security deduction. The final plan also is certain to include higher taxes on cigarettes, alcohol, luxury items such as furs, and airline tickets - elements that were in separate bills the House and Senate passed last week. Also destined for the final bill were cuts in crop payments to farmers, new fees for federal environmental tests and Coast Guard services, and stingier benefits for retired civil servants and veterans. Sunday afternoon, speaking to reporters just in time to make the evening's network news programs, the usually gruff Sununu complained that Democrats were dawdling rather than responding to the administration's offer to raise taxes on the nation's highest-income people. ``We're not going to negotiate with Democrats who can't come to an agreement among themselves,'' he said as he left the Capitol with White House budget chief Richard Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. ``This was a great offer.'' Top Republican lawmakers agreed, with Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., saying, ``These important negotiations have reached an impasse.'' But shortly after the gloomy GOP assessments, congressional leaders from both parties resumed bargaining in Dole's office. The deficit-reduction bill combined with other savings - mainly defense cuts and reduced interest payments on the debt - would lower the deficit by $40 billion for the 1991 fiscal year that began Oct. 1, and another $460 billion over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Extends KG&E Tender After 47 Percent of KG&E's Stock Pledged
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power and Light Co. on Monday extended its $875 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Co. stock until Nov. 30, keeping alive the first hostile takeover effort involving two major U.S. utilities. Kansas City Power and Light is offering $27 a share for the stock. The company said that as of the expiration of the previous tender period on Friday, 47 percent of Kansas Gas and Electric's common stock had been tendered. That is an increase from the 43.7 percent pledged when the previous tender period expired Sept. 14. Turner White, Kansas City Power and Light spokesman, said last week he expected the number of shares tendered to decrease this latest period because state and federal regulatory agencies have set 1991 hearings on the takeover, meaning there is no rush to make tender decisions. White has said the large percentage of shares tendered is a message from Kansas Gas and Electric stockholders urging the utility to drop its refusal to negotiate with Kansas City Power and Light. Kansas Gas and Electric's position remain unchanged. ``We're not really sure what the numbers mean,'' said Lyle Koerper, Kansas Gas spokesman. He said Kansas Gas and Electric still contends the offer is inadequate and illegal. He said the utility is negotiating with a third party and exploring all its options, including remaining independent.

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose today against major foreign currencies in light trading in Europe. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said that despite the dollar's rise, the U.S. currency still appears weak on fundamental economic factors. Dealers said they expected the dollar to trade within a narrow range before Wednesday's release of U.S. durable goods orders for September, a report that could provide more evidence about the state of the U.S. economy. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 126.25 Japanese yen from 125.25 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 126.00 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at midday at 126.25 yen. DOC.HEAD: 3M Reports 9.4 Percent Earnings Gain for Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co. said Monday its earnings rose 9.4 percent in the third quarter on continued growth in overseas sales. Net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 was $336 million, or $1.52 a share, compared with $307 million, or $1.37 a share, in the same quarter last year. Sales for the quarter rose 11.6 percent to $3.34 billion from $2.99 billion. Allen F. Jacobson, chairman and chief executive officer, said 48 percent of third-quarter sales came from overseas, where the company booked a 13 percent increase in the number of product units it sold. The company did not attach a dollar figure to the unit increase. ``Our international volume growth remains good, but probably won't match the third quarter's 13 percent gain,'' Jacobson said in a forecast of the fourth quarter. He said 3M expects annual sales and profits to exceed 1989 levels, but he said fourth-quarter results will be influenced by the sluggish U.S. economy. ``Our U.S. business began to feel the effects of the slowing U.S. economy in September,'' Jacobson said. The company said third quarter 1990 results also benefited from weakening of the U.S. dollar, which makes American products cheaper overseas, and a lower effective tax rate. For the first nine months, 3M's net income increased 6.4 percent to $1.01 billion, or $4.57 a share, up from $952 million, or $4.29 a share, in the same period last year. Sales rose 7.8 percent to $9.74 billion from $9.04 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Pump Prices Rise to Another Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to show average for latest week is at record and CORRECT size of latest jump in average gas price to 2.89 cents from 2.6 cents. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Retail gasoline prices rose 2{ cents per gallon on average during the past two weeks to another record high, a survey showed. The average pump price of gas for all grades, including taxes, was $1.4709 a gallon on Oct. 19, up 2.89 cents from the old high mark of $1.4420 at the previous sampling on Oct. 5, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey. The increase was about half the 5.8 cent rise per gallon from Sept. 21 to Oct. 5. In the latest survey, average retail prices were $1.3267 a gallon for self-serve regular, $1.3637 for regular unleaded and $1.5264 for premium unleaded, the Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gas stations indicated. Full-serve prices were $1.53.60 a gallon for regular, $1.5771 for regular unleaded and $1.7141 for premium unleaded. Motorists aren't the only ones being pinched, analyst Trilby Lundberg said. Retailers are feeling the squeeze as tee high prices and the end of the summer peak driving season reduce demand, she said. Retailers haven't been able to pass on all of the wholesale price increases to consumers because ``they are fighting for sales,'' Ms. Lundberg said. The dealers' margin, the difference between what they pay for gas and the price at which they sell it, stands at about 11 cents a gallon, down 2 cents a gallon from before the Middle East crisis, Ms. Lundberg said. The lost profit can amount to thousands of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Two Key Legislators Oppose Board of Trade Plan
DOC.TEXT: Two House Agriculture Committee subcommittee chairmen said Monday they oppose a Chicago Board of Trade plan to double the number of grain and soybean futures contracts available to speculators. Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said such changes should not be made until the effects of the 1990 farm bill are known. The bill, which establishes new planting options as part of government budget cuts, will dramatically change the commodities market, said Glickman, chairman of the wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee. He and Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., whose subcommittee oversees the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, have asked the commission to withhold approval of the Chicago Board of Trade plan until next year. The farm bill has been approved by a House-Senate conference committee, but awaits final votes in both chambers and the president's signature. Congress is expected to recess at the end of this month. Glickman and English said: ``At the very least we do not believe the commission should take final action on this proposal while Congress is in recess.'' In a letter to commission chairwoman Wendy Gramm, the congressmen said the Chicago Board of Trade plan appears to be response to pressure from big commodity trading fund managers. The funds ``have little interest in the price discovery or legitimate hedging functions of these markets and view them simply as another speculative venture to market to their customers,'' the congressmen's letter said. ``We do not believe the commission should approve the proposal until its proponents can verify with certainty that it will enhance the performance of these markets and allay fears that it will simply subject grain producers, marketers, and users to unnecessary, damaging price fluctuations,'' the letter said. Critics fear the change adopted by the Chicago Board of Trade directors would make the commodities market even more volatile than it is currently. They say the increased price uncertainty could be costly to farmers and others who deal on the exchange to hedge inventories and setting prices of produce.

DOC.HEAD: Reports More Than Eight-fold Increase in Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Pittston Co. said Monday its third-quarter earnings were more than eight times higher than a year earlier, when union miners were on strike against its coal subsidiary. Pittston reported earnings of $26.4 million, or 71 cents per share, in the period sending Sept. 30, compared with earnings of $3.1 million, or 8 cents per share, in the third quarter of 1989, the company said. For the January-September period, Pittston earned $35.6 million, or 96 cents per share, compared with net income of $22.6 million, or 60 cents per share, for the same period of 1989, Pittston said. Third-quarter revenues totaled $483.78 million, up 22 percent from $395.32 million in the 1989 third quarter. For the nine months, revelues totaled $1.36 billion vs. $1.23 billion, up 10.6 percent. Pittston's coal groups earned $14.4 million in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $9.8 million in the third quarter of a year earlier and net income of $13.3 million in the second quarter. Its coal subsidiaries are Pittston Coal Group Inc. and Pyxis Coal Group. For the first nine months of 1990, the coal groups earned $27.4 million compared with a loss of $1.7 million in the same period of 1989, Pittston said. About 1,700 United Mine Workers members in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky struck Pittston Coal Group Inc. for 10 months, ending in February. The strike also led to a six-week wildcat strike by up to 46,000 miners in other states. Third-quarter coal earnings were hurt by about $1.8 million from a short-term price reduction under the provisions of a long-term utility contract, said Paul W. Douglas, Pittston's chairman and chief executive officer. Pittston's three other subsidiaries - Burlington Air Express, Brink's and Brink's Home Security - also showed gains in third-quarter net income compared with the year-ago period.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, influenced by seasonal harvest pressure, rumors of Soviet grain purchases and volatile outside markets. Dry conditions were expected to continue for most of the week in the Midwest, where the corn and soybean harvest is believed to be near the halfway point, analysts said. Rumors of Soviet buying interest in U.S. corn and soybeans provided modest support to those markets. But a steep drop in crude oil and petroleum prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange tended to defuse inflation fears, which helped limit gains in grain prices, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.63 a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $1.24 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 5 cents higher with November at $6.11 a bushel.
