DOC.HEAD: Record Amount of Cocoa
DOC.TEXT: World stocks of cocoa have reached the highest level ever, following the sixth straight season of overproduction, the Internaional Cocoa Organization reported Monday. The 41-nation body estimated total inventories of cocoa at the end of the 1989-90 (October-September) season at 1.391 million tons. It put 1989-90 world production at 2.377 million tons - the second biggest figure ever recorded and 167,000 tons more than consumption. The all-time production high was 2.447 million tons reached in 1988-89, when the market was in surplus by a record 309,000 tons, the organization said. Malaysia and Indonesia achieved record cocoa harvests in 1989-90, which together with a bigger crop in Brazil helped to offset the declines in the Ivory Coast and most of the rest of Africa, organization estimates show. Traders said years of oversupply have weakened the world market, where prices earlier this year dropped to the lowest level in 13 years. They have recovered from the low point partly on worries that dry weather may have damaged new season African crop prospects.

DOC.HEAD: Phillips Earnings Double, Other Oil Companies Also Gain
DOC.TEXT: Phillips Petroleum Co. reported Monday its third-quarter earnings doubled partly because of rising oil prices, while Arco and Ashland Oil Inc. also reported sharp earnings gains. But all three companies said they did not pass the full cost of the higher prices to customers. ``During the quarter, crude oil prices increased about 53 cents a gallon while our wholesale gasoline prices only increased about 36 cents a gallon,'' said C.J. Silas, Phillips chief executive officer. Lodwrick M. Cook, chief executive of Arco, said the company ``made every effort'' to hold its gasoline prices down. Phillips earned $178 million or 72 cents a share on revenues of $3.43 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 30 The Bartlesville, Okla.-based company made $87 million, 36 cents a share, on revenues of $3.07 billion during the third quarter of 1989. For the nine months that ended Sept. 30, Phillips earned $542 million or $2.21 a share on revenues of $9.54 billion. That's up from $474 million or $1.95 a share on revenues of $9.46 billion in the year-ago period. Arco earned $462 million or $2.79 a share, on revenues of $4.82 billion in the third quarter, vs. $379 million or $2.19 a share on revenues of $3.71 billion in the same period a year ago. Los Angeles-based Arco froze retail gas prices for two weeks in August following President Bush's appeal for companies to hold retail prices down. Arco's third quarter results also include about $80 million from the settlement of a dispute over an offshore accident and sale of its Norwegian assets. For the nine months, Arco earned $1.45 billion or $8.70 a share on revenues of $13.1 billion, vs. $1.55 billion or $8.87 a share on revenues of $12 billion during the same period in 1989. Ashland earned $59 million or $1.06 a share, on revenues of $2.5 billion for the latest quarter, which ended its fiscal year. That was a sharp reversal from the same quarter in 1989, when Ashland lost $39 million or 71 cents a share, on revenues of $2.3 billion. Ashland closed its year with earnings of $182 million or $3.27 per share on revenue of $9.05 billion. In fiscal 1989, the company made $86.2 million or $1.55 a share on revenue of $8.54 billion. The Ashland, Ky.-based company reported gains from the sale of its Valvoline oil brand in the latest quarter. But the company said its Super America gasoline division showed lower profits because retail gas prices did not keep up with higher oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Fear Becoming Political Scapegoat in Wake of S&L Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Bankers' hands could be tied in the coming year by lawmakers bent on correcting the mistakes that led to the savings and loan crisis, a top industry official said Monday. Kelly Holthus, outgoing president of the American Bankers Association, warned his colleagues of congressional overreaction in a farewell speech to the organization's annual convention. ``The temptation for Congress to take drastic measures in the current political environment is strong,'' said Holthus, whose term expires Tuesday. ``All of us will have to work hard to make sure that commercial banks are not tarnished by the S&Ls' record. Otherwise, we'll surely find ourselves the victims of misguided legislation.'' Leaders of the banking industry say they expect a rash of legislation affecting their industry in the next Congress, and at this week's ABA convention they are firing up the lobbying machine. ``It's up to us to make sure that in politicians' zeal to correct a wrong - the banking industry doesn't end up battered instead,'' Holthus said. Several of the nation's top banks are having trouble because of the slowdown in the economy and fallout from bad loans. But those attending the ABA meeting are going to great lengths to distance themselves from the thrift ind yearly. ``Ninety-five percent of this package essentially is demanding serious sacrifice from everyone else, veterans, government employees, working families,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``We think it's fair to let millionaires pay their fair share.'' But GOP senators were ardently against the idea, arguing that imposing a surtax on some taxpayers would invie boosts later on for everyone. After days of bargaining, Democrats were considering other plans, which House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., described as ``infinitely changeable.'' The two sides were entertaining similar offers in other unresolved areas. They seemed near agreeing that the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax would increase by a nickel or perhaps slightly more. And while Democrats wanted to reduce the growth of Medicare by about $44 billion over the next five years, Republicans wanted to slash to be about $3 billion deeper. But participants emphasized that nothing had been settled in either of those areas. Democrats were saying the more taxes they could raise from the wealthy, the milder the Medicare reductions would be. ``M and M is still the problem, millionaires and Medicare,'' Panetta said. There were even hints that the gasoline tax might not be raised at all. Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich., said Gephardt told him it would be difficult for Democrats to achieve the 10 percent surtax on the wealthy, but indicated it might be possible to leave the gasoline tax alone. Last year, 65,000 families reported earning more than $1 million on their income-tax returns. Boosting tax rates on the wealthiest people would mean an increase for 600,000 families. Bargaining was also continuing over raising the $51,300 ceiling below which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is deducted from paychecks. Democrats want to boost the cap to $125,000, Republicans to $98,000. The bill, when completed, would be the cornerstone of $500 billion worth of savings over the next five years. The rest of the deficit-cutting would come from restraining the defense budget in a separate bill and from savings from projected payments on the national debt. White House budget chief Richard Darman was in the Capitol Monday participating in the talks. On Sunday, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and other administration officials left the meetings, complaining that Democrats were not responding to GOP offers. The meetings went on without them.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: credit policy.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which climbed 122.77 points last week, slipped 4.70 to 2,516.09. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 8 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 838 up, 725 down and 429 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 152.65 million shares, against 221.48 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 1.12 to 171.52.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened Monday against all major currencies in worldwide trading. Gold prices declined. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.60 a troy ounce, down $3.20 from Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $369.50 an ounce, off $3.25. Currency dealers said internal market influences were largely responsible for the dollar's across-the-board gain even though the currency remains fundamentally weak. Some dealers said the dollar had been due for a ``correction'' following its rapid decline over the past few weeks. The plunge in oil, by more than $5 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange on Monday, helped the Japanese yen, since Japan is heavily dependent on oil imports, dealers said. They said the dollar was indirectly boosted by the subsequent cross-trading between the yen and other currencies. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 126.25 Japanese yen from 125.25 yen Friday. The dollar traded at 126.00 yen in London, and at 126.015 yen in New York, up from 125.95 yen Friday. The dollar was stronger against the British pound compared with levels Friday. Sterling cost $1.9495 in London, less than $1.9590; and $1.9455 in New York, down from $1.9585. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes on Friday, included: 1.5182 German marks, up from 1.5025; 1.2835 Swiss francs, up from 1.26805; 5.0815 French francs, up from 5.0295; 1,137.00 Italian lire, up from 1,124.25; and 1.17605 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17305. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday: 1.5135 German marks, up from 1.5040; 1.2800 Swiss francs, up from 1.2700; 5.0662 French francs, up from 5.0380; 1.7060 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6940; 1,134.25 Italian lire, up from 1,127.00, and 1.1725 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1675. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $367.75 an ounce from $372.75 Friday. In Zurich, gold was bid at $369.00 an ounce, down from $372.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.22 an ounce to $371.36. Silver prices also slipped. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current deliery settled at $4.194 a troy ounce, down 6.4 cents from late Friday. Silver fell in London to $4.21 an ounce from $4.28.

DOC.HEAD: Posts $91 Million Loss in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Monday it lost $91 million in the third quarter due to the heavy costs associated with the media and entertainment giant's merger last year. But the company said that excluding interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization costs, third-quarter earnings were up 4 percent from comparable results a year earlier. The quarter included record operating results from its filmed entertainment recorded music, cable television and HBO programming units. Operating results fell slightly in magazines for the quarter due to losses at the new Entertainment Weekly magazine, while operating earnings tumbled in books because of the absence of a contribution from Scott Foresman and Co., the textbook publisher sold last December. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Time Warner lost $4.05 a share in contrast to a loss of $124 million, or $4.62 a share, on a pro forma basis a year earlier. Interest, depreciation and amortization costs amounted to more than $600 million in the latest quarter. The pro forma results for 1989 indicate what Time Warner would have lost had Time Inc. owned all of Warner Communications Inc. for the full year. Time bought a 59.3 percent interest in Warner in July 1989 and acquired the remainder of Warner this past January. Revenue for the quarter rose 9 percent to $2.9 billion from $2.66 billion a year earlier. Ed Atorino, who follows Time Warner for the investment firm Salomon Brothers Inc., said the results showed a ``very solid'' operating performance. ``Although they lost a lot of money, the operating numbers were very encouraging even for the magazine group,'' he said. In magazines, Time Warner said it had operating earnings of $38 million compared with $41 million a year earlier. The division would have had record results as well despite the depressed state of the magazine advertising market, company executives said, had it not been for losses at Entertainment Weekly, the magazine of entertainment reviews and features launched in February. The company failed to say how much the startup magazine lost in the quarter, but Atorino said company executives told analysts that seasonal factors produced a slightly larger loss than expected for the quarter. He said the company previously had projected a $50 million loss on the magazine for the year, or about $12.5 million per quarter. Other magazines in the group are Time, Life, People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune. Operating profit in the book division fell to $16 million from $66 million in the quarter a year ago when Scott Foresman contributed profits of $57 million to the total. Operating earnings climbed 36 percent to a record $140 million in filmed entertainment for the quarter, bolstered by record domestic syndication revenue that included sales of the TV shows ``Head of the Class,'' ``Alf'' and ``Perfect Strangers.'' In recorded music and music publishing, Time Warner has record operating earnings of $109 million, up from $108 million a year earlier led by domestic releases from Keith Sweat, AC-DC and Faith No More. The cable TV group had record operating earnings of $198 million in the quarter, up from $165 million a year earlier, and the programming-HBO division had record operating earnings of $45 million, up from $42 million. For the first nine months of the year, Time Warner lost $193 million, or $10.59 a share, compared with a pro forma loss of $257 million, or $11.75 a share, a year earlier. Nine-month revenue rose 7 percent to $8.23 billion from $7.69 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: U S West Signs Soviet Telephone Venture
DOC.TEXT: U S West signed a joint venture agreement on Monday to build the first commercial cellular telephone network in the Soviet Union. ``With the monumental changes occurring in the Soviet Union, communications will play a vital part in the country's future success,'' said Jack MacAllister, chairman of U S West. The agreement was signed in Leningrad with the Leningrad City Telephone Network Production Association and the Leningrad Station of Technical Radio Control. MacAllister said the agreement involves an initial $6 million investment in cellular equipment by U S West International Holdings, a subsidiary of U S West. The system is expected to serve 3,000 customers by mid-1991. It could be expanded to serve 50,000 customers. U S West is providing technical, financial and operational expertise for the project. The Soviets will provide interconnection to the local network, local network talent, land, buildings and labor. U S West began service to the first cellular system in Central Europe in Budapest, Hungary, on Oct. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Plunge $5.41 A Barrel
LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices plunged a record $5.41 a barrel in heavy trading Monday on a combination of Middle East peace hopes, technical trading factors and a report of an apparition appearing to Saddam Hussein in his sleep. The drop in the November contract for light, sweet crude oil to $28.38 per barrel marked the biggest single-day drop since futures contracts began trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange in 1983. The previous record was a $4-a-barrel decline on Aug. 17, the Merc said. But the sudden erosion of the so-called ``war premium'' may not show up at the gas pump anytime soon. Analysts said it would take anywhere from three to 14 days for price movements to be passed along to consumers, presuming the downward trend continued. Analysts cautioned that Monday's decline might have been exacerbated by the expiration of the November contract. Activity typically is volatile ahead of a contract's expiration as dealers try to settle their accounts. The November crude contract, which had traded above $40, lost $6.50 a barrel last week. The last time the near-term contract traded below $29 was in the second week of September. Other contract months fell $3 a barrel, the limit for contracts beyond next month. Because the difference in the decline between those contracts and the November contract was so great, traders are expecting prices to fall further at Tuesday's opening. Prices for refined products traded on the Merc also plummeted. The November contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline, which lost 9.22 cents last week, fell 11.41 cents to settle at 76.50 cents a gallon. The contract for home heating oil for current delivery declined 12.42 cents to settle at a 75.98 cents a gallon after losing nearly 17 cents last week. The November contracts for refined products do not expire until next week. Oil prices began tumbling in Europe's energy pits and opened sharply lower in New York as markets reacted to comments by Saudi Arabian Defense Minister Prince Sultan, who suggested that Arab countries were willing to grant Iraq ``all its rights.'' Market observers called Sultan's comments the most conciliatory since the crisis began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. His comments were interpreted as a sign that Saudi Arabia was prepared to agree to Kuwait ceding some land to Iraq. Traders pushed prices lower on the belief that this development might lead to a peaceful resolution of the Gulf crisis. Unconfirmed rumors continued to tweak the market. One had Iraq pulling back its troops, while a more outlandish report appearing in a Kuwaiti newspaper said Iraqi President Saddam was inclined to withdraw from Kuwait because the prophet Mohammed instructed him to do so in a dream. ``Between Saddam's dream and increasing supply and declining demand, the market is weaker than the Oakland A's,'' said Peter Beutel, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. of Hoboken, N.J. On the fundamental side, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said oil production in September was 22.7 million barrels a day, or about 200,000 barrels a day higher than previous estimates, according to the Cyprus-based newsletter the Middle East Economic Survey. Production at that level fully compensates for the shortfall created by the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. ``The market has been in a downward mood for the past week and a half . . . but the general consensus is that it will find support,'' Jim Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.F. & Man International Inc. Despite the drift lower, Fiedler said there remains a hefty amount of skepticism that ``we've got peace breaking out overnight as long as Saddam's in power.'' In natural gas trading, the November contract closed at $1.970 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.900 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: UN Study: OPEC, British, Soviets To Reap Billions From Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf-Oil Prices Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis will mean billions of dollars in higher oil revenues to the OPEC nations, Britain and the Soviet Union, but Eastern Europe and the Third World will suffer, a top U.N. official said Monday. ``A sharp rise in oil prices has darkened the prospects for global growth and hit the oil-importing developing countries and Eastern Europe particularly hard,'' said Rafeeuddin Ahmed, the undersecretary-general for international economic and social affairs. Oil prices have risen sharply since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, driving the price per barrel to about $40 earlier this month. Prices tumbled Monday below $30, but their long-term direction remains unclear. Based on the pre-crisis per-barrel price of $21, developing countries expecting to pay $30 billion for oil in 1991 will instead face bills of $45 billion to $60 billion, Ahmed told the General Assembly's Second Committee, which deals with economics. ``For many of these countries, this will be an unbearable additional burden,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market settled for a mixed showing Monday after last week's rally ran into resistance from sellers. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which climbed 122.77 points last week, slipped 4.70 to 2,516.09. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 860 up, 719 down and 422 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 152.65 million shares, down from 221.48 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 185.91 million shares. Analysts said buyers were leery of chasing after the sharp runup in stock prices late last week, given persistent uncertainties over the business outlook. Government budget talks bogged down over the weekend, leaving a major problem facing investors unresolved. At the same time, however, brokers said the mood in the marketplace had been given a big lift by the recent slide in oil prices. Crude oil for November delivery, which ended last week at $33.79 a barrel, tumbled to the neighborhood of $28.50 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. If inflationary pressures abate, many observers believe the Federal Reserve will be encouraged to relax its credit policy. General Electric led the active list, down 1} at 53} on volume of more than 2.6 million shares. A Barron's magazine article contended that the company's GE Financial Services operation might be vulnerable to the credit problems that have afflicted many banks and insurance companies. GE called the story ``highly speculative'' and ``misleading.'' Other losers among the blue chips included Coca-Cola, down | at 45[; American Telephone & Telegraph, down [ at 33]; McDonald's, down ] at 27[, and Sears Roebuck, down { at 25]. Federal National Mortgage rose 1[ to 29. David Maxwell, the company's chairman, said it expected to post record earnings for the year and looked for ``strong performances'' in 1991 and 1992, even in the event of a recession. Pittston, which reported sharply higher sales and profits for the third quarter, gained ~ to 20]. Blockbuster Entertainment dropped ] to 19} amid some evident disappointment over the size of the third-quarter earnings increase posted by the operator of video rental stores. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $17.82 billion, or 0.61 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added 1.12 to 171.52. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.47 to 369.89, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.28 at 314.76. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 3.76 to 341.12. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 292.23, down 1.48.

DOC.HEAD: Mosbacher, Serra Kick Off 5-City Tour on Free Trade Agreement
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and his Mexican counterpart, Jaime Serra Puche, on Monday began a five-city tour to promote a proposed U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement that would eliminate trade barriers between the countries. The pair told 300 Houston business and civic leaders attending the first full day of the traveling seminar on U.S. and Mexico business alliances that the free trade agreement could enhance economic opportunities for both countries and make North America more competitive with the European Economic Community. Canada reached a similar agreement with the United States two years ago and is considering joining the proposed alliance as a trilateral agreement. ``This is a win-win situation,'' Mosbacher said. ``We will be creating more jobs and more business on both sides of the border.'' He said there will be more U.S. jobs in the form of management teams and business owners and investors as well as complimentary firms in the United States while Mexico will benefit with more jobs, less outward migration and a more structured economy. ``The growth in Mexico is likely to produce increased demand for U.S. goods,'' Mosbacher said. He estimated U.S. exports to Mexico could rise from $52 billion last year to $100 billion by the year 2000. But he said that increase would depend on the approval of the agreement by Mexico over the next two years and in the coming months in Congress. ``If all goes well, we can hope to have an agreement in force by early 1993,'' Mosbacher said. He predicted such a pact would produce ``a combined output 36 percent more than the entire EC's.'' Serra said recent advancements in Mexico to stabilize the economy by reducing trade tariffs have laid the basis for serious negotiations for an alliance. ``In 1982, Mexico was one of the most closed economis of the world and today Mexico is one of the most open economies of the world,'' Serra said. He noted the nation's more relaxed trade restrictions that dropped import licensing requirements for 100 percent to less than 2 percent of imports during that period. At the same time, the maximum tariff dropped from 100 percent to 20 percent, encouraging more import investments. Serra said Mexico also has allowed two-thirds of its firms to be 100 percent open to foreign ownership, dropped its effective tax rates to encourage business development and cut regulations on its transportation and shipping industries. ``In Mexico, we are committed to becoming a world-class competitor,'' Serra said. Mexico is the United States' third largest trading partner, behind only Canada and Japan. ``From the beginning of this century, the U.S. has been Mexico's biggest trading partner,'' Serra said. The ``Road Show,'' as Mosbacher and Serra call their series of information seminars will continue in Dallas, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles in the next four days.

DOC.HEAD: Second T-Bill Auction Postponed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS lead to make auction $19.2 billion sted $18.8 billion; 4th graf, The Treasury, to make it $9.6 billion each of both 13-week and 26-week bills, sted $9.4 billion.
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department on Monday postponed a $19.2 billion auction of 13-week and 26-week bills because of inaction on legislation raising the debt limit. It was the second auction within a week to be delayed because the debt ceiling has been reached. The Treasury on Thursday postponed an auction of $10.75 billion in 52-week bills. The debt limit dropped from $3.195 trillion to $3.12 trillion Saturday and a bill to raise the ceiling is mired in negotiations between the Bush administration and Congress over a budget for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The Treasury had planned to offer $9.6 billion each of 13-week and 26-week bills in its weekly auction Monday. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve said Monday the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.58 percent last week, down from 7.62 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Hangs Tough Against Oil Price Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices fell Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange, but analysts said the metal held up well against a record-breaking plunge in oil prices in response to speculation Iraq would withdraw from Kuwait. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures also fell, and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled $3.20 to $3.40 lower in New York with the contract for spot delivery at $369.60 a troy ounce; silver ended 6.4 cents to 6.9 cents lower with the spot contract at $4.194 a troy ounce. Gold and oil prices often move in sync, because precious metals are considered a safe haven when oil is rising. But gold did not respond as strongly to oil's recent gains as many observers expected it would. And on Monday, gold did not fall as sharply as the conventional wisdom would dictate. In oil trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for November delivery of light, sweet crude oil fell $5.41 to $28.38 a barrel in the market's sharpest move since crude oil futures began trading in 1983. The previous record move was a $4-a-barrel drop on Aug. 27. Other crude oil futures tumbled $1.38 to $3 a barrel. Crude oil's loss, combined with a $3.01 decline on Friday, represented a 23 percent drop in the near-term delivery price in just two days. During the same period, the spot gold price fell 50 cents, or a little more than 1 percent. Frederick Demler, metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said gold's performance indicates the gold market never perceived $40-a-barrel crude oil as a sustainable price. He said the fact that gold prices did not collapse along with oil was ``bullish overall'' for the gold market. Oil prices plummeted amid increasing speculation that the standoff in the Persian Gulf is moving toward a peaceful resolution. The sell-off was prompted in part by a Kuwati newspaper report that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein told top aides the prophet Mohammed told him in a dream that his missiles were pointed in the wrong direction. Wholesale heating oil futures settled 6 cents to 12.42 cents lower on the New York Merc with November at 75.98 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline ended 6 cents to 11.41 cents lower with November at 76.50 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of government reports that indicated cattle supplies were larger and pork-belly supplies smaller than the markets had expected. The Agriculture Department's quarterly cattle-on-feed report showed 10 percent more cattle on feedlots as of Oct. 1 in the 13 largest cattle-producing states than at the same time a year earlier. In another report, the USDA reported there were 4.8 million pounds of frozen pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers as of Sept. 30 compared with 32 million pounds a year earlier. Live cattle futures settled .17 cent to .45 cent lower with December at 76.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .35 cent lower with October at 86.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .58 cent lower with December at 53.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.1 cents to 1.43 cents lower with February at 65.75 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade in a day of light trading influenced by harvest pressure, rumors of Soviet grain purchases and volatile outside markets. Dry conditions were expected to continue for most of the week in the Midwest, where the corn and soybean crops are centered. After the close, the USDA released a weekly report showing the corn harvest 47 percent complete and the soybean harvest 57 percent complete as of Sunday. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.63\ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $1.24\ a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to 5 cents higher with November at $6.10} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Taking On 3 Partners for Satellite Business
DOC.TEXT: Loral Corp., which is acquiring the communications and weather satellite business of Ford Motor Corp., is taking on three European firms as partners in the venture, Loral announced Monday. Loral said it had signed memoranda of understanding with Aerospatiale Societe Nationale Industrielle, Alcatel NV and Selenia Spazio SpA, who are expected to pay $182 million for 49 percent of the new firm, Space Systems-Loral. Space Systems-Loral is part of Ford Aerospace Corp., which Loral is acquiring from Ford Motor for $715 million. Ford Aerospace's other space-related businesses, whose main customers are the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Pentagon, are not part of the deal announced Monday. Loral said it would retain a 51 percent stake in Space Systems-Loral and would be responsible for managing the business. Space Systems-Loral is expected to design, manufacture and support telecommunications and weather satellites. Under Ford Aerospace, the business has been responsible for the Intelsat VII telecommunications satellites. Loral said its prospective partners have worked with Ford Aerospace since the early 1970s on projects including the Intelsats.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 17 Percent Drop in Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Reebok International Ltd., blaming sluggish U.S. sales of its footwear, reported a 17 percent drop in third quarter earnings Monday. Reebok said earnings totaled $41 million, or 36 cents per share, for the quarter that ended Sept. 30. That compared with earnings of $49.8 million, or 44 cents per share, for the same period a year earlier. Sales for the quarter increased to $588.8 million from $524.5 million in the same three-month period in 1989. Paul Fireman, chairman and chief executive officer, said sales for the Reebok brand outside the United States exceeded $360 million during the first three quarters, an increase of 119 percent. Last month, the company said it expected third quarter earnings would drop to the 33-35 cent per share range, due to lower U.S. sales of its Reebok brand footwear and higher advertising and promotional expenses. Fireman said the results were slightly higher than expected because of increased shipments from the company's international division and better-than-anticipated U.S. sales. For the first nine months of 1990, earnings totaled $137.1 million, or $1.20 per share, on sales of $1.67 billion. That compared with earnings of $140 million, or $1.23 per share, on sales of $1.44 billion in the same period a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Institutes Paint Gloomy Picture for East German Workers
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of former East Germany's workers will have fewer working hours or no job at all by next year, Germany's five leading economic institutes predicted Monday. It was one of the gloomiest employment forecasts ever for East Germany, which united with West Germany on Oct. 3. Economic growth is also slowing in what used to be West Germany and growth for the whole nation will likely reach only 1.5 percent in 1991, the institutes said. Two top German officials responded to the report by saying its unemployment prognosis for eastern Germany was too pessimistic. New investment in the region will quickly create new jobs, Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann and Finance Minister Theo Waigel said. The five institutes said about 1.1 million people in former East Germany are either jobless or working shorter weeks. The region now has 8.4 million workers. The region's unemployment problem will peak sometime next year with 1.7 million jobless and 2 million others working fewer hours, the report forecast. The region will average about 1.4 million jobless and 1.75 million with fewer working hours in 1991, it said. Workers in the region are losing their jobs because many aging factories and businesses are unable to compete in the new free-market system. The report predicted that production in eastern Germany will stailize by the middle of 1991, but that the job market won't immediately benefit. ``The necessary transformation of the east German economy will need much time,'' the report said. The report said the economic transformation of former East Germany is occurring more slowly than expected because of a slow rate of privatization, questions of property ownership, the continued existence of ``monopolistic operations'' and difficulties in ``building up a public sector that is capable of achievement.'' The institutes also said a slowdown of the world economy and shrinking exports will limit Germany's overall growth. In former West Germany, economic growth in 1991 will slow from 4 percent predicted for 1990 to 2.5 percent, the institutes forecast. The report was published by the DIW German Institute for Economics in Berlin, the HWWA Institute for Economic Research in Hamburg, the IFO Economic Research Institute in Munich, the Institute for World Economics in Kiel and the RWI Economic Research Institute in Essen. The report assumed that oil prices would gradually decline,but remain higher than they were before Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The researchers said they did not expect higher oil prices to dampen the German economy as long as wages don't climb. But they acknowledged that the Gulf crisis presented considerable risks to any forecast.

DOC.HEAD: Former Junk Bond Customer To Plead Guilty To Criminal Charges
DOC.TEXT: A major Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond customer with close ties to Michael Milken has agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges related to dealings with the firm, a federal prosecutor said Monday. The government was expected to use the plea by Richard Grassgreen, who resigned last week as chairman of Enstar Group Inc., to bolster its case at a pre-sentencing hearing on new allegations against Milken. The disclosure by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jess Fardella came during the sixth day of testimony on charges that Milken committed an array of crimes beyond the six felony counts to which he has pleaded guilty. Fardella said Grassgreen will plead guilty to two felony counts for personally receiving fees on financings paid for by Kinder-Care Inc., Enstar's predecessor. Grassgreen's lawyer, William Schwartz, did not return a call seeking comment. Kinder-Care, a Montgomery, Ala.-based day care company, was built largely with money raised by Drexel through the sale of high-yield junk bonds. Grassgreen and Milken had a close relationship and Milken and his advisers often pointed to Kinder-Care as an example of a successful junk bond-financed company. Details of the charges against Grassgreen were not disclosed. But people familiar with his case said they were related to misappropriating corporate funds and failing to disclose to his board his personal interest in MacPherson Investment Partners, a fund created by Drexel that invested in Storer Communications Inc., another Drexel-financed takeover deal. The 1985 Storer takeover is one of the main subjects of the special pre-sentence hearing on Milken underway in federal court. Prosecutors have sought to show Milken misappropriated valuable Storer stock warrants and used them to bribe customers into buying risky Storer securities. The accusation is part of the government's attempt to show Milken was a systematic lawbreaker. They want to convince U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood he deserves a severe punishment. He faces 28 years imprisonment. Grassgreen was expected to testify as a witness at the Milken hearing on Tuesday about the Storer transaction, along with former Drexel chief executive Frederick Joseph. It would be Joseph's first public testimony against Milken. On Monday, a lawyer who worked for Drexel said he questioned whether the firm had properly disclosed plans to allocate millions of dollars worth of Storer equity to important clients and Drexel employees. According to the government's charges, five Drexel-affiliated investment partnerships acquired 82 percent of certain Storer equity warrants without legally disclosing the interests. A large block of the preferred stock and the warrants were repurchased by Drexel from a customer, Atlantic Capital, shortly after the Storer deal was completed and in turn sold to MacPherson, one of the Drexel-formed investment partnerships. It consisted of several Drexel employees and major investors the government claims were given a stake by Milken as gratuities. One-third of the partnership was held by a trust for Milken's children. The outside parties included Columbia Savings & Loan Chairman Thomas Spiegel, takeover strategist Nelson Peltz and Occidental Petroleum Corp. Chairman Ray Arani. The government has charged that Drexel client David Solomon was sold an interest in MacPherson to compensate for trades conducted by Drexel to help him generate illegal tax losses, a transaction included in Milken's guilty plea. The Drexel lawyer, Craig Cogut, testified that the failure to disclose the 82 percent stake in the Storer raised questions in his mind. ``I was concerned as to whether it was appropriate for individual representatives of clients to receive these partnership interests,'' he said. Cogut also said that a fund manager who was given a stake in MacPherson in 1987 became concerned whether the investment was appropriate. But he said he did not discuss the disclosure with Milken. He also said Milken's brother Lowell handled the bulk of drafting documents and structuring the Storer deal, and that he had very little contact with Michael Milken. The government dropped criminal charges against Lowell Milken as part of Michael Milken's guilty plea in April.

DOC.HEAD: Nintendo to Allow Licensees to Manufacture Own Games
DOC.TEXT: Nintendo Co., which has strictly controlled the manufacture of games for its entertainment systems, has offered U.S. companies that design the games the chance to manufacture them, a company spokeswoman said Monday. Lynne Gray, a spokeswoman for Nintendo in Los Angeles, said the company sent a memo to its licensees on Oct. 3, offering the chance for them to manufacture their designs. No one has signed up yet to do so, Gray said, describing the program as experimental. The Japanese company licenses designers to produce games for its patented systems and manufactures the game cartridges itself in Japan. Nintendo's wildly popular computer system revitalized the video game industry in this country. Gray said the experimental offer was unrelated to a Federal Trade Commission investigation of Nintendo for possible anti-competitive practices. Nintendo had been studying the possibility of allowing games to be manufactured by licensees for some time, Gray said. It waited, she said, until it could be assured that quality control could be maintained by outside manufacturers. Nintendo makes many of its own games, including its No. 1 game, ``Super Mario Bros. 3,'' which has sold 8 million copies since its introduction earlier this year. It licenses 53 other companies to design games, but maintains exclusive marketing rights. Nintendo, whose subsidiary Nintendo of America Inc. is based in this Seattle suburb, estimates total video game market retail sales for 1990 at $5.1 billion. Of that, Nintendo estimates it will capture $4.1 billion or 80 percent. It forecasts it will sell about 9 million of its game systems this year. The systems range in price from $79.95 to $149.95. Nintendo spokesman Richard Lindner said the FTC investigation stemmed from allegations made late last year by Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, that Nintendo was stifling competition. Lindner said the FTC has been examining company records and talking with officials from Nintendo and its licensees, competitors and retailers since shortly after the first of the year.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Third-Quarter Profit Increases 3.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. said Monday its third-quarter profit rose 3.6 percent as its travel-related business flourished but its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. brokerage subsidiary posted a loss for the period. American Express said it earned $343.8 million, or 74 cents per share, up from $331.8 million, or 77 cents per share, in the same quarter of 1989. The drop in per-share earnings reflected an increase in the number of American Express' outstanding shares. The company's revenue tumbled 6.8 percent to $6.06 billion from $6.5 billion a year earlier. The decline was largely attributable to a slump in revenue at Shearson, where sales fell 23.3 percent to $2.52 billion from $3.28 billion. Shearson recorded a loss of $5.4 million, compared with earnings of $40.9 million in the same period of 1989. American Express blamed the loss on the slowdown on Wall Street that has put a crimp in business at many investment firms. American Express also noted that third-quarter 1989 earnings at Shearson were boosted by an after-tax gain of $37 million from the sale of its institutional money management division. Earnings at other American Express subsidiaries rose. The company's travel-related business, which includes its charge card and travelers check operations, earned $277.1 million in the third quarter, up 15.1 percent from $240.8 million last year. American Express said the number of its outstanding credit cards increased 7.3 percent to 36.2 million from a year earlier. The company's IDS Financial Services subsidiary recorded a third-quarter profit of $55.9 million, up 17.6 percent from $47.6 million in the same period of 1989. American Express Bank, which operates largely outside of the United States, reported earnings of $34.7 million, up more than 63 percent from $21.3 million a year earlier. And American Express Information Services reported earnings of $26.7 million, up nearly 24 percent from $21.6 million the previous year. For the first nine months of 1990, American Express earned $43.6 million, or 4 cents per share, on revenue of $18.34 billion. During the same period in 1989, the company earned $899.8 million, or $2.09 per share, on revenue of nearly $18.73 billion. The nine-month figure reflects Shearson's $915 million first-quarter loss that resulted from a restructuring of the Wall Street firm.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution-Control Bill Clears Major Hurdle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf: ``But White,'' with 3 grafs bgng: ``Late Monday,'' White House comment clarifying position on bill. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators approved a clean-air bill Monday that is expected to eventually cost the economy $22 billion a year and affect most of American society by toughening pollution controls on automobiles, factories and power plants. The bargainers worked out the final details before dawn, ending more than a year of bargaining between the two chambers. Late Monday afternoon, the conference committee gave the measure formal endorsement, with only Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., opposing it. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the legislation ``historic in its significance'' and said he expected both the Senate and House to endorse it and President Bush to sign it into law. Final approval from both chambers is expected by week's end. Bush, meanwhile, noted that tougher clean-air legislation ``has been 13 years in coming'' and said that ``no American should have to wait another day for clean air.'' Republican members of the clean-air conference, including Rep. Norman Lent of New York and Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, predicted that Bush would sign the bill. Late Monday, White House officials indicated that the president would likely look favorably on the bill, including the compromise job-assistance program. ``While we have to take a look at the final language, we are encouraged by the agreement reached on (the jobs assistance) amendment,'' said White House spokesman Steve Hart. Earlier, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater had indicated that the administration was still not satisfied by worker assistance program, although he too said the administration ``has not signaled a veto.'' Under the legislation, there would be drastic reductions in emissions of acid rain pollutants and toxic industrial chemicals. In addition, more than 100 cities would be given five to 15 years to bring their air quality up to federal standards, mainly by controlling pollutants that cause smog. The new requirements would be expensive, although cost estimates vary widely. The White House estimates the legislation would cost the economy $11 billion a year by 1995 and $22 billion to $25 billion annually by 2005, when the bill's provisions would take full effect. Industry estimates have put the cost in the $30 billion to $50 billion range toward the end of the decade. While conceding that the controls would cost in the tens of billions of dollars, environmentalists have argued that much of the cost can be expected to be made up from savings in health costs. The American Lung Association estimates that perhaps $50 billion a year could be saved in reduced health expenses from cleaner air. To improve air quality, the nearly 700-page bill would: -Tighten controls on tailpipe emissions, cutting smog-causing pollutants from motor vehicles by 30 percent to 60 percent. Businesses such as dry cleaners would also have to cut smog-producing emissions. -Require the sale of cleaner gasoline blends in cities with the worst smog problems and a phase-in of alternative-fuel vehicles in taxi and other fleets. A pilot program using private alternative-fuel cars would also be started in California. -For the first time control industrial releases of 189 toxic chemicals, including many carcinogens, through the installation of pollution-control equipment. Toxic air emissions, which total more than 2.4 billion pounds a year, would be cut by 90 percent by the end of the decade. -Reduce annual sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning power plants by 10 million tons, cutting nearly in half such acid rain-producing emissions. Midwestern utilities, reliant on high-sulfur coal, would be hit the hardest. Many of the plants will have to install expensive ``scrubbers'' or switch to low-sulfur coal. Those prospects have led many lawmakers to call for a financial aid program for miners who lose their jobs because of the tougher pollution controls. As they finished work on the bill, the negotiators agreed to a $250 million, five-year program to help workers who lose their jobs, but only if tied to a retraining program with strict qualification standards. Congress worked more than a year to craft the legislation as lawmakers struggled to find compromises that would overcome strong regional interests amid intense lobbying from the myriad of affected industries. The House and the Senate approved separate versions of clean-air legislation earlier this year, but the task of reconciling differences proved slow and difficult. Indeed, while representatives of the two chambers began their work in mid-July, there was no significant progress until earlier this month, when agreement was reached on automobile pollution. House and Senate negotiators followed with agreements to reduce toxic industrial chemicals and, on Sunday, reached an accord on acid rain.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arraigned in Theft of GM Pictures
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested a former photo technician for General Motors Corp. Monday on charges he tried to get the automaker to pay $75,000 for stolen confidential photographs of GM cars. Gregory Charles Hooper, 36, of Royal Oak, was charged with mail fraud in a complaint filed by the U.S. Attorney's office, the FBI said. He was released on bond. Hooper faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The FBI began an investigation June 16 after receiving a complaint from GM that some photographs of cars it was working on were appearing in magazines. Hooper allegedly tried to obtain $75,000 from GM for the return of the photographs, the FBI said in a statement. Last November, GM offered a $30,000 reward for the arrest of whomever was responsible for leaking pictures, slides and drawings of a variety of future GM products to auto enthusiast magazines. Among them were photos of what was described as the yet-to-be-released 1991 Saturn automobile. ``Such crime has a profound impact on GM's future competitive position and we will continue to cooperate with the FBI in its investigation of how these materials were obtained and who may have purchased them illegally,'' said GM spokesman Don Postma. Postma said Monday the $30,000 had not been paid.
